para.tab:
The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa)
took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.title: Petrol Excise
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

para.tab: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the increase in excise of 7 cents per litre on leaded petrol and 5 cents per litre on unleaded petrol resulting from the Budget. This rise in petrol tax:
1.discriminates against low income families and those living in rural areas
2.increases business costs and will cause further unemployment
3.adds further to the price of an already heavily taxed product
4.breaks Mr Keating's election promise not to put up tax.
And your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate oppose these increases in petrol excise.

petition.presenter.block:
by
Senator Calvert
(from 197 citizens),
Senator Campbell
(from 665 citizens, Senator Kemp (from 139 citizens) and Senator Ian Macdonald (from 692 citizens).

petition.title: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

para.tab: The petition of the undersigned strongly oppose attempts by the Government to increase the level of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) and to decrease the threshold at which graduates begin to repay their HECS debt.

Wherefore, your petitioners, request that any further changes to the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) be referred to a committee that will assess the impact of fees and loans on higher education.

petition.title: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

para.tab: The petition of the undersigned strongly oppose attempts by the Government to increase the level of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) and to decrease the threshold at which graduates begin to repay their HECS debt.
Your Petitioners ask that any further changes to the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) be referred to a committee that will assess the impact of fees and loans on higher education.

petition.title: Aerial Spraying
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

para.tab: We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to phase out aerial spraying in accordance with recommendation 89 of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia.

petition.title: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

para.tab: The Petition of the undersigned shows: That the laws passed in December 1992 counting unrealised capital gains on shares held by pensioners as income for the purposes of the social security income test are unfair, illogical and discriminatory, and should be repealed as soon as is practicable.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should: (1) note that the Liberal and National Parties now oppose the laws after voting for them in December; (2) condemn the government for persisting with the laws; and (3) take whatever steps are necessary to achieve the repeal of the laws mentioned above.

petition.title: Australian National Flag
petition.para: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

para.tab: We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the Constitutional Monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian Flag.

petition.para: And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Radio 6PR
petition.para: To the Honourable, the President and the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

para.tab: We the undersigned call on the Senate to support the granting of a narrowcast broadcast licence, to allow Radio 6PR's talk back programs to continue broadcasting.
We understand that the failure of the Minister to grant this licence will result in job losses and the cancellation of vital afternoon talk back programs.

We believe that the Honourable Minister for Communications, Senator Bob Collins, should give his immediate and special consideration to the granting of a narrowcast licence to allow the vital role 6PR plays in Western Australia to continue.

petition.para: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Genetic Engineering and Cloning
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

para.tab: We, citizens of Australia and custodians of the Earth, draw to the attention of the House our concern at the continued use of genetic engineering and cloning of human beings, animals, plant life, microbes and foods, along with the unknown consequences to the Earth's natural life forms and environment, in order for individuals and multinational companies to patent and own the food resources of the world.

We request you to pass laws prohibiting the continued use of genetic engineering and cloning of human beings, animals, plant life, microbes and foods. We want you to protect humanity from the patenting and owning, by individuals and large corporate bodies, of unnatural life forms.

petition.title: Detention of Asylum Seekers
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

para.tab: that the Australian Government's policy of detaining people seeking asylum has caused enormous hardship and misery for those detailed;
the policy has contravened international obligations undertaken by Australia;
as a result of the detention of asylum seekers the Australian community has borne a considerable financial burden;
Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government:
to end the policy of detaining asylum seekers, and
to release those asylum seekers still being held in Department of Immigration Processing Centres.

petition.para: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

petition.title: Bougainville
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and the Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament.

para.tab: The petition of citizens and residents of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the plight of the people of Bougainville. We call on the Australian Government to:
end military aid to the Government of Papua New Guinea.
demand the withdrawal of the Defence Forces of Papua New Guinea from Bougainville and an end to the blockade of Bougainville.
recognise the right to self-determination of the people of Bougainville.

petition.title: Lead Standards in Petrol
petition.para: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:

para.tab: Vehicle emissions are having a serious impact on the health of Australians and include lead emissions which are of sufficient volume to cause a permanent reduction in the intellectual capacity of young children in inner city areas, and benzene emissions which are highly carcinogenic and cause acute myeloid leukemia.

Your petitioners ask that the Senate should support a national uniform and legislated standard of lead in petrol of no more than 0.026 grams per litre, and a national uniform and legislated standard of benzene in petrol of no more than 0.8 per cent of total volume.

petition.title: Credit Unions: Limited Tax Exemption
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

para.tab: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that the Government proposes to abolish the limited tax exemption of Credit Unions, thereby affecting the ability of Credit Unions to provide alternative, low cost convenient financial services to Australians.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to REJECT the Credit Union provisions of the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993.

talk.start.para:
—by leave—The committee's concerns with these instruments include apparent lack of review rights, prejudicial retrospectivity, invalid subdelegation, lack of notification of rights and unfair procedures. As usual, I seek leave to incorporate in
Hansard
a short summary of the matters raised by the committee.

para.tab: Leave granted.

speech.para: AUSTRALIAN DRIED FRUITS BOARD (AGM) REGULATIONS STATUTORY RULES 1993 NO.144
These Regulations provide for procedures relating to Annual General Meetings of the Australian Dried Fruits Board.

The Explanatory Statement advised that the AGM of the Board for 1991-92 must be held on or before 30 June 1993. As the Regulations were only gazetted on 23 June 1993 there may have been some difficulties in complying with them.

The Regulations attempt to deal with this problem by providing that certain provisions do not apply to the first AGM. However, these exceptions may themselves have affected the rights of persons entitled to vote at the AGM.

More significantly, there is a number of other provisions affecting rights of voters which apparently could not have been complied with and which do not appear to have been excepted. These include correcting voter details, giving notices of motion and appointing proxies.
The Committee believes that personal rights expressed in legislation should be clear and unambiguous.
RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS REGULATIONS STATUTORY RULES 1993 NO.177
These Regulations, among other things, provide for a system of penalties using the infringement notice procedure.

One provision sets out the consequences which flow from the payment of a penalty under an infringement notice. In short, the liability of the person is discharged, no further proceedings may be taken and the person is not regarded as having been convicted of the alleged offence.

These safeguards emphasise the personal rights of those affected by the infringement notice scheme. However, their effectiveness is considerably reduced because there is no requirement for an infringement notice to notify people of these rights. The regulations provide for such a notice to contain a variety of information, but not these important safeguards. This is a matter which the Committee has raised in respect of a number of similar schemes. In every case the Minister has undertaken to amend the relevant instrument to provide for notification of safeguards.
PRINCIPLES NO.NHP 2/1993 UNDER S.40AA(7) OF THE NATIONAL HEALTH ACT 1953
These Regulations amend the funding arrangements for approved nursing homes.

Several of the Principles provide for the Minister or Secretary to determine certain matters. This appears to grant legislative power to those officials. The Committee has written to the Minister asking whether this subdelegation is authorised by the parent Act. If it is valid, the Committee asks why it should not be subject to tabling and disallowance.

It is a breach of parliamentary propriety if an instrument purports invalidly to subdelegate power which the parent Act has restricted to specified persons or organisations. On the other hand, if subdelegation is valid then its exercise should be subject to parliamentary scrutiny.
FIFTH AMENDING DEED TO ESTABLISH AN OCCUPATIONAL SUPERANNUATION SCHEME FOR COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYEES AND OTHER PERSONS UNDER S.5 OF THE SUPERANNUATION ACT 1990
This amending deed to a superannuation scheme for Commonwealth employees changes some of the definitions in the principal deed.

The amending deed grants two discretions to the Board which administers the scheme. In the first of these the Board is initially limited by reasonable criteria. However, the relevant provision then expands the criteria to include "any other matters that the Board considers relevant". There is a similar broad criterion in the second discretion, which merely refers to the opinion of the Board.
The Committee looks closely at such unrestricted powers and always seeks an assurance that their inclusion is justified.
IMPORTED FOOD CONTROL REGULATIONS STATUTORY RULES 1993 NO.100
The Regulations set up a Food Inspection Scheme for the inspection of imported food.

Regulation 35 provides for the Secretary to waive a fee for a chargeable service. The only criteria to limit and control this power is that the fee would be unreasonable in all the circumstances. In this case there is a variety of fees payable, up to $88 per half an hour for public officials to assess food shipments. The Committee has asked for an assurance that this discretion is covered by the review provisions in the parent Act.
The power to waive a fee is one of the more important administrative discretions and the Committee always ensures that its exercise is subject to appropriate safeguards.
OCCUPATIONAL SUPERANNUATION STANDARDS REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT) STATUTORY RULES 1993 NO.189
These Regulations amend the Principal Regulations to prohibit schemes which provide financial assistance to, or intentionally acquire assets from, members of superannuation funds or their relatives.

These provisions cover the period until the commencement date of the proposed Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act, the Bill for which was introduced in the House of Representatives on 27 May 1993.

The operation of new r.18BB(3) may retrospectively prejudice funds and persons who have entered into an affected scheme before the regulations commenced on 30 June 1993. In such a case the scheme may consist of a contract which is partially performed, with part payments or deposits paid and with possible formal legal commitments.
The Committee has sought advice on the effect of this provision on contracts partially performed.
SUPERANNUATION (PSS) FEES REGULATIONS STATUTORY RULES 1993 NO.200
SUPERANNUATION (CSS) FEES REGULATIONS STATUTORY RULES 1993 NO.201

These Regulations set application fees of $150 for reconsideration of decisions by the Boards of Trustees which administer the PSS and CSS superannuation schemes. The Explanatory Statements did not advise of the basis upon which the fees were set.

Any power to set fees or charges is an important and sensitive exercise of executive discretion. In such cases the Committee always ensures that the level chosen is not harsh or unreasonable. In the present cases the fee is particularly important, because it relates to the initiation of a review procedure.
GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT) STATUTORY RULES 1993 NO.206
These Regulations provide for permission to enter the Park and for permits to carry out activities in the Park.

The Regulations include a number of discretions, only some of which provide criteria to limit and guide their exercise. Some of these discretions appear to affect commercial operations and the livelihood of individuals. In these cases the Committee seeks confirmation of the existence of review rights.
AUSTRALIAN SPORTS DRUG AGENCY REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT) STATUTORY RULES 1993 NO.210

These Regulations provide safeguards for disabled and disadvantaged sporting competitors who are selected for drug testing. These safeguards seem comprehensive. However, their effectiveness may be reduced because they are voluntary, not compulsory. The Committee believes that procedural safeguards for personal rights should be enforced as strictly as practicable.
OCCUPATIONAL SUPERANNUATION STANDARDS REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT) STATUTORY RULES 1993 NO.213
These Regulations amend the operation of private sector superannuation funds.

The Regulations confer a number of discretions upon the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. There is no indication whether these discretions, which could affect the retirement rights of working Australians, are subject to review of their merits. The Committee always seeks full information about discretions which have an effect on individuals.
GUIDELINES UNDER S.18 OF THE TOBACCO ADVERTISING PROHIBITION ACT 1992

The Guidelines provide criteria for deciding whether a sporting or cultural event is of international significance and whether Australia is likely to lose the event because of restrictions on tobacco advertising.

The Committee's concerns relate to the drafting of the instrument. The criteria generally appear appropriate, apart from the final criterion in each case, which is that the Minister is to take into account "any other information that the Minister believes is relevant". The Committee has sought advice on why it was necessary to include such a broad and subjective criterion following specific and detailed criteria.
FORMULATION OF PRINCIPLES UNDER S.58CD OF THE NATIONAL HEALTH ACT 1953
These Principles fix a formula for a Commonwealth benefit.

The Principles provide for a specified sum, or such larger amount as determined by the Minister "from time to time" under another provision of the Act. The Acts Interpretation Act 1901 restricts the categories of material, as amended from time to time, which may be incorporated by an instrument. The Committee has suggested that it may be worthwhile obtaining advice from the Attorney-General's Department on the validity of this incorporation.

talk.start.para: —I give notice that it is my intention, at giving of notices on the next day of sitting, to withdraw business of the Senate notice of motion No. 1, standing in my name, for the disallowance of the South East Fishery (Individual Transferable Quota) Management Plan 1991 (Amendment) (No. 3). I seek leave to make a short statement.

para.tab: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I gave notice of my intention to move to disallow this amendment in response to concerns expressed by people who felt that this amendment would have a detrimental effect on them, particularly in relation to prosecutions which are pending under the Fisheries Act 1952. I am now satisfied that the disallowance of this amendment would have no effect, detrimental or otherwise, on the prosecutions and, in fact, this amendment may advantage the people concerned. Any doubts that might remain concerning the legal validity of this amendment are not a matter for the Senate and, should they be raised during any legal actions, they will be dealt with by the courts in an appropriate manner.

para.tab: The move to disallow this amendment also gave me time to investigate many other concerns that have been raised by those who are most affected by the management plan and these ongoing concerns may be addressed by the standing committee's current investigation into the adequacy of the Commonwealth fisheries legislation. Finally, I would like to note that the timing of this amendment, 23 December 1992, after parliament rose, and not being tabled until May 1993, meant that the amendment could not have been disallowed before the management plan expired on 31 December 1992. Therefore, there was no possibility that a disallowance could have had any real effect prior to the expiry of the plan.

speech.ministerial: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL
speech.speaker: Faulkner Sen J.P.

talker.name: Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs)

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para:
I table the explanatory memorandum and seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in
Hansard
.

para.tab: Leave granted.

The speech read as follows
—

speech.para: This Bill amends the Migration Act 1958 (the Act) to simplify the operation of the "points" system provided for in the Act. The "points" system provides for the application of a competitive points test which is used to assess people of working age seeking permanent entry to Australia under the Independent Entrant and Concessional Family classes.

Presently, the "points" system sets out three marks against which an applicant's score is compared "applicable pass mark", "applicable priority mark" and "applicable pool entrance mark". Currently the way in which the "points" system operates is that the pass mark and priority mark are set at the same level and a pool entrance mark is set at a lower level. Applicants whose score is equal to or more than the pass and priority mark proceed to further processing and applicants whose score is less than the pool entrance mark are rejected. Applicants whose score is at least equal to the pool entrance mark but less than the pass mark are placed in the pool and can be removed by meeting a subsequently gazetted pass mark. However, applications in the pool that fail to meet the pass mark after three gazettals are rejected.

Variations in the pass and priority marks are one way that changes in demand for migration are managed between one program year and the next. Adjustments can be made to the level of the pass mark and priority mark to control the number of applicants who would be able to proceed to further processing. Therefore, where the number of successful applicants is inconsistent with the program planning levels the priority and pass mark can be lowered so that more applicants move to the next stage of processing or they can be raised so that fewer applicants move to the next stage of processing. The numbers in the "pool" can be increased by lowering the pool entrance mark, however the "pool" cannot be reduced by increasing the pool entrance mark.

There are a number of problems with the current operation of the "pool "mechanism. First, rejection of applications in the "pool" requires three pass mark gazettals and an applicant in the "pool" must be notified on each occasion. This process is administratively cumbersome. Secondly, there is no time requirement in which the three gazettals must occur. Therefore, they could occur on consecutive days or over a number of years. This provides little certainty or security for applicants. Thirdly, the system provides little flexibility to reject those who receive lower marks in the "pool". Finally, the current system of three different marks has confused applicants.

This Bill will remedy these problems by replacing the three mark system with a two mark system consisting of a pass mark and a pool mark. The Bill will also simplify the operation of the "pool" mechanism by introducing a mandatory time limit of twelve months after which time an application still held in the "pool" must be rejected. This will replace the current requirement of three pass mark gazettals which, as previously stated, could have occurred over a period in excess of twelve months.

Under the scheme proposed in this Bill an application where the assessed points score is at least equal to the gazetted pass mark at the time of assessment would proceed directly to the next stage of processing. An application where the assessed points score is less than the gazetted pass mark but at least equal to the gazetted pool mark would be placed in the "pool". An application where the assessed points score is less than the gazetted pool mark would be rejected.

The Bill sets out the manner for dealing with applications in the "pool" and provides that an application in the "pool" must be assessed against any gazetted changes to the pass mark and pool mark during a period of twelve months from the date of the original assessment. At any time over the twelve month period an application in the "pool" could proceed to the next stage if the pass mark is lowered, or be rejected if the pool mark is raised. If an application had not been removed from the pool by either of these means at the end of the twelve month period it would have to be rejected.

Variations in the pass mark and the pool mark will be notified in the Gazette. Each time these marks are varied an application in the "pool" will have to be compared with the varied marks. The Bill makes it clear that this comparison does not allow a reassessment of the applicant's assessed score.
The Bill also makes provision for the pass mark and the pool mark to be varied independently of each other. When the pass mark and the pool mark are the same, no "pool" would exist.

The transitional provisions in the Bill ensure that applications that are held in the "pool" on commencement of the provisions will be held in that "pool" for a further period of up to twelve months. This will ensure that no applicant is disadvantaged by the operation of the new provisions.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

speech.ministerial: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL
speech.speaker: Faulkner Sen J.P.

talker.name: Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I would like to table a replacement explanatory memorandum relating to these bills.

—The wine tax is a matter which is of crucial importance to my home state of Western Australia. I have a specific interest in it in that I have spent a lot of my recent years living in the Swan Valley district of Western Australia and have enjoyed many fine wines from the Swan Valley district, the Margaret River district and the rapidly expanding wineries in the south-west of the state of Western Australia.

para.tab: The wine tax which was announced by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) on budget night was, of course, an absolute shock to the industry right across Australia, particularly to the relatively young industry in Western Australia. Although it has had a very strong base in the Swan Valley since the first settlement and the planting of the first vines by John Septimus Roe and other people many years ago, the industry has rapidly expanded over the last 20 to 25 years. One needs only to look at some of the figures that have been achieved in terms of production increases in recent years to see just how important the wine industry has become to Western Australia, and how important it is when one considers that there is an enormous concentration on the importance of value adding to our primary products. This is to ensure that we do not just produce raw products and export them but we actually process those products. Wine is a classic example of how that has been done very successfully, both in Western Australia and in the wine making regions in the eastern states.

It is interesting to note that, in terms of value adding, wine when sold as the end product increases the value of the primary product, the bunch of grapes, by something like seven times. So it is quite a massive value adding process. The figures from Western Australia—and I will concentrate on Western Australia, being a proud and parochial Western Australian—have seen production increases even in the last few years. Going back to 1988-89, in terms of exports from Western Australia, we exported only $770,000 worth. The export figures—and these are figures provided by the Australian Bureau of Statistics—have increased in the latest year, 1992-93, to in excess of $2.57 million from Western Australia.

This is a tremendous performance and it is very important to note that much of this export performance has been created on the foundations of a very solid domestic market. The Western Australian domestic market is very important to young producers and I would like to use it in what necessarily will be a brief contribution to this debate. There are enormous numbers of speakers on the list and we would like to see these bills defeated, if possible today, for the benefit of the wine industry and the employment it creates.

To get back to the line of argument, I will refer to the example of a winery that I know very well that is not so far from my home. It is a winery called Jane Brook on the Toodyay Road just out of Midland. David and Beverley Atkinson, who are friends of mine, started rebuilding the Jane Brook estate and building up their market share and building up the acreages they have under vine. They have built up a good marketing image. They have a new range of products, aggressively marketed through cellar door sales and through selected bottle shops mostly for the domestic market and the local market in Western Australia. They have increased their production year after year and they have increased the number of crushings they do. In the last three years they have gone to Japan on a number of occasions with the help of Austrade and have sold their products into the Japanese market.

It is a highly competitive market and not an easy market for a small husband and wife team from Western Australia to break into, but my latest conversation with David indicated that he sold something like a container load of wine to Japan last year and I think he has doubled that export this year. He is also providing wines to some international airlines. This is a tremendous achievement. It is actually a good example that proves the government's arguments, that the tax will not affect export markets, to be quite fallacious because export markets will be developed only if we have a thriving domestic industry. If a 55 per cent increase is put on the tax it will affect domestic sales. It will decrease sales.

Senator McMullan has admitted that in answers to questions in the Senate on this matter in recent weeks. He has said it will not affect the government's revenue because if the sales of bottles of wine go down people will transfer to buying beer. He is saying there is a total sort of elasticity there; people will just move from one product to the other. It does not really matter if people stop buying wine because if they stop buying wine they will buy a bottle of beer and the government will collect the revenue from that. So Senator McMullan has admitted that the tax will potentially decrease wine sales. Of course, all of us know that if the price goes up people will either buy cheaper wines or not buy at all.

This will have a devastating impact on an industry that has been one of Australia's export success stories in recent years. Only a year ago I was at a supermarket in London—I think it was Sainsburys—buying groceries to have a home-cooked meal. I was very proud to see in the wine section of Sainsburys a whole range of Australian, including Western Australian, wines for sale at very reasonable prices. The market share of Western Australian and Australian wines in England is rocketing. I visited France last year as the guest of the French government and I found that the French are extremely jealous of Australia's success in wine marketing because we are rapidly taking away their traditional markets in the United Kingdom for champagne and red and white wines. Our wine industry is a tremendous success story.

Let me make some other brief comments about the importance of this debate. The Green senators, my colleagues from Western Australia Senator Margetts and Senator Chamarette, initially agreed with Senator Kernot and Senator Lees on the Australian Democrats' position that this matter should be deferred for a year. I spoke to the press and suggested that Senator Margetts and Senator Chamarette would not be acting in the best interests of Western Australian wine producers and winegrowers if they were to agree to defer that tax. In fact, in a slightly flowery press release, I suggested that, if a sentence of a thousand lashes is imposed on someone, it is of little comfort if the person is told that the sentence will be delivered on him in 12 months time. It really does not help very much.

talk.start.para: —We are voting against it.
—I am getting to that. I understand that.
—Make it clear that we are voting against it.

—I am sure Senator Kernot will make it clear and I will help to make the position clear. I am very pleased that the Greens, after consultation with wine grape growers and wine makers in Western Australia, have decided to support a total blocking of this measure and that the Democrats will also be doing that.
—We announced that five weeks ago.

—I know. I thank Senator Kernot for setting the record straight. Another interesting occurrence is that the views of a former minister for primary industry, John Kerin, were published in the
Australian
newspaper this morning. The former minister described the proposal as being based on ignorance, stupidity and prejudice. In the letter that he wrote to people, in which he was obviously responding to concerns from the industry, he described very well and very articulately the difference between taxes on beer and other spirits and taxes on the wine industry.

para.tab: He said that it takes four to seven years to create a crop that can be crushed commercially. Even after four to five or six years, when that crop has been developed, it is exposed to the vagaries of the weather and, as people like Senator Panizza who grow wheat would know, there is still an enormous risk involved. Mr Kerin said that it costs $30,000 to $35,000 per hectare to establish a crop. All that money is paid up-front and it takes at least four or five years to get any sort of commercial return. So the wine industry is very different from other industries, and Mr Kerin should be complimented for having the honesty to expose the flawed decision making that has taken place on this measure.

I understand from reading the front page of today's
West Australian
newspaper that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, is now putting his hat into the ring in the leadership stakes for the prime ministership. I understand from talking to my mother earlier this morning that Randal Markey wrote that story. It does not surprise people on this side of the chamber that there is a leadership struggle going on. Clearly, Mr Keating has enormous problems with his petulance and the fact that he will not debate the Leader of the Opposition or even take him on in question time. It does not surprise us that there are rumblings on the back bench of the Australian Labor Party.

It is very good to see that there are some other Labor Party speakers who have added their names to the list this morning—people like Senator McKiernan, who is a well-known supporter of Mr Keating, Senator Loosley, Senator Carr and Senator Foreman, who have all added their names to the speakers list on this bill overnight. I presume that these Labor Party speakers will be coming out to stick up for their constituents in the wine industry and, hopefully, support Mr Kerin's line.

talk.start.para: —Wait and see how they vote.

—Indeed. I conclude by saying that the negotiations that have taken place with the wine industry over the past few weeks, where the government has been offering carrots in terms of early tax write-offs, industry support mechanisms and so forth, further reinforce the argument that this tax is a very bad tax and that it will hurt the wine industry. The ameliorative measures that the government is offering the wine industry are recognition of the fact that the tax will severely hurt the industry, and further support the wisdom of the opposition's position and the wisdom of the position adopted by the Democrats, I am informed by Senator Kernot, some five weeks ago. I commend them for that wisdom and I commend the wisdom of my Western Australian colleagues from the WA Greens—Senator Chamarette and Senator Margetts.

para.tab: I look forward to these bills being defeated, for the wine tax to be axed and, more importantly, for there to be certainty in the minds of those in the wine industry and those who choose to invest in it and put their hard work and hard labour into growing the grapes, crushing the grapes and marketing the products nationally and internationally. They can then be assured with the strongest message to the wine industry from the Senate—from a majority of senators, including the Democrats and the Greens—that a wine tax today, tomorrow, next year or the year after is off the agenda and that people in the industry can go ahead and invest with certainty. The message will be that if the government ever tries to bring a 55 per cent increase to a very important industry like this into this place it will be booted out as quickly as it is today.

talker.name: Senator KERNOT
talker.role: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

talk.start.para: —It is necessary to revisit the history of this debate while we are at the point of making a decision to increase rates of sales tax, amongst other things in these bills. We had a rejection of the GST by the Australian people. We had an obscene tax cuts auction. We have the return of a Labor government with a revenue raising problem.

para.tab: The government has chosen to change the tax mix by increasing the rate of wholesale sales tax. The choices that have been put before the Australian people have been quite simple ones—a GST or a wholesale sales tax. The government and the opposition have rejected other, more progressive suggestions such as a jobs levy, the abolition of negative gearing, the removal of some of the exemptions from the capital gains tax or increased marginal tax rates for very high income earners.

We are hoist on our own petard in this country because we all want an increased level of services, yet nobody wants to raise taxes in a progressive way. Nobody wants to pay more tax but we have ever increasing demands. Many families are affected by unemployment. They expect the members of their families who are unemployed to get unemployment benefits. We have to pay taxes to provide those unemployment benefits. We have to raise taxes somehow, and I am not afraid to say that the Democrats support some of those more progressive taxation options.

If we are given a choice, however, between a wholesale sales tax and a goods and services tax, why do we choose a wholesale sales tax? There are trade-offs all the time in politics. Although the wholesale sales tax is not as pure in terms of simplicity and efficiency, the Democrats believe its great merit is that it has the capacity to discriminate. By contrast, a consumption tax is a very blunt instrument. It offers no flexibility in terms of how heavily it falls on those least able to bear the burden of the taxation, specifically, low income earners. Although the wholesale sales tax is not perfect, it is superior if we are debating a choice—as I think we are, as a nation—between a goods and services tax or a broad based consumption tax and a wholesale sales tax.

The sales tax is imposed by four acts, namely, a duty of customs, a duty of excise, a tax on in situ swimming pools and a tax that is none of the above. Thus we have these changes in five separate bills—one for each of the four categories and one to make the consequential changes to the sales tax assessment acts to put into effect the changes to the sales tax treatment of luxury motor vehicles. The bills we are debating contain the following measures: an increase of all sales tax rates by one percentage point from budget night, a further increase of one percentage point for all sales tax rates from 1 July 1995, an increase in the rate of sales tax on wine and an increase in the rate of tax on luxury motor vehicles.

Mechanically, if we put the politics aside, the increases in sales tax are quite straightforward. I would, however, like to ask the minister to address the comment that I have heard that one of the unintended consequences of the proposal to increase the rates is to lead to a complication of the calculation of the tax. Whereas 10, 20 and 30 per cent are quite simple to use, I would like to know whether it is true that 11, 21 and 31 per cent are not. That suggestion has been made to me.

The proposal will raise approximately half a billion dollars, about $1 billion from 1995 to 1996. We would like to see that revenue used for constructive and appropriate purposes, such as job creation. We do not want to see a situation where we tax the poor to fund income tax cuts for the wealthy.

The wine tax proposal is a different matter. I agree with Senator Campbell that the industry has done well in the last decade, but it is on the cusp of a burgeoning export boom and now is not the time to impose a massive increase in sales tax on it. I do not just stand here and say that we are opposed to taxation increase of any kind, but I think the government has failed to make out a cohesive rationale based on industry policy. This is very clearly a question of industry policy. The wine industry is a regionalised industry; whole communities are dependent on it. It is one of our success stories. Senator Lees will be elaborating on the Democrats' position and negotiations with the wine industry in her contribution to this debate later today.

The final matter is the alteration of the luxury car tax. One would have to say that this area of policy has had a pretty poor record over the last few years. Firstly, in the 1990 election campaign, the government announced an increase in the rates of tax from 30 to 50 per cent. This caused a delay in the implementation of the measure, which means that purchases are simply brought forward and consequently the extra revenue from the rate increase is never collected. Then we saw that the recession battered the luxury car market. Perhaps that is one of the most benign effects of the recession! This caused the government to reverse its decision, so subsequently we had a further finetuning of the tax to try to make it operate in a less anomalous manner. Today we are looking at the further change that we now have to the structure.

The tax on luxury cars further demonstrates my point about the ability of a wholesale sales tax regime to be discriminatory where a consumption tax is not. Luxury vehicles in excess of a $32,486 threshold are currently taxable at 30 per cent of their total wholesale value and cars below this threshold are subject to the applicable sales tax rate, depending on their classification. This has the effect that, once a car costs $1 more than the threshold, an additional tax on the `sub-luxury' part of the car is payable. We know what effect that has on people's purchasing decisions. I think that is a legitimate function of a taxation regime. The Democrats endorse this change.

As I have said in a previous speech relating to other parcels of the budget bill, the support we give them is qualified. These are not our priorities; they are this government's priorities within the parameters of a straitjacket of its own making. Nevertheless, the final shape of the budget is its prerogative, and it will live with the consequences. The Democrats derive some satisfaction from being able to inject fairness into the original budget proposals, and I think it shows that minor parties can make a significant contribution and can achieve significant change.

Beyond that, we respect the government's right to govern and to make the tough decision on how the budget shapes up. If it were up to us, we would have done it differently. So we give our support, with all of these qualifications and with the exception of the wine tax, to the other sales tax bills that we are discussing here this morning.

speech.speaker: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

talk.start.para: —The tax bills before us this morning heavily underscore the double bankruptcy of this Keating Labor government. First, it is financially bankrupt; secondly, and more importantly, it is morally bankrupt. Its moral bankruptcy is indeed more important than its financial bankruptcy, because this has destroyed the government's capacity to provide inspiring and effective national leadership. Quite simply, nobody in this country accepts the authority or legitimacy of this government anymore. That is the direct consequence of the government having lied its way to success at the last election and having broken its promises since then. And that is one reason why the Liberal and National parties are opposing these tax increases: they are the very antithesis of the Labor Party's campaign at the March election.

para.tab: These tax increases also underscore the government's financial mismanagement. Its incompetence in controlling government spending frenziedly feeds an insatiable and rapacious desire for more and more revenue. The government has become a tax junkie mainlining on more and more revenue. And that is another reason for opposing these tax bills.

It is time for this government to apply some real discipline to its spending. The government's claim to be reducing the tax burden is patently false. In the 10 years since this government came to office, the average tax rate on people earning average weekly earnings has increased from 23 per cent in 1983 to 24.4 per cent this year. On top of that, over the life of this government we have seen massive increases in sales taxes, fuel and other excises and many other taxes. This means that the tax burden on many Australians has increased. These bills seek to increase that burden even further. And that is another reason for opposing them.

The taxes in this legislation reflect a poorly constructed budget and inadequate analysis, and I am sure that we will see further repercussions from them if they do pass the Senate in the coming months, as we have already seen horrified reactions from individual constituents and from industries in the six weeks since those people were betrayed by this budget. It may be that Sydney has won the 2000 Olympics, but this Keating-Dawkins budget has most certainly already won the gold medal for government greediness, botched legislation and fumbled fiscal strategy. The government remains weak and ineffective, and completely devoid of real leadership in the eyes of the community.

Many of my colleagues want to direct their attention to these bills, so I will address what I believe is the worst aspect of the government's now somewhat revised revenue raising measures, that is, the 55 per cent impost on alcoholic wine, raising the rate of sales tax on that product from 20 per cent to 31 per cent. It does not matter whether you drink wine or not, the fact is that this tax will hurt ordinary Australians—Australians who are already overburdened with taxes and, in particular, Australians who derive their income from the wine industry. It will hurt them unjustifiably and in a regionally discriminatory way. It is particularly detrimental to my home state of South Australia, and that is another reason for opposing these bills. This industry is just starting to capitalise on its vast export potential, but now the government has come along and nipped all of that in the bud.

The Liberal and National parties, the Winemakers Federation of Australia, grape growers—indeed, anyone with an ounce of analytical capacity—know, even if this federal Labor government does not know, that because of this tax domestic sales of wine will drop by more than 10 per cent. The key victims of the tax will be grape growers in the Riverland areas of South Australia, in Victoria's Sunraysia district, and in the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area in New South Wales.

How do we in the opposition know this and apparently federal Labor does not? We know because the South Australian Labor government—a government of its own political persuasion, a government that will undoubtedly soon be in opposition, not only because of its own mismanagement but also because of the direct impact of this tax on South Australia—commissioned a quarter million dollar economic research program on the wine industry. That report predicts that 15 million litres of the domestic cask wine market will be lost because of this tax. That cask wine is not exportable. The report also predicts the reduction in domestic demand by 15 million litres of premium wine. In other words, total domestic demand will be 30 million litres less than it would otherwise be. This 15 million litres of premium wine would become available for the export market. Hence, there will be lower wine production, and this in turn means that the industry will invest less in vineyards, inventory and wineries to meet its overseas market opportunities.

In short, this government has done more to the wine industry than a year of bad harvests across the nation would have done to it. In fact, it is devastating the industry. This all represents a loss to Australian industry and lost opportunities for job creation—lost opportunities for Australians who want to pull themselves out of the economic malaise which surrounds them and put something back into this country and back into their own lives. Wine production throughput will be lost as a result of this tax, due to the loss of cask wine sales. This will increase production costs in Australia and will therefore increase the cost of the product they wish to export and make them less competitive on those overseas markets. This cost increase has been estimated to be around 16 per cent.

One can only wonder why this myopic Labor government cannot see that such an increase in costs will erode the international competitiveness of our wineries on highly competitive markets. But perhaps the chardonnay socialists across the aisle have failed to get out amongst their constituents, as I and my colleagues have done lately, to see what effect these ridiculous budgetary measures are having on ordinary Australians.

A continuing lack of international competitiveness is reflected in a further balance of payments deficit of $1.4 billion, or $80 per Australian last month. So as a country we are continuing to go further and further into debt. The government's commitment to Australia's international competitiveness is shown to be no more than lip service because of its high domestic tax regime. No other major wine industry anywhere in the world has to operate under such imposts. Brian Croser, the president of the Winemakers Federation of Australia, is on the record only weeks ago as saying in relation to this budget `that logic and wealth creation for Australia are the victims'; and further, that it `is now bankrupt of concern for the fate of one of Australia's most rapidly expanding export and highest value adding industries, and that is shameful'.

In addition to that South Australian government report to which I referred, a further report, the so-called Sharp report, challenges the claim by the federal Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) that the government's 55 per cent tax increase will not harm wine exports. The truth is that both reports provide independent proof that the Australian wine industry cannot afford the budget's savage tax increase. Exports and potential job growth will both be harmed. There is little doubt that reduced profitability will result in investment in new vineyards and winery upgrades being abandoned and marketing budgets being reduced, affecting primarily advertising and sales support. All of that affects jobs. Indeed, as I found in a visit to the renowned Coonawarra district a couple of weeks ago, new vine plantings have already been put on hold pending the outcome of this tax bill.

To demonstrate the depth of feeling from those involved in the wine industry and from constituents, I presented to the Senate last Thursday over 7,700 signatures, just from South Australians, calling for this unjust tax to be defeated. These signatures were collected in only a few weeks, which proves that Australian voters have already had enough of repressive tax measures. A search of the Senate records reveals this number of signatures to be amongst the highest ever presented to the Senate on a single issue. That they were collected in just a few weeks is truly remarkable. For most petitions attracting large numbers of signatures, the collection of signatures takes many months, even a year or two. To attract such numbers of signatures in just two or three weeks demonstrates the absolute outrage of the South Australian community at this proposal. Completed petitions are still coming in.

The Winemakers Federation and the Winegrape Growers Council of Australia have campaigned responsibly and professionally against this tax increase. Members of those industries are more than astonished at the Treasurer's attacks on them in his attempt to defend the government's position. The industry certainly sees the threat the government has made against them as particularly shallow. There is no doubt that a 55 per cent increase in tax will most certainly damage the low end of the market, which is required to undergird the overall profitability and expansion of this industry and to undergird its export potential. It is incredible that this government comes along and does this at the very time that this industry is successfully achieving such export growth.

The Treasurer has claimed that tax equity between wine and other alcoholic beverages demands that we have this impost, and we have heard very fanciful claims from him in justification for it. Each and every one of those claims has been shown by the industry, in documents they have presented to the government, to be fanciful and false, yet the government still persists with these false and fanciful claims. The claim is that tax equity demands that similar industries bear similar tax levels. To say that, in taxation terms, wine should be treated at similar levels to brandy, beer and spirits begs the question as to whether they are indeed like industries. Certainly they all produce alcoholic beverages, but a logical comparison beyond that suggests that they are not the same.

The beer industry relies on raw materials, with short production lead times, crops sown and reaped on an annual basis, plus the addition of water. The raw materials of spirits are essentially waste products. In contrast, grape vines, the raw material source for wine, require up to seven years from planting to adequate grape production. So the supply tap cannot be turned on and off over a short period in response to government tax policy that is detrimental to the industry.
This Keating Labor Government talks repetitively and correctly about the need for Australia to become internationally competi-

speech.para:
tive. International competitiveness includes having an internationally competitive tax regime, something this government refuses to provide. In particular, I seek leave to incorporate in
Hansard
a table showing the way in which wine is treated in Europe in taxation terms compared with other alcoholic beverages.

para.tab: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I thank the Senate. A study of that table will clearly show the preferential treatment that is provided in Europe to wine compared with other alcoholic beverages. That completely destroys this government's argument on tax equity grounds, the only argument that can be mounted for the tax. Given the disastrously detrimental effect this tax will have on the industry, it ought to be opposed and this legislation ought to be rejected.

—I rise to speak very briefly on the package of sales tax bills that we have in front of us. It is not necessarily all about wine, though people could be excused for thinking it was totally about wine. The government in its election campaign promised no new taxes. To attack our situation the government promised no new taxes and no increased taxes. Now we have this package of sales tax bills to complete the package of lies perpetrated by this government during the election. These budget measures come in with increased sales tax in every direction. In fact, these bills will total $1 billion in a full financial year.

para.tab: I am not going to spend much time on wine tax, but that tax is an attack on a growing industry. It is growing, but still small, and this attack when it could have done without it means people in that industry will be paying 55 per cent extra. The idea behind bringing in the increase in the sales tax on wine was to balance it up with beer and spirits; but if the government wanted to balance that up, I can think of an easier way to do that, and that is to reduce the sales tax on beer and spirits. That would have been much easier. It could also have looked at other measures to cut the wasting of money—something this government is good at doing—to balance the budget.

Increases in sales tax on any industry puts on it an impost that gets in the way of industries competing on export markets; but our wine industry also has to compete on the Australian market, so it will cause a loss in jobs. This government set out to increase job opportunities, and increasing job opportunities is what our GST package was about; yet here we have this government going in exactly the opposite direction. Last time this government put an increased tax on wine, there was a cut-down in consumption and a loss of jobs in the industry. Maybe some people reckon it is a good idea to cut down the consumption of wine. I do not know, I do not drink the stuff; but whatever the government wants to do, in this case what it is doing is bringing about the loss of jobs.

talk.start.para: —In Western Australia jobs will be lost in Margaret River, they will be lost in Mount Barker, and they will be lost in the Swan Valley. As Senator Beahan knows, two of those three places I have mentioned are regional areas, and these special regional areas like Margaret River have high unemployment. We want to increase job opportunities there, not cut them down. So where is this government going in attacking this industry?

para.tab: As I have said, I have no self-interest in the wine game. I am not in the industry, nor do I drink wine, so I have no self-interest. The only interest I have is for the people of Western Australia. It is marvellous how attitudes change over the years, is it not? Anyone as old as I am, who can remember back that far, will remember that anyone who drank wine 20 or 30 years ago was one of three categories: a ding, a dago or an Aboriginal.

talk.start.para: —Which one were you?

—I probably cover the first two categories. Now it has turned around. It is accepted in Australia, and there is an industry; so now the government has got to tax it out of existence. That is the situation we are in. The wine tax will raise only about an extra $100 million.

para.tab: But as I said when I first started, I am more interested in the other sales tax moves. There is a general one per cent rise: one per cent now, two per cent in August 1994. Let us look at the effect that will have on transport through plant and repairs, tyres and parts. For instance, in transport, for a prime mover that is worth about $200,000 wholesale, the tax will put $2,000 on it now and add $2,000 next year. That is $4,000. Look what that will do to the cost of transport and the cost of goods, especially in those rural and remote areas. Look at that sort of situation.

For the family car, there is to be a wholesale sales tax rise of one per cent this year and one per cent next year. That will be $300 there. For a set of tyres that cost, say, $200 each retail and $140 wholesale, it will put $1.40 on to each tyre this year and another $1.40 next year. What does this sort of measure do? It causes people to keep plant going longer. Plant that goes longer is not as safe, not as up-to-date and not as efficient on fuel. It is the same with cars. We are trying to get more modern cars on the road in Australia, ones that use unleaded fuel. The average car out on the road in Australia is 10 years old, a 1983 model that burns leaded fuel. So how is this measure going to help? All that increased sales taxes will do is stop or cut down the sales of new cars.

The first change in the sales tax will raise an extra $585 million. With the one per cent next year, it will raise a total of $1 billion. I have heard big noises about the sales tax on wine which will raise $100 million or less. The general rise in sales tax is the killer. It will be raising around $1 billion. We were criticised for coming out in our GST package with a balanced situation which was transparent. The government, in its package, lied about that.

My time is limited so I will wind up by stating generally what these bills do. In Australia, sales tax raises $9.44 billion a year. These bills will increase that by 10.6 per cent to $10.23 billion. That is about three times what inflation is today. It is a total disgrace. Government supporters lied. They tried to shoot holes in our Fightback package. Having lied their way back into government, what are they doing now? They are breaking every rule in the book and giving us these massive rises.

The government promised in the last election that there would be no new taxes and no rise in taxes, and what have we got? We have got one bill alone in front of us that is going to raise an extra $1 billion in a full financial year. It is a total disgrace. The tax will be loaded on to areas that cannot afford it, especially the export industries and farming. No-one can tell me that farmers do not pay sales tax. They do, especially on their transport gear.

talk.start.para: —Tell us about the GST?
—Senator Cook lied as much as anyone else about the GST.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Panizza has accused me of lying. That is not true. It is also unparliamentary and not acceptable conduct and I think he should be called upon to withdraw it.

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)
—It is unparliamentary, Senator Panizza, and I am sure you will withdraw.

talk.start.para: —If Senator Cook had not jumped up so quickly, I would have withdrawn that and accused him of mistruths or something like that, whatever fits him. The government has got itself into a corner and now it has to raise taxes left, right and centre. So I support my colleagues in rejecting these bills.

—I suppose the Senate is going through something of a fightback to inflict retribution on the government because the unlosable election was lost seven or eight months ago. It has taken some time to sink in over there on the opposition benches that the 10 years in opposition are now going to be 13.
—A long time.

—It is a very long time. I sympathise with Senator Short. It is something that we have not experienced on this side of the chamber for quite some time. One of the things that honourable senators and the general public ought to do is go back and have a look at the election promises. Senator Panizza, who has just concluded speaking, made the assertion that the government promised in the election campaign that there would be no increases in taxes. In my recollection of the election campaign—a very good election campaign to which many people contributed, which convinced the public to reject the people who now sit on the opposition benches—the government never made those grandiose promises as was asserted. It was said that there would be no general increase in taxation rates. What we are getting here is not what Senator Panizza asserted. Certainly, there are proposed increases in wine taxes. There is an 11 percentage point increase on wine; we all consume it from time to time.
—No, not all.
—That is 11 per cent, Senator Panizza. It is asserted, for political campaigning, that it is a 55 per cent increase. In actual fact it is going from 20 to 31 per cent—

para.tab:
Senator Ferguson interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Senator Ferguson, who is not in his correct seat, is interjecting on me. He will probably set the record right from the other side of the chamber because I think he is one of the few people over there who can actually count. The difference between 20 and 31 is 11, and it is an 11 per cent increase in the taxation treatment on wine.
—What?

—It is. I know Senator Panizza really does not know how to count. Take 20 away from 31 and the remainder is 11. That is what it was when I went to school. That is a little while ago, but it is still the same. I do not need a calculator to work that out and I know my colleague Senator Ferguson does not need a calculator, either.

para.tab: It is also said this will have a damaging effect on our export industry and the growth industry in Australian wines. This is a big lie; it is a big fib. This increase in tax on wine is not going to be levied against wines that are being exported; it is not going to be levied on them at all. The export part of the wine industry of Australia is exempted from that. Hopefully, that has put the big lie to bed as well. Following my speech, when Senator Ferguson gets to his feet, I hope he will agree with me, because I think he understands it, coming from the state that he does. He does know about this. I am not so sure that Senator Panizza does.

What I really wanted to talk about today is the double standards that exist from time to time in this place, in the other place and out there in the community. It is not so very long ago that we had a debate in this place about the increase in the excise levied on unleaded fuel. Part of the reasoning behind that decision to increase the excise on unleaded fuel was to do with the bad health effects on our community, particularly our children, caused by lead in the environment.

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Senator. I hope you will support that money going into a solution to the problem.
—I thank Senator Coulter for his interjection. I was actually hoping I would get some form of interjection in that regard.
—We support you for that reason and that reason only.
—It doesn't matter how much more it costs to drive in the country.

—I will take Senator Ferguson's interjection about the costs of driving in the country as well. I have been trying to get measurements of lead levels in the environment in my state of Western Australia. I have been able to get some indications of the ill effects of it by measurements in the capital city of Perth. Those measurements do not compare in any way with the measurements that have been made in Melbourne or in Sydney—certainly, in specific areas of those larger cities. It is not as bad a problem in Perth as it is in Melbourne or Sydney. But Western Australia is a big place; there are one million square miles in Western Australia.

para.tab: I have not been able to get measurements from the National Health and Medical Research Council or any other bodies as to what the lead levels are in some of the more populated areas outside the capital city—Kalgoorlie and Bunbury, for example. I have not been able to get readings for the smaller regional towns where my constituents live, either. So the point Senator Coulter was making a while ago about increasing the excise level of taxation on leaded fuels really does not apply right across this great nation of ours. But it was done for health reasons so we should all support it. Indeed, I think we all do support that.

talk.start.para: —You don't believe this stuff.

—Alcohol—and Senator Chapman would know about this subject—also has deleterious effects on the health of many of us. Indeed, from time to time on this side of the chamber we can look across and see, in some cases, just what its bad effects are. I exempt Senator Short from that.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I think Senator McKiernan is casting aspersions on people in this place that are not founded—in any shape, shadow or form.

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)
—Yes, I think that comment should be withdrawn.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I do withdraw it. I will try to think of a better way of framing it. I was not directly pointing at any individual member of the opposition. There is Senator Brownhill, and I note the presence now of my colleague from Western Australia, Senator Crane. I come back to the point before us of the sales tax and its effect on wine. Without question, the abuse of alcohol does have a bad impact on many of the citizens in our society. There are unfortunates in our society who are addicted to it. Those people are not going to be helped. It could be argued that an increase in sales tax on wine, on the alcohol content of wine, would be helping those people.

para.tab: I am surprised that the people who argue, for health reasons, that we ought to increase the excise on leaded fuel, on cigarettes, or on other forms of alcohol—spirits and beer—do not come forward and exercise the same measure of concern when we are talking about tax on wine. Not all people who consume wine are addicts or are badly affected by it, but surely everybody would agree that there are some people who are very badly affected by it.

talk.start.para: —It also affects their behaviour.

—Yes, Senator Panizza, it impacts on their behaviour. It does cause real damage in our society. From time to time, violence in the home and the community is seen as the direct result of the abuse of alcohol. I wonder about the double standards when we talk about wine. Much has been made about the growth of this industry. It is a wonderful industry for this country, not only for its role in the halting of imported wine, but also for the export dollars that have been earned from the product. Levying taxes and levying increases in taxes are not popular in any shape or form; they never are.
—Especially when they cost jobs.
—That is where the big lie is. I hope that when Senator Ferguson speaks, coming from the state that he does, he will clearly make the point that no export jobs will be lost because of this action.
—You lot argued this way back in 1984 or 1985. There is no evidence for it. The wine industry has grown.

—I think Senator Cook's interjection is correct, because every time there are increases in taxes or excise we get predictions from that side of the chamber of gloom and doom—it is going to be the end of the industry, and hundreds of thousands of people are going to be tossed out of jobs. I recall the debates here when the wine tax was introduced. As Senator Cook rightly reminded the chamber just a moment ago: there was gloom and doom, and it was going to be the death of the industry, a growth industry at the time.

para.tab: Those opposite should go back and measure the number of people that were in jobs at that time and compare it to what it is now. There has been no gloom and doom; their predictions did not come true, just as their election campaigning that went on earlier this year did that lot more damage than it has done us. It does society no good when they continue with these predictions of gloom and doom.

Another tax that we imposed—we removed an exemption, more properly—was the gold tax, which my colleague Senator Panizza knows a good deal about. He continues to argue the gloom and doom and despair argument that the industry will die because it is going to be paying its rightful share of tax, just as every other extraction industry in this country—including primary producers—has to pay taxes on things. That industry was brought into stream with everybody else, but at the time we heard the gloom and doom and predictions of despair and the death of the industry. We look at the gold industry now, as we look at the wine industry, and we see that the people who own and operate those industries are very resilient. They will grow.

The wine industry will take this tax in its stride. There will be a short period of adjustment and then we will move forward, and all the predictions of gloom and doom, which I do not expect to hear from Senator Ferguson, will be put to bed until those opposite pick up a new issue to run with in their despair to try to give themselves some credibility in the community. It is a difficult job, because they have not been doing it for the last 10 years, and we seen no signs at the moment that they are ready to give themselves some credibility for the future.

speech.speaker: Ferguson Sen A.B.

talk.start.para:
—I listened with interest to Senator McKiernan, as he traversed a fair bit of territory in that speech. It is interesting to hear him talk about the effects of the wine tax, because those views are not shared by all of his colleagues. Certainly they are not shared by one of his colleagues who was quoted in the
Australian Financial Review
this morning in an article that is headed, `Minister cops wine tax penalty'. The article goes on to say:

speech.para: Guess which federal minister admits he forgot the Budget?

para.tab: And as a result had to fork out an extra $1,700 on wine he was purchasing for fundraising in his marginal seat?
None other than the Federal Minister for Development Co-operation and Pacific Island Affairs, Mr Bilney, whose electorate of Kingston takes in some of South Australia's premium wine country.
Several weeks before the Budget, Mr Bilney ordered 200 cases of 1989 McLaren Vale Shiraz, but did not get around to paying for it.
`Then came the Budget,' he writes in a letter to his prospective wine buyers.

speech.para: I want Senator McKiernan to take particular note of what he then says:

para.tab: Who would have thought that John Dawkins, recent Barossa Valley land purchaser and my friend, would have put up the sales tax on wine from 20 per cent to 31 per cent?

speech.para: One of Senator McKiernan's colleagues says: who would have thought that Mr Dawkins would have put that up? The article continues:

para.tab: Mr Bilney recounts that the next day he received `a stinking fax' from the wine supplier, revising his quote upwards by $8.50 a case.

`And just in case you're wondering whether you can avoid the wine tax, there isn't a wine maker in Australia who's not adding it on to their wholesale prices, right now—or a retailer who's not adding a lot more,' he writes.

Mr Bilney is philosophical about his problem because, like most retailers, he has simply passed the tax impost on to his customers. `For this wine, paying the tax is worth it—and no mistakes,' he writes.

speech.para: I wonder what is going to happen if this wine tax is not passed by the chamber. I wonder whether Mr Bilney is going to refund all of those people that are currently paying far more for those bottles of wine than they may have to, if that wine tax is not imposed. I can remember when this budget was introduced; we were told that it was a budget about jobs, and yet jobs in regional Australia are going to be affected by these regressive increases in sales tax because the vineyards and the wineries that are involved are all in regional Australia.

talk.start.para: —But—
—If the minister will just wait a minute, I will cite some evidence.
—There will be no job losses because of this measure. You know that.

—Rubbish! When I raised the issue at Estimates Committee E, I asked Senator Schacht who was representing the Minister for Tourism (Mr Lee) what the effect of the increases in tax on wine and fuel excise would be on the Barossa Valley wine industry. Senator Schacht said that the attractions of the Barossa Valley are such `. . . it would not be significantly affected in any way. There might be a bit of a dip'.

para.tab:
Obviously, he has not read the report by Katrina Ball, Elizabeth Geddes and Malcolm Buckby from the South Australian Centre for Economic Studies—
Impact of Wholesale Sales Tax on Wine—1993 Budget.
The report, I might add, was commissioned by the South Australian Labor government to show up the flaws and inaccuracies in the report relied on by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) when deciding to increase the sales tax on wine. One of the major findings of this study is that the increase in sales tax on wine will exacerbate the economic depression in the irrigation regions of Australia and, in particular, the Riverland area of South Australia. The draft industry report shows that the Riverland area, which forms part of the statistical division of the Murray Lands, is one of the four poorest regions of Australia already. Mr Dawkins used one report.

talk.start.para: —How? Anyone can say anything, but how can they justify it?
—How can Mr Dawkins justify the report that he used?
—Don't you understand?
—Yes, I do understand.
—Don't you understand that the wine tax will be paid, no matter what it is?

—Let me quote some of the other figures and then the minister may himself be able to understand. Let me say that three of the four poorest regions of Australia are in the South Australian rural and regional areas. The Yorke Peninsula-Lower North, the Murray Lands and Eyre regions all record average personal incomes of less than $14,000 per year and now there is an added impost in these areas which are already suffering. Senator McMullan comes in day after day saying that this budget is to try to help those people who are low income earners and yet here we have the people who are in the lowest income earning areas in Australia who are the ones who are suffering the most. It is very interesting to note that the people living in each of those three areas are represented by Liberal federal members of parliament. Liberal members are representing those people on lower incomes whom government members always claim that they can do the best for. Government members always claim to represent the low income people and those in the lowest socio-economic groups.

para.tab:
Let me go on and give some idea of the effect of this wine increase on some of the small producers. It is the small businesses and small producers which are the ones that we are looking after. I would like to read one of the many letters that I have received from wine producers over the past months since the budget was announced. This is one letter written by two very small wine producers from Eyre Peninsula. Eyre Peninsula is one of those poorer economic regions where the average household income of something like 60 per cent of the people is less than $25,000 a year. It is from the Delacolline Estate and the Boston Bay wine producers in Port Lincoln. I will read into the
Hansard
this short letter which was written to me. It states:

speech.para: Dear Sir

At the present time, we represent the only members of the grapegrowing and wine industry on South Australia's Eyre Peninsula. In the light of the recent savage increase in sales tax applicable to wine products, it is unlikely that we will be joined by others in the foreseeable future.

Both of our vineyards were established in 1984. The first commercial release of wine from either vineyard was in October 1988. When the first plantings were done, there was no sales tax applicable to wine products.
The first tax was introduced at a rate of 10% in 1984, throwing out all of our budget projections by a significant factor.

By the time we reached a productive status, the tax had been doubled. Any budgetary adjustments that we made in 1984 were consequently rendered useless, even though those adjustments had been in place for four years whilst we waited for a commercially saleable product.

Neither of us is an exporter. The volumes of our production are such that we can only hope to realistically market our product on the domestic scene. Nevertheless, the real impact of this latest increase will be just as devastating as it is for larger producers who do export. We participate in a legitimate area of the wine market, namely the production of premium quality wines in small to medium volume. With others, we have evolved to meet a gap in the market place. Producers of our size must be extremely careful of the cost inputs whilst at the same time providing our products to the market place at a reasonable and acceptable price. We cannot overcome cost difficulties with increases in volume. This latest tax increase will go a long way to making it impossible for us to keep our products in a reasonable and affordable price range. The effective retail price on our products will instantly jump between $1 and $2 a bottle.
