We believe that the wine industry on Eyre Peninsula, however small, makes its contribution to what is already a fragile local economy, providing a level of employment, a market for local suppliers and contributing to a balanced tourist economy. There is a place for other producers to follow suit, but we believe that this most recent measure will quickly discourage any expansion of the industry in this region.
We urge that tax increases be reconsidered and we support the representations made . . . by the Winemakers' Federation . . . and the Winegrape Growers' Council . . .

That is signed by Mr Tony Bassett of the Delacolline Estate and Graham Ford of Boston Bay Wines. I think that highlights what will happen in the wine industry. There is no future for anybody else to take on small production, as these people have done since 1984, when the government has changed the rules. Every time they get near to putting wine into production, we see an increase which throws out all of their forward projections.

para.tab: I would like to make one other brief comment, Mr Acting Deputy President, on the issue of sales tax in general—that is just sales tax, without taking into effect the fuel taxes—and in particular its effect on regional and rural people. I note that the government still has not acted to amend the anomaly in the sales tax legislation with regard to spare parts used to recondition machinery which is later sold to exempt primary producers. It will cost primary producers another $10 million a year in taxes—$10 million which, as I have pointed out several times in this chamber, our rural sector cannot afford.

The government has already admitted that this is an unintended consequence, and yet we have seen no legislation introduced to change that sales tax provision so that those people in rural and regional areas who are being hardest hit at present will have the benefit of tax exemption on second-hand machinery. I will confine my remarks to those matters. I urge the government to reconsider the effect that the wine tax and the sales taxes are having on those people who can ill afford it.

speech.speaker: Tierney Sen J.W.

talk.start.para: —The bills that we are debating today are the result of the most farcical federal budget that has ever been delivered in this nation's history. The bills currently before the Senate seek to impose dishonest increases in taxation that the Labor Party did not even mention during the election campaign.

para.tab: In the coalition's response to the federal budget the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, outlined the position that the coalition would take. He said that we would vote against the four increases in taxation announced by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). During the time since the budget we have consistently opposed the increase in the fuel tax, the increase in the wholesale sales tax, the increase in the retrospective changes to taxation on accrued unused long service and annual leave lump sums, and the increase in wine sales tax. Since the budget, the opposition has been resolute and consistent in opposing all these increases.

This stands in stark contrast to the inconsistencies displayed by the Labor government since it brought down the budget on 17 August. We have seen since that time the spectacle of failed Treasurer Dawkins going through a whole series of backdowns.

The coalition has been forced by these budget measures to hold the government to its mandate and oppose the four major sales tax increases. They are a betrayal of the Australian electorate, they are regressive in their effects, and they will damage the Australian economy through increasing costs to businesses at a time in the economic cycle when they can least afford it.

talk.start.para: —By disrupting the government's mandate, you have damaged the economy already by increasing instability.
—We are not disrupting the government's mandate.
—Have a look at the exchange rate.

—Has the government got a mandate to increase these taxes? I cannot recall the Labor Party mentioning during the election any increase in the taxes that I have just outlined. That was not mentioned at all. The Labor Party was going to drop taxes, not raise them. The net effect of what the government is going to do is to raise taxes. It has no mandate for any of these measures at all.

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)
—I will have to ask that the interjections from my right cease.

talk.start.para: —Let us go through what the government did say in the election. It said that income taxes would be cut and there would be no offsetting rises in indirect taxes. Winning the last federal election on a campaign platform that was based on lies has left the government in the dilemma in which it finds itself today. The budget will go through, but the budget will go through in a more honest form that keeps the government to its mandate. That is what we propose to do in this debate and in the way in which we vote for these bills.
—You will try and disrupt government. That is what you will do.

—I do not think Senator Cook will find that coming out at the end of the day. I think what he will find at the end of the day is that the government will be held to its mandate. What this budget shows is that the government's campaign in the last election was a complete fraud.
—No, it wasn't.
—Of course it was.
—I have asked for the interjections on my right to cease and I would ask Senator Tierney to ignore them if they do continue.
—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I do enjoy Senator Cook's interjections. They show how frail the government's position is. But I will keep to your ruling.
—In the chair, I do not particularly enjoy them.

—Let us have a look at some of the effects of these sales tax rises. It is incredible that a government that is supposed to support and be representing people on lower incomes brings in such measures. The effect, particularly of measures like the wholesale sales tax, will be to put a disproportionate burden on the people who can least afford it. It has become more that way as the years have gone on. During the time of this government, we have found that the top 10 per cent of the population have become richer and the bottom 10 per cent have become a lot poorer. Now the government, with these sales tax measures, is putting the boot into this group yet again.

para.tab: The other major reason why the coalition has chosen to oppose the government's tax increases is their effect on jobs. We have almost one million people unemployed in Australia. We now have an unemployment rate of 11.1 per cent. But the Treasurer said that the primary objective of the budget was jobs. As I will go on to prove to Senator Cook in a few moments time, the effects of these measures will be actually to reduce jobs and increase unemployment. As a matter of fact, the New South Wales Chamber of Manufactures has calculated that under the measures of the budget there will be a loss of 50,000 jobs. That is of concern across the whole country, but to people like me who are based in a regional area like the Hunter Valley it is of particular concern because our rate of unemployment is much higher than 11.1 per cent. We have an unemployment rate of 13.4 per cent in the Hunter Valley.

The measures in this bill are going to be devastating for employment in an area where seven people join the dole queue every day. I have asked in this chamber and in the media on a number of occasions that the Australia Labor Party members of parliament who represent the Hunter Valley stand up for the Hunter Valley, cross the floor and vote against these measures. Unfortunately, when the bill went through, they did not do this. I assure the Senate that we let the people of the Hunter know well and truly that their so-called representatives in the Hunter were voting for measures that put up their taxes and put their families out of work.

The effect on the wine industry, not just in the Hunter but Australia-wide, has been pointed out by the South Australian Centre for Economic Studies. It was interesting to listen to what Senator Cook had to say earlier. He kept saying, `Prove it'. This is a proper research body. The study was funded by the Arnold government. I say to Senator Cook that the Labor government of South Australia thought so much of his government's measures that it spent $250,000 on funding this study. It discovered that, following this tax measure, the sales tax on wine would put prices up by nine per cent. It would displace 15 million litres of non-premium wine. Fifty per cent of the grapes grown to support this production would disappear. Exports would be constrained by the availability of premium grapes.

Mr Kerin pointed out that a lot of his colleagues did not understand how the grape growing industry worked. Producing wine from grapes is very different from forms of production of other forms of alcohol, in that there is a five- to six-year lead time when grapes are grown for wine. Constant chopping and changing of government policy creates havoc in the industry.

In your government, Minister, you have in the last 10 to 12 years put the sales tax in this area up from zero to 10, to 20, to 31 per cent. What do you think that does to the production in an area where you have a five- to six-year lead time? How are people going to make sensible investment decisions? You have chopped and changed so much in this area, Minister, that what is going to happen is that people are not going to invest in an area where the future economic outlook is so uncertain.

talk.start.para: —Tell us about demand.
—Not only are you discouraging investment in areas that already grow—
—Order! Senator Tierney, if you directed your remarks to the chair, there would be fewer interjections, I think.

—Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, I point out to Senator Cook that not only will it reduce investment in existing areas but also a whole new range of areas that were going to open up to meet the export market may not do so because of the uncertain investment climate he has created. I refer to areas like Orange, in New South Wales, which is going to become a new wine producing region. I wonder whether investment will go ahead in that area, particularly as the projections now are that, instead of $1 billion in exports in wine by the year 2000, we will probably achieve half that. It will really cut back investment.

para.tab: This excellent economic study has proven that this wine tax is going to have a devastating effect on the industry. The findings were accepted by the Labor Premier who financed the study, Mr Arnold, when he said:

speech.para: The results confirm our concerns that the Federal Government will not gain income from the move, rather it will cause serious disruption and downturn in an industry just beginning to make its impact on our export horizon.
Mr Arnold said also:
The increased tax will severely undermine future investment decisions.
That is the point I made to Senator Cook. Mr Arnold concluded:
We will not stand by and let this have a ruinous effect on our State.
Perhaps the most devastating comment on the government's measures has come from Mr Ian Sutton, chief executive of the Winemakers Federation of Australia. Mr Sutton said:

With the stroke of a pen the Federal Government has effectively achieved what the French, the Germans and the Americans and others have been trying to do for years—erode our international competitiveness.
Mr Sutton said also:

It is particularly frustrating and disappointing that the wine industry has pursued the objectives of quality, purity, international competitiveness, value adding, vertical integration and international best practice as promoted by the Federal Government, only to find, as our export assaults succeeded, the same federal government decided to blow up that fort from inside with the most explosive of devices—a massive tax increase.

talk.start.para: —It doesn't apply to exports.

—With friends like the federal government, minister, the wine industry does not need enemies. What the minister fails consistently to understand—I say this through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to Senator Cook—is that to have a successful export industry one must have a thriving domestic industry that gives one economics of scale and gives the opportunity for the small wineries to become large wineries. Not only will the small wineries not become large wineries, but under the government's policies what is going to happen is that they will go out of business. This whole area will go backwards. All the economic figures that I have quoted today prove that.

para.tab: This bill will devastate the wine industry. The government has betrayed the people that it promised to give jobs to. These measures are going to destroy jobs. The government has promised to look after its true believers but instead what it has done has harmed them by introducing regressive tax measures. The government promised not to introduce new taxes but what it has done is exactly the opposite.

The dishonesty of the government's position is highlighted by the comments this morning of Mr Kerin, the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. He said that the policy to increase the sales tax on wine was based on `ignorance, stupidity and prejudice, and the 55 per cent tax increase is a massive disincentive to invest'. I repeat for Senator Cook's benefit that his colleague Mr Kerin, a former Treasurer, says that the 55 per cent tax increase is a massive disincentive to invest in one of our few expanding export primary industries. The government's budget is one of betrayal, and the opposition has the right to hold the government accountable and oppose these tax measures.

speech.speaker: Cooney Sen B.C.

talk.start.para: —I have taken on board the arguments put this morning by various speakers that these increases in taxes are going to bring this country into real difficulty; that the increase of one per cent on goods is not going to be at all helpful for our industry and will bring a horrifying reaction from people; and in particular, as Senator Chapman put it, that an increase in the sales tax on wine from 20 to 31 per cent will cause real difficulties for this country.

para.tab: It is a familiar argument because it is the same sort of argument that is used in relation to the Mabo case—that unless there is certainty there is going to be real difficulty getting people to invest in Australia. I understand from Senator Carr that this afternoon there is going to be a report brought down dealing with sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act and the way in which people work in this country and the basis upon which employers and employees work together. No doubt it will be said that that is going to bring disaster upon the country.

So we have, as an example, the wine tax and the increase of one per cent in the range of goods that the sales tax is imposed upon. We have this industrial relations problem and, as Senator Tierney has said and as I expect Senator Macdonald is about to say, this is most retrograde.

talk.start.para: —Quite right. Not only is it retrograde, but I am about to say it.

—Senator Macdonald is about to say it. I took all this on board and then I read this morning's newspapers. It seems to me that the media of this country must have it wrong. This problem of the wine tax is very serious; the problem with Mabo is very serious, and there is not going to be investment in this country; the labour market reforms are slack, which is a matter of real concern. Listening to Senator Tierney, I thought, `Things must be disastrous'. So I got these newspapers from outside the Senate chamber—I will put them back—and I read in the
Australian
of today's date that the share market has cracked the 2,000 barrier. I thought, `The
Australian
newspaper has got it wrong. That could not possibly be the situation, given the arguments we have heard here today'. So I went to the
Sydney Morning Herald
, and it says, `Shares soar beyond 2,000'.

speech.para: Under the by-line of Matthew Russell it says:
The Australian sharemarket surged through the 2000 barrier yesterday for the first time in six years.

Not only is the Murdoch press wrong, but it seems that the Fairfax press is wrong, and that is confirmed by the
Age
newspaper in Melbourne. Under the by-line of Malcolm Maiden, business editor, the headline says `Time to take stock'. The article goes on:
Australia's all ordinaries share price index sailed blithely—
it did not just sail, it sailed blithely—
past 2000 points in mid-1987, on its way to a peak of 2312 in September that year.

I thought that must be an aberration and the people of Australia had suddenly decided to invest in local shares rather than invest overseas. But it seems that it is not only the local people who are doing this. In the
Financial Review
the headline is `Foreign rush for Australian shares'. The article states:
As foreign money poured in, the Australian sharemarket powered to its highest level in six years yesterday when the All Ordinaries index broke through the psychological 2000 mark to close at 2018.8.

para.tab: It marks the present share boom as one of the most spectacular in recent history—in 11 months it has lifted the value of Australian stock and shares by $84 billion.
Turnover yesterday totalled $530 million, triggered by a surge of support from overseas institutions, which pushed the $A back above US65c to close at US65.16c.

speech.para: And so it goes on. Now, who is right? Should we appoint a select committee to look at the headlines on the front pages of the dailies? It seems to me that those headlines cannot be consistent with what we have been hearing today. If we ask the wine industry to pay some extra tax, will we find that the foreign people who have rushed in to buy Australian shares today will rush to sell them tomorrow because we, irresponsibly, according to others in the chamber, are going to ask people who grow wine and sell it to pay tax?

para.tab: I do not know that they are alone in paying tax. We all pay tax. We do not like paying tax. No doubt if we had more money that we did not have to pay to the government we would invest it. If we invested, the foreign rush for Australian shares might become a foreign stampede for Australian shares. If tax were simply abolished and nobody had to pay tax, things would be sensational, according to the analysis we have heard here this morning.

The
Herald-Sun
in Melbourne, just to finish off, has the headline `Share dollar boom', and goes on to talk about that. By the way, I notice that on the front page of the
Herald-Sun
there is a reference to a 16-page guide to the spring racing in Melbourne. The spring carnival in Melbourne is one of the highlights of that great city's year.

The racing industry has great export potential to South-East Asia—to Hong Kong, to Japan and to Malaysia. They are all developing their racing industries. I searched this 16-page article in the
Herald-Sun
on the spring racing carnival. I thought that since the industry has that great potential for export, there would have to be some article saying that if taxes were put upon the sale of thoroughbreds, whether at Inglis's sales or the Dalgety sales in Melbourne, that would ruin the industry. I thought I would find an article saying that the great potential we have to expand one of the major industries in Australia will be set back, and therefore it should not pay tax; but I could not find that.

The conclusion I have reached from that is that the racing industry has a sense of responsibility to the rest of Australia. It probably thinks it ought to contribute to the hospitals, the schools and the roads that we have got to pay for in this country to run it well. I would have thought the racing industry would think it proper to accept some responsibility for the money we need to develop the culture we have in this country, to pay for the Olympic games, to keep our rivers clean and to reclaim land.

This great racing industry has so much potential. It has tourist potential in Australia. It attracts millions of dollars to Victoria during the spring carnival, millions of dollars to New South Wales during its season, and millions of dollars into Senator Lees's state of South Australia through institutions like Lindsay Park. That industry seems to have faced up to its responsibility to the rest of Australia. It does not engage lobbyists. It does not go around the countryside urging politicians and other people to stop it being taxed so that its members can make a proper contribution to the country in which they live.

When one looks at what the racing industry does, not only through the taxes it pays but also through the generosity of many of those associated with it in terms of contributions to charity, one can only be amazed at the stark contrast between that industry and the wine industry of this nation. Those associated with the racing industry can point to the contributions the industry makes to hospitals, to charities of all sorts, to private institutions and to private charities such as church groups. I ask those who are going to get up following me and who will be supporting the proposition that the wine industry should not contribute to this country through taxes to point out where that industry has made even half of the contributions on a voluntary basis that the racing industry has.

We have heard statements like that made by Senator Kernot that now is not the time to put a massive increase on the wine tax, because the wine industry is a burgeoning export industry. What follows from that is that somebody else ought to pay the tax that the wine industry would otherwise have to pay. Somebody else would have to contribute to all those institutions that we look upon to make their proper contribution to this country.

Everybody in this chamber is paid out of consolidated revenue. So we take money from consolidated revenue for our wages. But, because we have got a wine industry in our particular state and because we are affected by the lobbying that has gone on in reaction to this measure, we say that the wine industry—which enjoys all the benefits of this nation, including the excellent government we give it and including the scrutiny of various pieces of legislation in this chamber which will otherwise affect it—does not have to make a contribution to that because now is not the time, because it is now going to be on a big export drive, because it should be given special attention and because it should receive discriminatory treatment in its favour.

It seems to me that the great success of the wine industry has been its very effective lobbying processes. I would like to put on the public record my admiration for the way the people in the wine industry have been able to get together a program which may well defeat the imposition on them of a proper tax. I say it is a proper tax because everybody in this nation is expected to make a contribution to the great lifestyle that we have. It must be a great lifestyle because people on the opposite benches keep saying, `We do not want to change it. We do not want to move to a republic because under the monarchy we have got the best system'. That, of course, pays great tribute to the way my party has governed for the last 10 years. People do not want to change the system. They want to stick by it. So we cannot complain about the lifestyle we have got. Yet, when people are asked to contribute to paying for that lifestyle, they object and say, `Oh, well, let somebody else pay'.

I would have thought that what has got the wine industry going is the quality of the wine. It is a good product and people want to buy it. But apparently I am wrong in that. On the analysis coming from the opposition, people have been buying wine because there is only a 20 per cent tax on it. But if the government puts another 11 per cent tax on it, it does not matter how good the wine is, how great the quality of it is, people are not going to buy it. They are not going to buy it for its quality; they are going to buy it because it has only a 20 per cent tax on it instead of a 31 per cent tax. It is an amazing proposition that we are building an export industry, not on the basis of the quality of our wines but on the basis of the level of taxation we are going to put on it. It is a proposition that I find very interesting.

The people who have spoken longest and loudest, and properly so, are those with wine industries in their state. I do not suggest for one minute that, when they get up to speak on behalf of the wine industry in their state, they have in any way got their eyes on the next ballot. I do not say that at all. It would not be worthy of me to think that people would be speaking about the evils that come with a wine tax because they might be looking for votes at the next election. I do not say that, but I do say that, when they make a proper assessment of how this wine tax will affect the industry, they have to realise that it is one of many industries and it is one of a whole series of income producing organisations in the country that ought to make a contribution to what they get out of this place.

talk.start.para: —If time had not been against us I would have liked to refute some of the quite spurious arguments of the previous speaker, Senator Cooney, arguments that dealt with the spring racing carnival and other ridiculous matters that not even my good friend and honest parliamentarian Senator Cooney could possibly have believed in. It is fairly obvious that the Labor Party wants to stop this from going to a vote. It wants to drag this out as long as possible. We on this side have been asked to confine our speeches to the barest minimum so that we can get on with the legislation and have it passed, in order that the uncertainty in the wine industry at this time can be overcome. It seems to be the definite ploy of the Labor Party, however, not to allow that to happen but to exacerbate the current uncertainty.

para.tab: My remarks will be brief. I support wholeheartedly the arguments that my colleagues who have spoken previously have put in this debate. The arguments have been put very well. They have canvassed all aspects and they have put the case so skilfully as to convince even the densest of legislators of the correctness of our argument. I would not say that even the Labor Party is so dense that it cannot understand what it is doing with this legislation. I can only think that the Labor Party has introduced this legislation, which is to tax one of our better industries, out of sheer prejudice—not out of a desire to gain revenue or a desire to do anything in the taxing area but simply out of prejudice.

The arguments have been made but the debate would not be complete without some reference to the wine industry, which has the greatest potential within the Australian industry. The Australian industry is now world renowned for its quality, its value and its consistency. The area which has the greatest potential within the Australian wine industry is the Queensland wine industry. Many of our colleagues have spoken about the wine industry in other states but not a lot of people realise that there is a substantial and increasing wine industry in Queensland. There are 31 registered winemakers and approximately 25 of these winemakers use grapes. The rest of them in Queensland use tropical fruits, for example in the Daintree area of north Queensland, and they also use dates from Surat in western Queensland. Most of the vineyards in Queensland are in the Granite Belt region; other locations include St George, Roma and Charters Towers.

The industry has 18 operating commercial wineries with a total annual crush of 600 tonnes. This is only small when compared with production in the Hunter Valley, which has a crush of around 18,000 tonnes. The Queensland industry accounts for just 0.1 per cent of Australia's total grape production. All traditional grape varieties are grown in Queensland and they all show very great promise. Over 90 per cent of the Queensland wine sales is for the Queensland market. I understand that the balance is for the Australian market and there is very little, if any, export. That is very important in this debate. The industry in Queensland has great potential. Over the last six years the industry has grown by 50 per cent. Queensland wines are increasingly gaining national recognition, winning awards in major wine shows in the southern capitals.

It is always a pleasure, when parliamentary business takes me to Stanthorpe or when I attend Stanthorpe for Liberal Party functions, to be able to get from the source some of the great Queensland wines that are now being produced in the Granite Belt area. The potential for growth is enormous. There is plenty of land available in the Granite Belt, which is in proximity to the Australian region with the fastest growing population—the south-east region of Queensland.

The wine industry council of Queensland believes that prior to this wine tax announcement the Queensland industry had the potential to grow to the same size as the Hunter Valley. The Stanthorpe-Granite Belt region was starting to get real gains from the tourism activity which follows a successful wine industry. That area in the border region of Queensland, in the Granite Belt, is seeing an increase in tourist activity because of the wine industry.

Like my colleagues, I oppose the tax on wine because it is simply brought out of prejudice by this Labor government. I am pleased to see that the Democrats and the Greens—I think—are opposing the tax. I cannot help but say what Senator Cooney was not prepared to say, that it seems to me that the attitude of the Greens and the Democrats is purely for crass political purposes. If they were concerned about the taxes on an industry affecting adversely that industry, they would be the first ones to join with us in opposing the increase in tax on petrol. But no, the Democrats are not interested in that; perhaps there are not the same sorts of votes in that in their constituencies. They seem to think that they have a real constituency in South Australia and it is to pander to that that they seem to be opposing this tax, but not opposing the petrol price increase of 7c a litre which will affect every rural industry and every other industry in Australia. That is not to say I do not welcome the Democrats' opposition to this proposal, but it does show again quite clearly the hypocrisy of this particular political party of the left.

Our attitude to this bill has been consistent with our policy generally on these new taxes for which this government has no mandate whatsoever. Nowhere during the election did we see the Labor Party indicating that it was going to put an increase in tax on wine. Neither did we see it proposing an increase in petrol tax or in fact any other tax at all. All it proposed was that there be reductions in personal income taxes which it told us were fully funded and did not need any new taxes. That is what it told the Australian public about. We have consistently opposed these taxes for which it has no mandate and about which the Labor Party collectively lied before the last election.

I oppose the tax for the reasons that my colleagues have mentioned, but as well because it will set back a Queensland industry which has enormous potential for growth. Investment and expansion in the Queensland industry would vanish if this tax were to be implemented. The concessions held out by Mr Dawkins in a desperate attempt to save his position in this failing government would have mainly helped the large winemakers and disadvantaged the small companies which make up the entire Queensland industry. So Mr Dawkins was trying to buy off the big fellows but completely ignore the little fellows who comprise the total amount of the Queensland industry.

The tax increase means a decrease in demand for wine, an oversupply of grapes, falling grape prices and heavily discounted wine competing for a smaller domestic market. Consequently, winemakers will be absorbing the tax rather than passing it on. The government just does not seem to understand that winemakers are price takers, not price setters. As I mentioned previously, Queensland does not export wine; so this tax will fall directly upon it. I am sure Senator Burns, as a loyal Queenslander, will be joining me in opposing these taxes which will adversely affect the wine industry in Queensland.

I am informed that, if this tax were to go through, there would be many wineries in Queensland that would become bankrupt. It would completely stifle this new and potent industry for Queensland—an industry which, without this tax, will make very great strides. I listened with interest to Senator Cooney's figures and his run-through of this morning's papers. I heard Senator McKiernan talking about some arithmetic and blaming us for not being able to add up.

I conclude simply by again quoting Mr Kerin, the disgraced former Treasurer but well-regarded former primary industries minister. I point out to Senator Cooney that Mr Kerin—not I, not the Liberal Party, not the industry but Mr Kerin himself, one of the honourable senator's colleagues—said that the proposed wine tax increase was based on `ignorance, stupidity and prejudice'. It seems that so much of the legislation in this budget—I mention also the FBT on business travel, which according to former Labor minister Mr John Brown is in the same category—is based on prejudice by the Labor Party against others in Australia.

Mr Kerin, in my view, has hit the nail on the head when he says that the tax is based on ignorance, stupidity and prejudice. Mr Kerin—not I—says that the government's arguments for it are dishonest. Mr Kerin has further said that it would be a massive disincentive to invest in the industry. I point out to Senator Cooney and Senator McKiernan that Mr Kerin says that the 55 per cent tax increase is a massive disincentive to invest in one of our few expanding primary industries.

I hope that the government will see sense in this matter and will join the Liberal and National parties in opposing this. I call on Queensland senators, who obviously have an interest in the wine industry in my home state, to join me in doing something to protect that industry in our state—at the same time enhancing the industry in every other state—by opposing this very iniquitous legislation.

speech.speaker: Lees Sen M.H.

talker.name: Senator LEES
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

talk.start.para: —I will be speaking on behalf of the Democrats on only the sections of these bills that relate to the wine tax. I begin by saying that this is consistent with the Democrats' stand on the two previous wine tax increases, in 1984 and 1986.

para.tab: Perhaps I should begin also by answering some of what Senator Cooney had to say, in particular to stress that the wine industry is already paying a considerable amount of tax. This is an increase on what it is expected to pay now. More importantly, I should put in a couple of points that Senator Cooney glossed over. This industry provides more than just a tax base for the government. It also provides employment, particularly employment in rural areas of Australia, where jobs are not easy to come by, and in particular it provides this country with considerable income, thanks to its success on the export markets.

The Democrats believe that winemakers have provided sufficient evidence to show that this sudden tax increase would have a negative impact on the industry—indeed, quite a disastrous impact, not just on the industry itself but also on entire rural communities. There is no doubt that winemakers feel betrayed.

The winemakers believe the proposed tax increase to 31 per cent would see the retail price of wine jump somewhere between nine and 15 per cent, resulting in a $100 million fall in domestic wholesale sales. They base these figures on what has happened previously when there has been an increase in the tax on wine. The winemakers say that the proposed tax increases would have seen the displacement of 50,000 tonnes of grapes and that $126 million per year in export income would have been lost.

Most importantly, Australia's wine makers believe that the proposed tax increase will slash investment. There will be $35 million in lost investment for plant and equipment, $160 million in lost inventory investment and $250 million in lost investment for new vineyards. I had first-hand evidence of that when I recently visited the Coonawarra area of South Australia, where a number of plantings have been put on hold awaiting the outcome of this tax impost. The $445 million in lost investment is in an industry that proudly boasts that it is on target to achieve its goal of $1 billion worth of export sales by the turn of the century.

The extent of the damage that this tax could have caused is open to debate. It is open to debate primarily because the government has no industry plan for the wine industry. The government has not done its homework. It does not have the figures. Indeed, it seems from the letter from Mr Kerin leaked to the
Australian
and published this morning that this tax came straight out of Treasury and that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy had no input whatsoever into the imposition of this additional tax on the industry. So we cannot put a precise figure on how many grape growers would have been pushed to the wall to the point where they were forced out of the industry or how many small wineries would have closed. What we do know is that some grape growers would certainly have gone, or indeed will go if we have an impost of this type, and that some wineries certainly would not have survived.

The need to develop a full industry policy for the wine industry is now urgent. The budget shows that the only industry policy that the Australian Labor Party seems to be able to come up with is one that revolves around the idea of to tax or not to tax, one with absolutely no parts that consider what this industry is able to contribute to the Australian economy. The winemakers' view is that there certainly will be severe damage, and the Democrats do not question that. Their views are supported in the findings of a detailed examination conducted by the South Australian Centre for Economic Studies.

The centre found that an increase in the wholesale tax on wine from 20 per cent to 31 per cent will result in a retail price increase of at least nine per cent. At page 16 of the document it is stated:

Given the nature of the export market—the low price points on the market and the higher production costs associated with the smaller levels of production—the smaller wineries have to market their wine hard in order to compete at the higher price end in export markets. Significant costs are involved in a marketing exercise of this nature. Notwithstanding, the possibility that many small wineries will successfully export part of their volume, it is anticipated that these wineries will experience a decline in sales as a result of the increase in sales tax to the order of 3.6 per cent in the short run and up to 18 per cent in the long run . . .

speech.para: For many small wineries, such a decline in sales may be unsustainable in the long run.

para.tab: Small wineries are important for the continuing tourist potential of the wine regions. It is the small wineries in the Barossa, Clare and McLaren Vale regions that attract visitors to the regions which sustain other associated businesses (restaurants, bus companies etc). No attempt has been made to quantify the impact on small wineries.

speech.para: The claim that Australia's wine industry will suffer internationally because of the wine tax proposed was also highlighted in a study conducted by the Centre for Brand Management and Marketing Communications Research. In that document it is stated:

The Australian wine industry has the ability to supply to the export markets of the United Kingdom and Northern America with brands with product quality and cost advantages. Unfortunately these "product-based" advantages are eroding day-by-day as the traditional suppliers to these markets improve their own winemaking . . . Now is the time for investment in marketing activities which build market-based assets . . . It is in light of this commercial reality that any change in the tax system which reduces the ability of Australian wine exporters to invest in the building of market-based assets has the potential to substantially downgrade the industry's international competitive advantage . . . Put simply, the Australian wine industry's competitive advantage is neither as secure or as strong as some would wish. One hopes it has the ability to weather the consequences of this tax increase but any drop in the investment in export marketing activities is a waste of a current, temporary opportunity.

Not only do the winemakers feel betrayed, they are clearly distressed about their future and the futures of their families. The Democrats have received hundreds and hundreds of letters from across Australia setting out examples of what the wineries themselves believe is going to happen if this tax goes ahead. I have selected only a handful of quotes from letters received by the Democrats. If the Senate will bear with me, I will just go through a few of those. The first is from Garry Crittenden from Dromana Estate Vineyards in Victoria. He says:

Should the tax go through my calculations suggest the shedding of one to one and half full time positions from my labour force as well as the complete shelving of a major expansion currently being considered.
James Talijancich owns a small winery at Herne Hill in Western Australia, and he says:

Over 85 per cent of wineries in Australia are family operated. A greater majority of these are wineries who have made the tremendous effort to specialise in PREMIUM WINES. . . The main reason not being to pocket more money, but to make the absolute most of this fruit and the region in which they work and at the end of the day to be proud of what they have achieved.
For this to occur takes years, and in most cases generations of persistence, patience and dedication to this craft.
I go on to a letter from Phillip Tonkin from Currency Creek winery in my home state of South Australia. He says:
Our small business has looked closely at the results on us should this proposal come into effect.
Sadly the answers are not at all good.
Our proposal to plant more vines and employ more staff to increase our competitiveness and cost effectiveness will be shelved. . .
This leaves us to consider the option of simply closing the door.
David Wynn, an Eden Valley winemaker, says:
Having changed our export market to one based on quality and value, are we to be cobbled with a huge burden instead of getting the encouragement that other countries offer their wine industries?
I go on to a letter from Kym Tolley, the director of the Penley Estate winery in South Australia's Coonawarra region, who says:

If our politicians really believe it is through self interest that the wine and grape growing industry have rallied together, then it may be time for a closer inspection of our history, planned future and its effect on the people of Australia in terms of employment, capital investment and export sales—all vital to Australia's future.

As I said before, these are just a few examples of the views of thousands of ordinary Australians who are trying to ply an honourable craft against multinational competition and government insensitivity.

para.tab: The winemakers are also critical of the Treasurer's compromise package. They say the phasing-in component of the package would make no difference and would only prolong the agony, as the industry would end up with an even higher tax rate than the 31 per cent. It goes up again. The industry is also very aware that the compromise package is nothing more than a government gimmick aimed at taking the pressure off the government and placing it back onto the Australian winemakers.

A quick calculation suggests that in this new package much of the $70 million that the government was planning to receive from the wine tax in the first year would go back to industry. It is a very interesting acknowledgment that what we are seeing here is a government saying it does not really need this $70 million after all.

Much of the debate over the proposed wine tax increase has ignored the plight of Australian grape growers. Let us look at some of the statistics that have been provided for us as to what the impact will be on the grape growers. I quote here from a document that they have put out which makes the following points:

speech.para: 80% of Australia's wine grapes are grown by independent grapegrowers. . .
90% of these enterprises are family farms.

85% of these farms
are smaller than
50 hectares.
The Sales Tax increase will ultimately see a reduction in demand for 50,000 tonnes of neutral grapes, equivalent to the loss of 300 growers and their families.
This loss of 10% of the industry's producers will be concentrated on the Riverland, Mildura and Griffith.
It takes 3 years to bring a grape vine into bearing and at least 10 years before a profit can be realised.
So much for those who believe that this industry can easily be compared to any other industry. Their final points are:
The Federal Government has changed the ground rules for investment in grape industry 3 times in the past 10 years.
The Federal Government takes $200 million from the industry but returns only a paltry $1.3 million in research grants.

It is clear that the 55 per cent sales tax hike on wine is simply a cynical tax grab. It is also absolutely clear the government has not taken the time to think through the ramifications for Australia's wine and grape industries. Obviously, a measure of the evidence of that can be found in that letter from Mr Kerin. The government must put aside this tax grab and institute a thorough regional development study into this industry. Indeed, the wine industry is a perfect case for such a study. We need to examine what level and type of assistance is needed to help the wine industry flourish, and we must identify the danger points and the possible impediments to the progress of this very valuable industry.

para.tab: The government's offer that the Industry Commission can conduct a study is unacceptable to the Democrats. In its current form the commission, with its entrenched ideological bias towards extreme economic rationalism, is not going to be the way to proceed. It is interesting to compare the very detailed work the government was able to put into the Button car plan and, indeed, the excellent work that has also gone into a policy for the pharmaceutical industry, with the fact that it has done no work at all on the wine industry. There is no effort on the part of the government to put forward a comprehensive package for this industry to ensure its future. Hopefully, the Democrats' decision not to support the proposed tax increases on wine will help the government to get to such a point where it will acknowledge that an industry plan is required. If the government does not, then the Democrats will proceed anyway. As Senator Spindler was able to show with his successful inquiry into tariffs, we can put together an independent parliamentary inquiry. Indeed, it is urgent that we do this if the government itself is not prepared to move on the wine industry.

As the winemakers state, the wine industry is a model for all Australian manufacturing industries in that its competitiveness is based on sustainable, natural and technological advantages. Most importantly, the industry's competitive domestic marketplace is the main springboard for its export success. This model would have been totally undermined by the proposed tax increase. The Democrats will continue to oppose any increase in future budgets unless there has been that full and detailed study; and that examination has then led to a detailed industry policy that shows a tax as an acceptable part of the package; and that taxing the industry in such a way will not have any negative impact or repercussions.

The Winemakers Federation represents one of Australia's few industries clearly able to establish export goals, and feels it has been tripped at the last hurdle by the government's change of rules. The change of rules does not even represent a distribution of burden but is a straightforward, discriminatory, targeted action aimed at the one industry which is constructing an orderly solution to the Australian malaise in the international marketplace. The ultimate disappointment for the Winemakers Federation is that it will not make its full contribution to the Australian economy if it is hamstrung by this government's taxation policies—indeed, hamstrung by taxation policies here, while its international competition enjoys subsidies rather than taxes. Let us hope sanity prevails in this debate and that an industry plan can be quickly and thoroughly developed so that we will be enhancing this export industry, enhancing the employment opportunities it is able to offer and actually supporting a very valuable Australian industry.

talk.start.para: —It is a pleasure for me to speak on the sales tax bills today and to support my colleagues in opposing this wine tax. I would like to reiterate what has been said before: it is another example of the utter contempt this government has shown for business and rural communities. It is just another example of the way in which they operate, without any consultation with the industry. It is another example of decisions that have been made on the run by this government that is getting so desperate to try to find some money from somewhere.

para.tab: I must say that I was rather amused at the wide-ranging contribution to the debate by Senator Cooney, who came in here with a great pile of papers and showed us today's headlines about the share market, as if that were going to save Australia. He did not mention the adjacent headline, `Former Minister brands wine tax hike dishonest'. I went out and got out the share price list, thinking that I would see how the wineries were going. The only four I could find were Penfolds, which had not moved; Petaluma, which had gone down; Peter Lehmann Wines, which had gone down; and Rothbury, which had not moved. Whilst the share market might be steaming ahead with gains of 40c and 50c by some of the major companies and the blue-chips, certainly the buyers have not fallen over themselves to buy shares in wineries. I can understand why when I look at the decision that this government has taken to impose a 55 per cent increase in sales tax on the industry.

This industry is one that has really been a flag carrier in the last few years. Its exports have grown by 1,000 per cent in six years. It has gone from a $20 million industry in 1986 to $300 million in 1993. As Senator Tierney said earlier, it was on track to become a $1 billion wine export industry by the year 2000; but I am afraid that is not now going to happen. It has been an example of our technology and of cooperation between industry and science. It is another example of the wonderful work that the CSIRO and the Wine Research Institute have done. It is interesting to note that large winemakers such as Penfolds, Orlando and Hardys have ploughed almost $40 million a year into the industry. They have certainly been given a nice slap in the face with this 55 per cent increase in wine tax.

It is interesting to note also that, because of the technology that has been developed in Australia, companies overseas—particularly the French and German winemakers—are looking very closely at our industry. It came to my attention that at least two Australian industries have moved into the south of France and are actually growing wine in France. One is Hardy Brothers and the other is Global Vineyards. The interesting part is that, I believe, the French are actually advertising a French chardonnay made in the Australian way. Obviously, the effect of our wine industry on world markets is being felt even by the French.

To reiterate, the government's wine tax will, at one blow, increase retail sales prices by up to 15 per cent, reduce domestic sales by $100 million, raise sales tax from $200 million to $279 million, cut export income by $126 million each year, cut back on investment in the vineyards by $250 million, cut back on investment inventory by $160 million and slash investment on equipment by $35 million. For the government to try to gain a projected $79 million, the wine industry is going to suffer a total investment and income loss of some $445 million. What a ridiculous state of affairs that is. It will also cut the projected number of permanent jobs in the industry by up to 45 per cent.

talk.start.para: —Whose figures are they? Same source, Senator?

—That has been pointed out in a survey by KPMG Peat Marwick. In the few brief minutes I have left, I particularly want to put in a word for the fledgling wine industry in Tasmania because, as Senator Murphy would know, Tasmania being a small state has been relying on its high quality products to become very competitive and to make a name for itself with such things as its fish exports and its high-priced luxury goods such as cheeses. The Tasmanian wine industry has become an integral part of this as it has also become an integral part of our tourism industry. We have 100 winegrowers and 25 of those have full-scale operations. They employ about 100 people and they have 400 people on a part-time basis. So whilst these may not be huge numbers, from our point of view in a state of our size they are quite significant. In fact, this year the Tasmania winegrowers will harvest something like 1,200 tonnes of grapes which will produce more than one million bottles of very high quality Tasmanian wine.

para.tab: This industry did not just happen overnight. In fact, the first experimental vineyard of any consequence was established by the CSIRO in conjunction with the local winegrowers at a property right next to mine some 20-odd years ago. I had the pleasure of watching this wine industry development. Bob Menary from the CSIRO has been mentioned in Tasmania as one of the early pioneers of the industry. Claudio Alcorso is well known to most Tasmanians. I believe he is a very good Democrat or Greens supporter at the moment, but in the early days he was a very good Labor supporter and his son was a strong Labor voter. I can tell honourable senators that they are not very pleased with what has happened with the wine industry because the Alcorsos were, really, the first major wine producers in Tasmania.

They have just invested hundreds of thousands of dollars in improving their vineyard, bringing in a restaurant and making it into a wonderful tourist attraction. We can understand the devastating effect that this increase in wine tax is going to have on them. I spoke to one of the members of the family only on Sunday and, like Senator Lees who was here earlier, he gave me the same sort of sad news that she has been receiving from her constituents. So it really is very serious; it is not something that can be scoffed at.

The increase in the wine tax is going to have a devastating effect, particularly on small wineries in all sorts of areas over Australia. As I said earlier, the wine industry itself is not only producing export wines, it also has a very important role to play in the tourism aspects of each different area. As wine drinkers like Senator Murphy and Senator Loosley would know, a wine reflects the nature of a particular area and for that reason it is popular. People like to take what they see as part of an area when they are visiting and so it is very important for our tourism industry.

Time is short so I will conclude by reiterating that the wine industry is one of the true success stories of our recent agricultural endeavours. It has prospered because winegrowers all over Australia—like those in Tasmania—have concentrated on a quality product. I guess some of that growth of the wine industry can be attributed to our friends from overseas. It was originally commenced, in Tasmania anyway and I guess in some other places, by immigrants who brought their skills to our country. There is no doubt—as Mr Kerin said this morning—the government tax will decimate the industry. The industry itself says so, and independent financial research confirms those views. We will be opposing this tax because we believe, unlike the government, that the wine industry is very well worth preserving.

speech.speaker: Loosley Sen S.

talk.start.para: —I thought it appropriate to begin a brief contribution in the debate this afternoon by quoting from the Treasurer on a sales tax bill. This is from the second reading speech in the House of Representatives:

speech.para: First of all, I remind the House that any taxation changes, unpopular as they inevitably are if they involve increases in taxation for any section of the community, have to be seen in their overall economic context as part of a Budget which seeks to achieve an overall economic objective. At this time, amongst other things, the economic objective is to take pressure off interest rates which is a very important cause to all Australia's families, and the entire country. Therefore, it is important to see these changes in the context of the Budget because they are clearly an integral part of the Budget and cannot be severed from it. It has been our view from the beginning that they are central to the Budget. That has been and will remain the view of the Government on this legislation.

Of course, I am not quoting Treasurer Dawkins when I bring those words before the House; I am quoting Treasurer John Howard in the Fraser government in 1981. It is fascinating to see the total change that has occurred in the coalition ranks on measures such as these.

para.tab: The circumstances that confront us this afternoon are well beyond those that just reflect upon the tax measures that are proposed. Senator Ian Macdonald, in his earlier contribution, actually maintained that the legitimacy of the Labor government was in some question. As coalition speakers are wont to do these days, he continually talked about whether or not the government had a mandate to legislate in the national interest. The answer to that is a resounding yes; of course, the Labor government has a mandate to govern—confirmed for the fifth successive time by the Australian people on 13 March 1993.

It is not only a circumstance whereby we made certain commitments to the Australian people which we are about honouring, including the tax cuts which also form an important and integral part of the current budget. We also made certain commitments not to do things. We maintained, for example, that tax would not rise overall relative to GDP. That commitment has been honoured. We also maintained that we would not do things that were being proposed opposite consistently and vehemently—slashing Medicare to pieces, up-ending the industrial relation system and introducing a goods and services tax, 15 per cent, on everything that opens and shuts. There is no question that, in terms of commitments, we committed ourselves to take certain positive steps. We are doing precisely that. We also committed ourselves not to do certain things that are still embraced by the coalition, and we have honoured that commitment as well.

The questions about our legitimacy ought to be rejected, ought to be dismissed, and I do that right now. Coalition members appear to be reverting to the only tactic that they believe works in opposition. The only manner in which they see a trail back from opposition to government is to endeavour to make the Senate unworkable. So we have seen the guardians of gridlock at work again today, in terms of the tax measures. The guardians of gridlock are going to be associated with the coalition right through the life of this parliament. There is no doubt about that in my mind. I listened to the unelectable Dr Hewson yesterday morning on
AM
. He ran about No. 10 or 11 on the program.

talk.start.para: —That is what you said about Jeff Kennett. You ran that line against Jeff for a while.

—There is no doubt that any opposition leader who continually fights the last election has lost the plot. Senator Kemp ought to be the first to realise and acknowledge that, given the grasp of Australian history which he claims to have and which I believe he does have. He is led by someone who is unelectable—and thank heavens for that.

para.tab:
In terms of his contribution on
AM
, though, again Dr Hewson wanted to fight the last general election. It is like strategists for the Second AIF basing what we were doing in the 1940s on what happened between 1914 and 1918. It simply does not work. Fightback has actually become `fight backwards', looking back on how the election perhaps ought to have been fought.

We cannot have a debate on tax in the chamber without reflecting on Australia's position among Western industrial countries overall. Australia, according to the OECD, now has the lowest rate of tax applying in any Western industrial economy. That is a first-class achievement in terms of the direction in which the government has gone over the last decade. When we came to office, after the Fraser-Howard-Stone period, we had tax rates routinely going above 60 per cent. They are now, in many cases, half that, or getting towards half that. We have seen the corporate tax rate well down, we have seen the individual and personal tax rates well down and we are seeing another raft of tax cuts coming through as a consequence of this budget, when ultimately it is passed, even by the recalcitrant senators opposite.

There is no doubt, in terms of economic governance overall, that there are some first-class measures in the budget document that Mr Dawkins presented to the House of Representatives. I refer in particular to the economic stimulus that is contained within the budget. I am referring to the expansion in labour market programs, particularly for the long-term unemployed. Looking briefly at the tax cuts—
Debate interrupted.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)
—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., we will now proceed to debate matters of public interest.

speech.speaker: Murphy Sen S.M.

talk.start.para: —I would like to take this opportunity to bring to the attention of the Senate a matter that has caused me great concern. I refer to the sad and sorry state of Tasmania's forest industry. Most honourable senators would know that the Tasmanian forest industry has suffered more inquiries than any other state forest industry in Australia.
—Mainly by your government.

—I say to Senator Kemp that it is important to note that his party had a major role to play in delivering security to the country's forest industry and decided to vote against it. So I think it is a very important matter for the opposition also.

para.tab: The Tasmanian forest industry has had a number of inquiries over a long time, the most recent of which was set up arising out of the Helsham inquiry. It was funded by the federal government and a forests and forest industry council was put in place. It was made up of bodies representing the conservation movement, industry, state and federal government, and the trade union movement. It conducted a process of seeking to develop a strategy for Tasmania's forests arising out of other inquiries and also of trying to settle disputes arising out of those matters and the use of the state's forests.

The process dragged on for a long time. I think it started in about 1989 or 1990. I was a member of the Forests and Forest Industry Council, by ministerial appointment. I have to say that, although at the start we had great initiative and, I think, we set down some very clear objectives for the state's forests, many of which were very good objectives, we still failed to deal with some of the very key and important issues.

I would like to refer to the report, which was finally called
Secure Futures for Forests and People
, handed down in September 1990. It contains a summary of agreed recommendations for the forests and forest industry and for forest strategy for Tasmania. Although the conservation movement did not finally support the report, I think the intention and the objectives set out in the report are very good.

Essentially, the report dealt with three or four key areas. They were the people issues, the employment aspects of what we could derive from the commercial use of Tasmania's native forests, conservation and a transition strategy which would try to take it out of the debate about conservation matters and settle it in a very democratic way to ensure that we did maintain in a sustainable way all of the state's forest types and species. The report also related to the public use of forests and, last but not least, the forest industry.

I want to deal with the forest industry more than anything else because it is the industry that I believe has the greatest potential for Tasmania to provide employment on a sustainable basis. Unfortunately, even though we have had some 13 reports and even though we have a current strategy, we do not seem to be able to get it right in terms of the recovery and utilisation of the wood that is harvested from the state's forests. That is very sad.

We have gone from being an industry that was quite a large employer to an industry where we have lost a lot of jobs in a lot of the larger manufacturing mills such as paper and pulp, mainly due to technology. I am concerned with the sawmilling industry. The state government at the moment has the opportunity to deal with the industry and actually bring about some changes, particularly in light of the recent sale to Amcor of the paper making processes that belong to North Broken Hill.

I will go back to make the point about how the major companies operated in this state. Some years ago they were granted concessional rights on the basis that they would undertake downstream processing. Those rights were granted in very substantial areas of forest over long periods of time. They were legislated rights, but they were mostly associated with a program that required the company or companies that had those rights to enter into downstream processing, primarily associated with pulp and paper manufacture.

Sadly, we have seen the demise of those industries to the extent that North Broken Hill has sold the APPM paper mills it owned at Burnie and Wesley Vale. The company still retains the concessional rights, and it is my view that it should not. I believe the state government ought to terminate the rights.

I say that because in 1991 there was legislation passed in the House of Assembly in Tasmania—and supported by the then Liberal opposition—that concessional rights would be replaced with wood supply agreements, and that those wood supply agreements would be based on volume rather than area. It is my view that the current Liberal government ought to terminate immediately the concessional rights that still exist in Tasmania's forests today. It is the only way that we will see the industry changed in a way that will ensure greater participation from other developers and other proposers in what I hope will be better downstream and value adding processes for the wood that we take out on a commercial basis from both the public and private forests in the state.

In the circumstances that exist now, we have North Broken Hill proposing a further woodchip mill. North Broken Hill initially proposed it on the basis of primarily using wood from the company's private property. It was going to be built for the primary reason of securing the future of the two paper mills at Burnie and Wesley Vale, but they are paper mills that they no longer own. As a result of that, I have some doubt as to the legitimacy of the company's claim for the building of another woodchip mill.

Nevertheless, I think that if we are able to convince investors to build a pulp mill in Tasmania in the longer term, it will be a very worthwhile investment. In terms of the overall wood production, my concern is that because one company owns a substantial amount of private forest it has the capacity to affect significantly the harvesting of the public wood resource, and that will impact very substantially on the state's sawmilling industry.

One of the other very important areas is the utilisation of the wood. When we actually cut trees down we should try to maximise the value adding. Some people would say that if one looked at value adding on a dollar basis one would make it all into paper. It is probably true that on a dollar per tonne basis paper is the most valuable manufactured product that one can get out of trees; but it does not employ many people, and it is going to employ fewer because of the technology that is available in the industry.

I think this is a very important matter for the state government, and I hope that the federal government will be able to assist in some way. We have to encourage the Tasmanian government to allow different uses, and to be pro-active in the area of initiating programs that will ensure that the wood is utilised in such a way that it will create more employment and, simply by better utilising the trees that are cut down, reduce the necessity for the current level of harvesting native forests.

That is not to say—and I want to make it quite clear what I am saying—that we should have less native forest to harvest. I do not believe that should be the case. I think harvesting of forests can be done, and it can be a very valuable thing to do if it is done in a sustainable and ecologically sensible way.

The Tasmanian state government has not signed the federal government's national forest policy statement; it is the only state that has not signed. The statement goes to some very important areas. One that I would like to refer to is the efficient use and value adding of the wood that is harvested from the country's forest. The statement says that we have to take it into account that:

speech.para: The benefit to the community from using forests for wood production can be increased through the efficient use of wood by industry.

That is one of the fundamental problems we have at the moment. There is so much wood that is wasted by way of woodchips, et cetera, just being shipped out of the state and certainly from the country in the rawest possible form. This simply should not be allowed to continue. The statement says:

Efficient wood production and use can also provide greenhouse benefits by reducing greenhouse gas emissions through minimising soil disturbance during harvesting, reducing milling waste and producing long-lasting products. The governments agree—
that is, all of the state governments which have signed this policy statement—
that it is essential to foster a dynamic and efficient forest products industry that offers employment opportunities and economic benefits for the nation.
I would have to say that in Tasmania right at the moment we are sadly lacking in that area. The statement goes on:
. . . the governments will keep regulations to a minimum. In order to attract new investment and profitable value-adding projects . . .

Again I would have to say that the state Liberal government has failed dismally to do that, even though it currently has proposals before it that would increase the recovery and utilisation of wood harvested from Tasmania's forest and would also increase employment in the industry. The state government has not done anything about it. In fact, one proposer who has sought my assistance has had nothing but difficulty—brick walls, almost, are put up to the projects that he has proposed. Given the state of unemployment in Tasmania, it is a sad reflection on any government that it would take that sort of position.

para.tab: As to the overall process in terms of where the industry goes, the industry has a great future. It is a very important industry and, given the employment opportunities in Tasmania, probably one of the best in terms of being able to provide long-term employment, providing it is managed right.

There have been 13 reports on this long-term issue. We have had many debates. Many debates about Tasmania's forests have taken place in this chamber and in the House of Representatives. Those debates may not always have been about employment. The forests that we have in the state—it is one of the most heavily forested states of Australia—have contributed great value and certainly can contribute great value to the nation's economy.

talk.start.para: —Look at Wesley Vale!

—Senator Kemp mentions Wesley Vale. Wesley Vale is a pulp and paper mill proposal and its not getting off the ground was primarily the fault of the company and the then state Liberal government, because of the way that they actually dealt with the issue.
—Richo, when you were in government.
—It has got nothing to do with why the proposal failed. It failed simply because of the way the company dealt with the issue and the way the state government dealt with it.
—Richo stomped on it.
—That may be Senator Kemp's view but it is certainly not the factual position.

para.tab: I hope that, by raising some of these issues in this chamber, I may be able to get the state government to actually do something about what is a very important issue in terms of getting better utilisation. I do not think any honourable senator or in fact any member of this parliament ought to oppose improving recovery and utilisation of the country's forests. It is probably one area that does have a very substantial opportunity to offer employment.

In view of the amount of forest products imported into this country annually, everybody should be seeking to improve the recovery and utilisation process. It is for that very reason that I sought to raise this matter today. From here on in it is going to be a very important issue and I hope that the government will pursue it.

speech.speaker: Tierney Sen J.W.

talk.start.para: —I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate the very real problem currently being faced by the libraries in our higher education sector. The problem of funding is at crisis level and this Labor government has only recently acknowledged the problem. It acknowledged it and has done absolutely nothing about it.

para.tab: As the Senate representative on the council of the National Library of Australia, I was present recently when the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Beazley, officially launched the current contents database service developed by the Council of Australian University Librarians. In his speech, Mr Beazley noted that the architects of the current contents database are addressing a very real problem faced by libraries in the higher education sector. Mr Beazley acknowledged that, with the cost of journals rising annually at a rate substantially above inflation, pressure is being placed on libraries to cut serial subscriptions, especially as more and more library expenditure is taken up by serials at the expense of books.

It is outrageous that this government can acknowledge the problem and then fail to come up with any sort of workable solution. It has decided to increase funding, but what a pathetic amount! At the National Library, the minister tried to boast about the measly $5 million extra he planned to spend. I must point out to the Senate that this $5 million will be spent across 36 universities. Also, he is not talking about an annual figure; he is talking about a triennial figure. Bringing that back to how much extra he is planning to spend on capital infrastructure for libraries in the next three years across Australia, it amounts to a figure of $50,000 per university per year. That will go a long way! It is really throwing cents at a problem that needs big dollars to fix it.

Mr Beazley should know that the $5 million that the government has allocated for the next triennium is on top of the miserable $1.5 million over the past three years. This is creating, over the six-year period—the last three and the next three—a massive run-down in our university library system. What this minimal commitment shows is that the federal government simply does not understand the extent of the crisis it has created.

The effects of this crisis have been illustrated recently to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training inquiry into the organisation and funding of research in higher education. The hearings of our committee have been conducted all over Australia, and at each university we are constantly hearing about the deteriorating state of university libraries. At the hearing in Perth, Mr Ellis, the librarian at the University of Western Australia, said:
. . . in recent years we have noticed a very significant decline in the purchasing power of Australian libraries, particularly academic libraries, and this has had a series of consequences.

speech.para: The dire nature of some of these consequences was probably best illustrated at the University of Adelaide. There they have an excellent library, the Barr Smith Library, which really becomes a regional library, in a sense, for the rest of South Australia. The pressure on the Barr Smith Library was so great that it could not keep up with just restacking the shelves from use. Because the librarian did not have sufficient money, he was forced into a position where he had to bar access to that university's library by people outside the university, and that bar continued for three months.

para.tab: It is Third World stuff if libraries are forced into a position where they are so lacking in resources—not just for books and journals, but for proper staffing—that they have to cut back to that extent. What is the minister's answer? His answer is $5 million over three years for 36 universities—$50,000 per university per year—to solve what is an absolutely massive problem.

It is now reaching the stage in some universities where the journals, which are absolutely essential for research, are being cut back—not just fringe, marginal journals but essential journals. Journals can be very expensive and the costs are going up, but the government is not recognising this in its funding arrangement. What is happening in a number of universities is that they are saying to the various departments, `We want you to cut a number of journals out of the annual stock you subscribe to. Your choice, you can pick the journals, but you have got to cut them out'. As I said before, this is really Third World stuff.

Additionally, just as the libraries of our higher education sector are not able to keep up with updating their journals, nor are they able to keep up with the technological advances that are occurring so rapidly in the information industry. A major capital injection is needed for library infrastructure to enable them to access electronic databases in Australia and especially those now being created overseas. This is the life blood of academic research, yet because of the lack of funding by this government our academics are being denied it. Our academics and researchers cannot remain at the forefront if they do not have regular access to this information.

talk.start.para: —Where is the clever country?
