—I thank Senator Kemp, because that was my final point. He must have been reading my speech. If we are to create the clever country, the libraries in our education sector need urgent attention, not just the lip service they are currently getting under this Labor government.

debate.sub1.title: Alleged Physical and Sexual Abuse in Catholic Institutions

speech.speaker: McKiernan Sen J.P.

talk.start.para:
—It is with some regret that I rise today to speak on the topic of the allegations of physical and sexual abuse over a period in a number of Catholic institutions in my home state of Western Australia. I am motivated to rise by an article that appeared in today's
West Australian
newspaper headed `panel sparks anger'. The article went on:

speech.para: Outrage greeted the announcement yesterday of a special panel to help former Christian Brothers students.

para.tab: The advisory panel was announced by the Christian Brothers of WA as the first step in a program to help former residents of Clontarf, Castledare, Tardun and Bindoon.

Brother Tony Shanahan said the move was part of a commitment given by the Christian Brothers when they publicly apologised to former students after inquiries revealed instances of physical and sexual abuse in their institutions.
The panel, to be chaired by a senior public sector executive, would employ a clinical psychologist as full-time adviser.

speech.para: I am greatly concerned about this because I do not think enough has been done to redress the wrongs that have occurred to many human beings who, unfortunately, were sent to live in these institutions.

para.tab: I first became involved in this issue some years ago when I assisted a constituent, who happened to have been born in the same part of the world, who had just discovered—he was in his late fifties—that he had some relatives living back home. He had no travel documents and he came to me for assistance to get travel documents so that he could go back and visit his sister, who was very ill. Luckily, we were able to arrange for the travel documents to be provided quickly. He was able to jump on a plane and to meet up with his sister just before she died. Of course, he was able to attend the funeral.

Incidents like that do affect individuals, and I have followed the matter through. I have tried not to sensationalise this issue, although I have made public comment back in my home state on a few occasions. I have met with a number of people who approached me for assistance in the matter. These people allege that in their childhood, while they were in these institutions, they were abused not only physically but also sexually. It was disturbing to sit and talk with people who were trying to block out memories from their childhood. It was very difficult, and I felt inadequate to the task of talking with these people about something they did not want to talk about yet did want to talk about. I have thought long and deep about what our society can do to help redress the alleged injustices that it has been put to me have occurred.

talk.start.para: —What page are you on?

—I am not sure. I do not have the reference number; it is not a long article. In order not to sensationalise the matter, and these things can from time to time be sensationalised, I thought the best way of tackling the matter was to request our Western Australian government to arrange for a judicial inquiry into the matter. I felt that that was the only way the truth of this matter could finally come out. I asked for it to be a judicial inquiry because of the sensitivity of the matter not only to the brothers, to the church, but also to the victims. It is the victims I am particularly concerned with—people who want to talk but cannot talk and at the same time do not want to talk. Such an inquiry would have to be handled very sensitively.

para.tab: I wrote to the State Attorney-General, Mrs Cheryl Edwardes, on 28 July asking that such an inquiry be established. I got a prompt acknowledgment of that letter very shortly afterwards. I again wrote to the Attorney, Mrs Edwardes, on 1 September of this year, again calling for the establishment of the inquiry. I got a further reply from the Attorney on 14 September, which concluded:

speech.para: You may be assured that I am cognisant of the concerns of both groups and I am confident that conciliation will result from an atmosphere of mutual cooperation.

Obviously the Attorney has not committed herself to a judicial inquiry. I also had come into my possession a letter from a Christian Brother which said a number of things that particularly disturbed me and which, together with this article I mentioned in opening, prompted me to rise today. I shall quote parts of the letter. I will not use the name of the brother, but if any honourable senators want to look at it they are more than welcome to do so. By way of introduction, he says:

Senator McKiernan . . . are entitled to your view on the matter of the public inquiry over the child migration/Christian Brothers orphanages controversy, but there is another view, and the other view is not merely . . . a sort of cretinous self-interest. The Brothers officially, and myself too, feel that a public inquiry is unreasonable in the circumstances.
He went on to outline the reasons why it seemed to be unreasonable:

para.tab: On the Brothers side many of the main accused, the Principals of Institutions, and the Brothers' executive tend to be dead and their capacity to contribute to the inquiry is limited.

speech.para: That is pretty obvious.

para.tab: Surviving brothers from the 40s and 50s are old and cannot present themselves properly or at all at an inquiry.
Therefore the Brothers cannot present properly at such an inquiry.
The VOICES organisation—

speech.para: I will explain who they are shortly—
wants an inquiry but many past students of the Homes do not want their childhood and adolescence paraded before their wives, work mates, friends.
I empathise with that but, nonetheless, we do have to press on. What really concerned me was the next dot point:

para.tab: There WAS a grotty underworld in the Homes and some of the lads were into unpleasant activities with one another. All this muck would have to come out in an inquiry.

speech.para: He concludes:

para.tab: We do have good reasons for not agreeing with Senator McKiernan and I understand that the government agrees with us—or so I am told.

speech.para: I hope that the government does not agree with the writer of that particular letter, because the Brothers organisations themselves have conducted their own inquiry into this matter. They have been motivated, from the results of that inquiry, to publish an apology and a form of explanation in the media. They have publicly admitted that some form of sexual abuse and physical abuse has occurred in institutions which they were in charge of. That report, the result of their investigations, remains secret to the Brothers organisations. Whilst they would argue that they have a right for it to remain secret, it is a matter for the community. And it is a matter, I believe, not only for the current Western Australian state government, but also for this government.

para.tab: The VOICES organisation which was mentioned in the Brothers letter is an acronym for the Victims of Institutionalised Cruelty, Exploitation and Supporters. Mr Bruce Blyth, who is quoted in the article I opened up with, describes the panel as `a sick joke`. I am not going to go that far. But if the panel is going to be the only investigative action into this area, I would be really concerned.

I am going to await a further reply from Mrs Edwardes to see whether she can be convinced to organise a judicial inquiry. I think a judicial inquiry can be very useful, not only to the victims but also to the Brothers and the Brothers organisations themselves. Unfortunately, when accusations like this are made in our community, all people get tarred with the same brush; and nowhere are the VOICES organisation, the victims or I saying that all Brothers are abusers. We have never said that. Neither has Mr Blyth and neither have any of the spokespersons and, to the best of my knowledge, neither have any of the victims made that accusation. Nonetheless, it does happen that it is spread around. So it can help to clear up the name of the Brothers organisation and, to a certain extent, the church as well.

I will await Mrs Edwardes's response to the calls from myself, from the VOICES organisation, and from other members in the community as to whether or not a judicial inquiry can be established. However, I would give notice now that, if the requests for a judicial inquiry in Western Australia are not acceded to, I will in a month or so take whatever action and use whatever procedures and processes are available to me as a member of this Senate—be it through the chamber itself or the parliamentary committee system—to expand, open up and delve into this. I do not think a parliamentary inquiry would be the right way to investigate the various allegations that have been made on this issue—I really do not think that is the right way to go—but, if it is the last course open to us, that might be a road that we will have to go down.

talk.start.para: —I rise to very briefly comment on the points that Senator McKiernan has brought up today. I am very happy that he has brought this subject up at this stage, because I have been involved with this situation since 1987. Senator McKiernan might remember that there was quite a toing-and-froing between former Senator Jenkins, who used to sit in this place, and me on this matter, going back quite some time. Unfortunately, she overdramatised the situation and threw accusations at members of this parliament as being part of the use of child and migrant slave labour—if I could so describe her words at the time. With the overdramatisation then, it got out of hand.

para.tab: As I said, I am glad that Senator McKiernan has raised this matter today. Over the years I have spoken about this situation to Brother Faulkner, who is in charge of the Christian Brothers in Western Australia. The people involved in VOICES have been in constant contact with me, because I came to the conclusion quite a few years ago that an inquiry was needed.

I am a product of the Christian Brothers education system, and I must say this in their defence: if it were not for the Christian Brothers movement, a lot of people in a lot of places today would not have had the opportunity to gain a secondary education. The Brothers provided boarding schools that were cheaper than the normal private schools around the place. They were probably a third of the price of the normal boarding high schools that were available. It was through these cheaper schools that people were provided with an education, and it was a good education.

For that reason, with the other reasons that Senator McKiernan has mentioned, I want to see an inquiry. From what I have seen, there could have been a few rotten apples in the barrel. The brothers who are still alive will now be quite old. But it does not matter how old they are; I do not accept the excuse that an inquiry should not be held because they are too old. I do not want the whole Christian Brothers movement brought down or discredited because of those few rotten apples. The brothers did provide for the education of a lot of people. There are a lot of good Christian brothers who are still alive, and I still have contact with them.

I welcome an inquiry. I have made inquiries, too. Christian brothers, just like sisters, do not stay in the orders for ever. I took the opportunity of speaking to a former Christian brother whose opinions I trust. I knew he was a former Christian brother, but he did not know that I knew. I rang him up one day and broached the subject. I asked him to tell me what went on, and whether there was any need for an inquiry or whatever. I wanted to know. I will defend the innocent, but I will not defend anyone who is guilty of some of these alleged crimes. Having that in mind, and having spoken to Brother Faulkner, I am of the opinion that we need an inquiry.

Only last week I wrote to Brother Faulkner telling him my view that it is time that we held an inquiry. Four or five years ago he was rather reticent about having an inquiry. I also wrote to the Catholic Archbishop of Perth, encouraging him to have an inquiry. I thought that as head of the church in Western Australia he should be involved, but to date he has been backward in being involved. The inquiry will show whether there was right or wrong, and I believe the head of the Roman Catholic Church in Western Australia should be involved.

Senator McKiernan will probably be interested to know that I have written to Cheryl Edwardes, acknowledging what she has said—what Senator McKiernan read out to the chamber. I suggested to her, and in fact I implored her, to have a judicial inquiry. Like Senator McKiernan, I do not think a parliamentary inquiry is really the way to go, but if we were to be denied a judicial inquiry then I would support it. I think we have got a bipartisan approach on this. I will certainly keep encouraging Cheryl Edwardes, the Attorney-General in Western Australia, to have an inquiry, and I hope that over the ensuing weeks or months we will get some result.

speech.speaker: Herron Sen J.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak about a matter concerning Senator Richardson answering a dorothy dixer in question time. I will quote his reply to the question, which was in relation to the medical benefits schedule:

speech.para: The AMA has been claiming that the latest increases can be defended on the basis that the MBS fee has not kept pace with doctors' costs. Between 1984 and 1992 the average medical benefits schedule fee went up 62 per cent. At the same time the CPI went up 59.8 per cent and full time average weekly earnings went up 54.5 per cent.

I probably should entitle my few words `Lies, damned lies and medical economic statistics' because that was the gist of what Senator Richardson was talking about. I have done an analysis since the reply and I am appalled that a minister of the crown should manipulate statistics to suit his own purposes in an attack that has gone on for two days now. On the one hand, he has spent the time since he was appointed Minister for Health going around the country telling everybody what they wanted to hear because that is how he functions, I know from past activity; on the other hand, he has been giving them a slap over the face when it suits his political purposes. Ultimately, as I mentioned previously, they will wake up to it and understand how he does function.

para.tab: I would like to revert to the statistics. The first point to make is that there have been dramatic changes in medical services between 1984 and 1992. The actual explosion in technology has been phenomenal, far exceeding any of the other explosions in technology that have occurred, say, in telecommunications, the developments in fax machines, mobile telephones, et cetera. In that time we have seen, for example, the use of laparoscopic cholecystectomy—removal of the gall bladder—through the use of video cameras and instruments, allowing the patient to be discharged from hospital within 48 hours but often 24 hours, as opposed to the situation in 1984 where a patient was in hospital for about a week and then unable to return to work for at least four weeks, sometimes six weeks. That time is now a week.

So the first point I want to make is that there have been dramatic changes in relation to medical services. To come back to Senator Richardson's answer, to equate an average medical service in 1984 to an average medical service in 1992 is comparing apples with pears or something of that nature. There is no such thing. It is like comparing a motor vehicle that you bought in 1984 with the improvements that have occurred in the average motor vehicle that you can buy now.

The next point in relation to those statistics is that some of those procedures, of course, take a lot longer in time to perform—to use that same operation again, the removal of a gall bladder using video cameras to do those procedures. As Senator Kemp would know, it is like using chopsticks as a lot of us do sometimes in eating Chinese food; surgeons have to learn those procedures using chopsticks through small holes in the abdominal wall to remove internal organs.

talk.start.para: —You are not suggesting that the equivalent skill of a surgeon is the same as a beginner using chopsticks?

—Not at all. It is very successful, as Senator Schacht would know from his knowledge of these procedures. The other comparison that puts the lie to the figures that were produced is, as I mentioned, not only the sort of technology but the introduction of technology. One of the most dramatic increases has been in the insertion of ocular lenses, and there have been coronary bypass procedures, diagnostic imaging, organ replacement—all those things. So to draw a comparison, as I mentioned, between 1984 and 1992 in relation to medical procedures is also fallacious.

para.tab: The next point I want to make is in relation to the bulk-billing of services. Again he claims that something like 80 per cent of procedures are bulk-billed. But what he does not tell us is that most pathology and most radiology is bulk-billed. Of the specialty procedures, less than 10 per cent are actually bulk-billed. The bulk-billing is heavily weighted by 24-hour clinics, the very group that he is looking at in relation to overservicing and the other matters in relation to that. He has ignored practice costs. On the one hand, he is saying that is immaterial and, on the other hand, he is introducing tax bills that will considerably send up the cost of petrol, when a major feature of medical practices is driving between hospitals and seeing patients in their homes. That is not acknowledged on his part.

Using the CPI as a reference guide, I can produce a table for him which quite clearly demonstrates that the CPI has accelerated far in advance of medical benefits schedule fees, which is the true measure, rather than actual medical costs. It has exceeded them by over 20 per cent in that time. He did not acknowledge that the Auditor-General in his report in 1991 clearly stated that the medical benefits schedule fee is regarded, for audit purposes, as the fee that the government is prepared to subsidise a patient for his medical costs. It has no relation whatsoever to the costs of practice or the fees charged by doctors. That is conveniently forgotten. The Auditor-General said:

speech.para: There is no longer a single well established and commonly understood basis for the schedule fee. Reductions in schedule fees have generally resulted in reduced observance of schedule fees by medical practitioners and increased costs to patients.

The very man who, when he was minister, introduced the concept of co-payment in relation to pharmaceutical benefits and claimed that it was an important feature in restricting the cost of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme—and it has successfully done so—is now claiming that that is not acceptable in relation to medical services.

para.tab: Finally, he instanced the top 25 per cent—`quartile' was the word he used—of medical specialists who earned incomes. His figures were, for the ophthalmologists, obstetricians and ENT surgeons, between $400,000 and $500,000. Senator Patterson interjected with the previous point about ignoring practice costs. I have done an interesting exercise—I have not completed it, so I cannot give the figures—on the top quartile of politicians. It is very interesting. The minister has 13 personal staff, even more than Senator Schacht has.

talk.start.para: —They are all very good, too.

—I am sure they are superb. They would not be there otherwise. Adding the salaries of the 13 personal staff to the minister's own salary, his travelling costs, his electorate allowance and his superannuation, his income—I do not mean his personal income but the analogy to any medical practice is the same—is over $1 million a year, to run him. By interjection I said, `What does it cost to run you?'. He did not reply. He probably does not know.
—But those are set by parliament.

—I am not saying that it is unnecessary. I am saying that he is the very person who is saying that the top of the tree, the top 25 per cent of specialist medical practice, is not entitled to gross this income. If one takes in all his practice costs, as they might be called—the running of his electorate offices, the running of the ministerial wing, the 13 personal staff—his income is double that. I know whom I would rather trust in those circumstances. It is no good his coming in here, throwing mud at the top of a profession and then smugly sitting down and saying, `Aren't they rats? Aren't they terrible? They are costing the Australian public this'. I know what members of the Australian public would think about whether they would have the bunch of politicians down here or the top percentile of eye specialists, obstetricians and ENT surgeons around the place, if one wanted to put them in a boat and send them offshore. I will expand on this at a future date in relation to bulk-billing. It is obvious when we look at the bulk-billing figures that there are many other factors there.

para.tab: The other interesting factor is that only 40 per cent of Australians pay any Medicare levy at all, and some of them might pay $50 a year. Only 40 per cent! In my state, Queensland, it is 37 per cent that pay any Medicare levy. To say, on the one hand, that this relates to—

talk.start.para: —Do you want kids to pay the Medicare levy?

—Now the truth is out. Senator Schacht wants health care socialised. Every country in the world that has had socialised medicine has gone bankrupt in relation to it. You said, Senator Schacht, that you were a proud socialist. You are still a proud socialist, are you not?
—The inference of what you said is that you want kids to pay. You said that only 37 per cent pay.

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)
—Order! There are too many interjections. Also, all contributions should be directed to the chair.

talk.start.para: —I might upset Senator Schacht's digestive juices; so I will sit down.

para.tab: (1) That discussion of matters of public interest be not further proceeded with this day.
(2) That intervening business be postponed till after consideration of government business order of the day No. 9—Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1993.
(3) That this order have effect till 2 p.m. this day.

Debate resumed from 31 August, on motion by
Senator Robert Ray
:
That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Ferguson Sen A.B.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to speak on this Customs Tariff Amendment Bill—a bill which provides yet further proof of some of the inadequacies of the government, particularly in the area of drafting. The purpose of this bill is to correct a drafting error in paragraph 41A(a) of the Customs Tariff Act 1987, the principal act—
—Remember it is the lawyers who have actually drafted it.

—Which possibly opens up a loophole to allow the duty-free importation of vehicles by people who do not hold a determination under the export facilitation scheme. If we needed any evidence of the inadequacies of the drafting I could quote Mr Holloway, from the minister's department:

speech.para: In this particular case one would have to say that the particular by-law in question—if not the item, certainly the by-law—could have been drafted better than it was.
He repeated later:
It could have been drafted better than it was.

The amendment will remove a potential liability by the Commonwealth to refund duty paid in respect of motor vehicle importations since 1 January 1991, which this government claims could be as high as $500 million.

para.tab: As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, which conducted a hearing into this matter last Monday, I think it has to be asked how a mistake of this magnitude could occur. I suppose it is not surprising when one considers that this amendment bill arises out of an error in previous amendments which were overseen by the former minister for customs, now the Minister for Communications, Mr Beddall. As we have seen, the former minister has moved to bigger and better mistakes over pay TV.

However, with regard to this particular mistake, it has recently been contended that under paragraph 41 of the Customs Tariff Act and the accompanying customs administrative by-law, the duty-free importation of all passenger motor vehicles, including by those companies which are not participants in the car plan—that is, which are not domestic manufacturers—is allowed. It is as a result of this that at least two companies which are not domestic manufacturers have now submitted claims to the Australian Customs Service for a refund of duty paid on all vehicles imported in the last 12 months.

This is obviously contrary to the original intention of the car plan, to support only those importers which manufacture in Australia. Duty is paid on a motor vehicle at the time it is imported. The duty is subsequently claimed back from the Australian Customs Service, if export credits are available. Importers who are eligible for a refund of duty using export facilitation credits obtain a determination from the Australian Customs Service which waives payment of duty on vehicle and components when they land on the dock. This has obvious cash flow and administrative benefits because the businesses do not have to pay duty and then claim back a refund. Importers who do not have these facilitation credits simply pay the duty and obtain the cargo.

With regard to these two companies that I have mentioned, claims for a rebate of duty have been submitted, but without the offsetting export credits having been accrued. If this duty was successfully claimed from customs, it could provide a windfall for the companies concerned because the duty has already been paid, and it has already been built into the sale price of the vehicles. Moreover, as the claim is for a rebate of duty paid over the past 12 months, many of these vehicles would have already been sold. So it is for these reasons that the consumers presumably would not gain any benefit at all from refunding duty to non-exporting companies.

It is important to note that the two companies that I have mentioned did not apply for a duty exemption. I guess that is because they had already paid the levy before they found out there was this possible loophole, and only then did they decide to take advantage of what might be construed as a drafting error in the legislation. I note that other car importers have not tried to take advantage of this error, because they want to see stability in the car plan. But I wonder how long these companies would have held out in the face of their competitors getting an unfair advantage. I cannot imagine it would have been too long. How long would it take them to join the line to claim a refund? For all the reasons that I have outlined so far, the coalition obviously supports the original intent of the export facilitation scheme. Therefore, we will be supporting this amendment bill.

Having said that, I have several serious reservations. The first concerns the right of all Australians to rely on the law as it is written. The two companies involved have relied on the law as it is written, and they have applied for a refund of duty paid, even though they have not earned export credit points. They believed, and they had advice that the law, as it stands, allows them to do this. I also have a concern with the retrospective nature of the bill because we are always loath to support retrospective legislation, and for very good reason. I would like to quote one small passage from the evidence that was given to the committee by Mr Carlsson from Volvo Australia in which he said:

I would also like to point out that we are very concerned about the retrospectivity of the proposed legislation. What industry wants is to have stable conditions and a legal framework within which to work that does not alter and does not change. We have in this country experienced quite a lot of uncertainty and changes to legislation without proper notice being given. We find it difficult to operate under such conditions.

May I just call to your attention that not even at the present time do we know what sales tax is to apply to the sales we are making and have to make. The luxury car tax has been going up and down with very little prior notice. It makes it very difficult for us to plan and it causes losses to our company and then, in the long run, also to the consumers of Australia. We would very much resent it if the legislation were to be passed retroactively.

speech.para: He says `retroactively', but I think he means `retrospectively'. We have a particular concern about the retrospectivity, and have a belief that we should not be agreeing to retrospective legislation. It is our view that taxpayers must be confident in the legislation so that they can plan accordingly for the future. They must be certain that a government cannot levy extra taxes and charges which are retrospective, and hence certain that they will not face a backdated fiscal responsibility.

para.tab: However, there are some places where the coalition may feel that there are compelling reasons to support retrospective legislation. It was with this in mind, and because of the retrospectivity of the nature of this legislation—Volvo in particular having applied for a refund of the duty paid because it believed it was entitled to that under the current legislation—that the matter was raised at the committee hearing. The rules have been changed after Volvo had made application for the refund of duty that was already paid. Had this legislation been changed 12 months ago, or at the time of its making that application, I am quite sure the company would have never made that application.

With this in mind, the committee in its deliberations believed that as there was no provision for a refund of the lodgement fees, the government should make an ex gratia payment to those who lodged applications under the legislation that was in force at the time. This was communicated to the minister, and I compliment him on the speed with which a reply was given to the committee. In a letter to the finance minister he has asked that those application fees that were paid under the original legislation, which will now be superseded by this retrospective legislation, should be refunded to those companies—including Volvo.

I note that in the letter he has requested that from the finance minister. I am hoping that perhaps the minister, if he speaks later, will be able to tell us whether or not those fees will be refunded. I am quite sure that he would have had an answer by now, but I think it would not be right for us to proceed under the belief that these fees will be refunded and then find at some later stage that they are not to be refunded. As I understand it, it is only a request from the minister.

talk.start.para: —I cannot direct him.

—I understand that the minister cannot direct him, but I do compliment the minister on the speed with which he was able to determine this matter. It occurred within a couple of hours of our deliberations.

para.tab: In considering the retrospective element of the amendment bill currently before us, the coalition has examined what would happen if we did not allow the amendment to go through. We have considered the likely impact on industry and consumers and the original intentions of the legislation. Accordingly, and after considerable deliberation, the coalition will not be opposing this bill. The amendments proposed are obviously in line with the original car plan, and to oppose the amendments would give car companies which do not manufacture in Australia an unintended advantage. We have, I believe, made a responsible choice, but one we would not have had to make if the legislation had been right in the first place.

In conclusion, Mr Acting Deputy President, I would like to make it perfectly clear that the coalition does not like retrospective legislation. The support for the legislation on this occasion is strictly a one-off. In no way does it set a precedent for future support to any retrospective legislation, especially in matters of taxation. As I said before, we will be supporting this amendment bill.

talk.start.para: —The Australian Democrats will also be supporting this bill, which seeks to correct the drafting error in paragraph 41A(a) of the Customs Tariff Act 1987. The provisions are part of the export facilitation scheme which provide duty bonuses to passenger motor vehicle manufacturing plan producers for successful exports. As such, they are a major part of the car industry plan, and they have been working successfully.

para.tab: The drafting error makes it possible for a manufacturer to claim the credits without actually having exported vehicles. Clearly, that is not the intent of the legislation and it would be ludicrous to allow that to happen. The Australian Democrats are therefore supporting it. We are well and truly aware that this is retrospective legislation. I wish to put on record as well that this is something that is abhorrent to us. Under normal circumstances, we would not agree to retrospective legislation. Indeed, we have weighed this one very carefully. But in this case it is quite clearly an error. The intent of the legislation is clear. We should not allow people in the industry to take advantage of an error. The Democrats will therefore support it.

speech.speaker: Margetts Sen D.

talk.start.para: —I noted with interest some of the comments from Senator Ferguson earlier. It appears to me that when you have a drafting error of this nature—an unintended drafting error—a couple of things should be considered. First of all, I believe that such drafting errors are a consequence of bloc party voting. If all individual senators and members in the parliament felt that it was their right or responsibility to scrutinise or to have their staff scrutinise legislation, there would be much less likelihood of such errors going through to legislation with their unintended consequences.
—Not in this particular case. This is very technical stuff, Senator. You would have to have a bunch of QCs sitting in your office for days to pick up this one.

—They would be more likely to pick up such errors than is currently the case. I notice also a number of pieces of legislation coming up containing spelling mistakes and errors of grammar. I guess they would be picked up and it would save a lot of time in this place.

para.tab: The Greens (WA) are supporting this legislation but I would like to speak very briefly about a matter which came to light as we reached our position on this matter. We, as most honourable senators, received letters from Trade Management Australia. In attempts to lobby us to vote against this bill, Trade Management Australia wrote to me. I would like to table this document.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —The submission from Trade Management Australia, acting for Volvo and Daihatsu, invokes the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade so as to deny this parliament its sovereign right to pass laws concerning the conduct of trade in Australia. I quote from the document:

speech.para: GATT directs that signatories (including Australia) should maintain policies and practices which ensure certainty of duty liability as this is a prerequisite to successful international trade.
Further it is stated:
In accordance with the principles of GATT . . . importers are currently entitled to rely on the Tariff as it stands at the time of importation of goods.

That worries me considerably, especially considering that in this place I have heard statements that GATT is not a regulatory body and it simply allows free trade. But we see here that even the opposition is prepared to admit that sometimes retrospectivity in legislation is necessary to correct unintended consequences when the unintended consequences contravene the spirit of the act.

para.tab: Therefore, I would like to issue a warning to all of those honourable senators in this place to look carefully at the implications of the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to see whether or not some of the applications of GATT mean that we, as a senate, and we, as a parliament, are giving up our sovereign right to make legislation for the governing of our nation.

talker.name: Senator SCHACHT
talker.role: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

talk.start.para: —In the couple of minutes left to get this bill through before question time, which we all want, I acknowledge the cooperation of honourable senators in debating the bill in the limited time available.

para.tab: First of all, I want to emphasise that the government has never conceded that there was an outright error in this clause; it was a matter of interpretation. We believe that if it had gone through the legal process of challenge we would have won, but there was a doubt. When there is a doubt on an industry policy of such size and importance to Australia, the government is not willing to take even that slight risk. So the comments about bad drafting or an outright error we do not concede. However, these things are always open to interpretation, and we were not going to take the risk.

talk.start.para: —It could have been drafted better—that is what I said.

—Mr Holloway in the hearing used those phrases, and we accept that. Even as it is drafted, we do not concede that we would have lost the case in the court. But if it had gone to challenge other companies would have jumped in as well, and we would have had to go through the whole process. For the next 12 months or two years the whole of the program would have been at risk. A program that has taken Australian exports for motor cars and components from under $50 million in 1983 to $1.3 billion last year is a magnificent achievement in policy terms and a magnificent achievement for the car industry in Australia. I point out that a number of motor car manufacturers have supported this retrospective legislation. The Ford Motor Company, General Motors, Mazda, BMW and Nissan have written to the government in support of this retrospective legislation.

para.tab: I thank the opposition and the Democrats for their support for this retrospective legislation. I say to Senator Margetts that I am not quite sure that the GATT issue is relevant to this piece of legislation. As I understand it, the export enhancement program dealt with by this legislation is in accordance with GATT arrangements; it is not contrary to GATT arrangements. Finally, as to Senator Margett's comment that all members of the Senate should be more vigilant in reading clauses, I wish her well. Like all of us, I take that suggestion. However, I point out to her that the Customs Act, with all the amendments that have been made over the years, is one of the massive acts of parliament, going back to 1903. It would defy description for most of us to be able to pick minor debatable legal points on a particular section. That only happens when it is gone through, for instance, by a customs agent who has some particular expertise and believes he can find a variation that most of us would never pick if we spent days studying it.
I again thank all honourable senators for supporting the bill, and I commend the bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

question.speaker: Tierney Sen J.W.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Does the minister stand by his answer to a question on 18 August this year concerning the 55 per cent increase in sales tax on wine? He said that the increase:

question.para: . . . will not, in our judgment, make a major dent, in any significant way, in an industry that is booming, that is doing brilliantly well in terms of export markets, and that we fully expect not only to survive but also to flourish locally.

How does the minister reconcile this with the comment on the wine tax increases by the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, in today's
Australian
? He is reported as saying:

para.tab: The 55 per cent tax increase is a massive disincentive to invest in one of our few expanding primary industries.

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —I do stand by what I said back in August on this subject. Indeed, I agree with what Mr Kerin has said in this respect because the selective quoting of Mr Kerin's private correspondence omits to include a couple of really rather crucial sentences where, at the outset of his letters to a small number of people in the industry, he said:

answer.para: There are no reasons in tax equity why wine should not be taxed at a higher rate.
More specifically, in response to what Senator Tierney has just said, the second sentence states:
I don't believe the dire results projected by the wine industry with a 31 per cent tax will necessarily occur.

Certainly, as I say, the government agrees with Mr Kerin's judgment in this latter respect for a number of reasons. The first is that wine exports will continue to be wholly exempt from WST, given the nature of that taxation; but, secondly, and more specifically, because there are indications that there is still very strong investor support for the industry, particularly given its present buoyant state with exports at record levels and the long term future is very bright.

para.tab: I remind Senator Tierney—he might not be aware of the facts—that since the budget BRL Hardy, for example, has announced a $75 million vineyard development program. Again, South Australia Brewing has announced additional capital expenditure of $100 million to $150 million over the next few years. This is not the response of an industry that feels itself subject to some kind of knockout blow as a result of what was contained in the budget in this respect.

Another thing to bear in mind about what we have said in the budget, because I think these have been insufficiently emphasised in the debate, is that wine will be permanently excluded from the imposition of excise. That is something the wine industry has sought for a very long time—a guarantee of exclusion in that respect—and that is exactly what it got.

Wine does remain lightly taxed and the increase in wholesale sales tax applying to wine has reduced a longstanding anomaly that did place wine at a very significant tax advantage over beer and spirits. That tax anomaly was a legitimate concern, given that wine and beer are substitutable alcoholic beverages. Prior to the changes, beer and spirits were taxed around four times more heavily than wine. That gap has been a little reduced as a result of the changes and certainly it is not an intention, I repeat, to impose an excise on wine, which would close the gap completely.

The remaining point to be made is that the tax we are proposing will also be progressive because the price impact will be lowest on the cheapest wine. The price of a four litre cask of wine is estimated to increase from only around $7 to $7.50 and there will be similar orders of magnitude on bottled wine. Mr President, that is the response. I do not think we have anything to be remotely apologetic about in terms of the way that this issue has been handled and certainly not in terms of the basic core proposition about the impact of these proposals on the industry as a whole.

question.speaker: Tierney Sen J.W.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the minister's sleight of hand answer, but it does not really disguise the fact that Mr Kerin said that a 55 per cent tax increase is a massive disincentive to invest in one of our few expanding industries; and that the winemakers federation, in addition to that, said that there would be $445 million lost in investment.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order.
—A bit sensitive about it, are you?

—No, not at all. On the point of order: the bill containing the wine tax is currently before the chamber and being debated. Therefore, it is, on my reading, against standing orders to raise questions on it during question time. If that practice were to be indulged in, then all current debates could be canvassed during question time in this chamber.
—What are you frightened of?

—No-one is frightened of anything, and we are giving full measure in the debate in the chamber. But it is a misuse of question time to invite the government to connive with the opposition to subvert standing orders.
—Order! The question is in order because, if there were a strict interpretation of these rules, we would not have a question time at all.

—After that red herring, I will return to my supplementary question. Mr Kerin said a 55 per cent tax rise is a massive disincentive to investment in this industry. The winemakers federation said that $445 million is going to be lost to this industry. I refer the minister to what he said on 18 August:

question.para: . . . the nature of the projections I have seen suggest that there will be no difference in consumption patterns and no impact at all on jobs in this industry.
How can the minister say there will be no impact on jobs based on what the winemakers federation has said and what the former minister has said?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —I guess it is the case that politicians are not immune from hyperbole and maybe there is the odd occasion on which something is overstated. But I go back to the basic point where I started, that the opening sentences of Mr Kerin's letter, when fully quoted, contain the following passage:

answer.para: I don't believe the dire results projected by the wine industry for the 31 per cent tax will necessarily occur.

That is the opening line and that is the bottom line of what Mr Kerin had to say. The evidence, as I have just said, in the context of, for example, the BRL Hardy's investment and the SA Brewing investment, gives the very answer needed to confirm that particular assertion.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I ask: is the minister aware of the legal advice provided by Ian Viner QC and Mr Rene Le Miere on the Western Australian government's workplace agreements bill? Does the minister agree that the legislation would leave individual workers unprotected in negotiating their wages and conditions in Western Australia?
—Mr President, I raise a point of order.
—Who is afraid now?
—No. On the point of order: it is not within the minister's province; it is not part of his administration. It is a matter purely relating to Western Australian government administration.

—The point of order is that the debate that has been taking place and the questions which have been asked of me and Mr Brereton in public and, to some extent, in the parliament have referred to alternative proposals to that which we are putting forward and, in particular, the Western Australian legislation.
—You gave him the wrong question; that is the trouble.
—I did not give it to him. It is directly relevant to matters directly the responsibility of the Minister for Industrial Relations, and one of the key elements is its implication for the federal law.
—Order! The federal government has a responsibility for industrial relations and I will allow the question, but I must admit that it probably could have been better worded.

answer.speaker: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Mr President. I am, as you might have detected, aware of the legal advice provided by Ian Viner QC. It was interesting for me to see the origin of the advice and, having seen the nature of it, I had to go back and make sure it was the same Ian Viner I had heard of elsewhere and met previously. But it is, in fact, the Mr Viner who used to be a Liberal Party federal Minister for Industrial Relations and, more recently, was the President of the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party; it is, in fact, that same person.

para.tab: In an opinion dated 21 October which Mr Viner provided on protection for employees under the workplace agreements bill, he concludes as follows:

answer.para:
1.
The legislation does not protect prospective employees, who wish to be employed pursuant to an award, rather than a workplace agreement, in circumstances where the prospective employer requires that they enter into a workplace agreement as a precondition to employment.

2.
The legislation does not protect employees, who have entered into workplace agreements in circumstances where the employer threatens to dismiss them from their employment by notice, in accordance with their contract of employment, for the purpose of compelling them to accept less favourable terms and conditions of employment in a new workplace agreement.

3.
The legislation does not protect employees, in circumstances where their employer threatens to dismiss them from their employment by notice, in accordance with their contract of employment, for the purpose of compelling them to accept the terms and conditions of employment in a workplace agreement proposed by the employer, except in the situation where an employer has not previously entered into a workplace agreement. Whether the employee is actually protected will depend upon the particular circumstances.

4.
The legislation does not protect employees, if their employer dismisses all its workforce by notice, advertises their jobs and then employs only those persons, including the former employees, who are willing to enter into a workplace agreement on the terms and conditions specified by the employer.

Quite clearly, we have a package of legislation which was rammed through the Western Australian Legislative Assembly. Although the minister, Mr Kierath, claimed that his legislation was similar to this government's proposal, it is significantly different in a number of ways, but most importantly because it does not have a no disadvantage test. That is the crucial difference.

para.tab: The only constraint on flexibility which our proposal provides is a no disadvantage test. That means that employers can have all the flexibility in the world, except to cut the conditions of workers. People who do not like it are complaining only because they cannot pursue their preferred policy, which is to cut the wages and conditions of working men and women. We do not accept that, we will not accept that and that will not be the basis of any package which we introduce. That is what is fundamentally flawed about the proposal in Western Australia. It is why Mr Viner's advice is such good advice. It leaves individual workers unprotected in negotiating their wages and conditions and it stands in very stark contrast to the more reasonable, humane and consistent with Australian tradition policy of industrial relations which we are putting forward.

question.speaker: Minchin Sen N.H.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I note the minister's reference to the opening paragraph of the letter from the former Labor Treasurer, John Kerin, to wine makers, but I refer him to the closing paragraphs of that letter in which the former Labor Treasurer said:

question.para: I use the arguments above, I am dismissed because of the success of the industry on the export front and the dishonest tables, graphs and arguments of Treasury and Finance swallowed by my colleagues.

Again, I have made my views clear and will continue to push an industry policy for the wine industry, not a tax policy designed to thwart it and imposed on the basis of ignorance, stupidity and prejudice.
I ask the minister: if the former Labor Treasurer does not accept the basis for the proposed wine tax increase, why should this parliament or the people of Australia?

talk.start.para: —It is a free country. Mr Kerin has expressed his views in robust and colourful language. He is entitled to them, but they are not views which are shared by the government and the data is against him.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. Is it correct that the chief of the Australian Defence Force has directed that random urinalysis testing for the use of illegal drugs be introduced to the Australian Defence Force? Can the minister advise whether this measure will enhance the occupational health and safety of the Defence workplace?

answer.ministerial: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL
answer.speaker: Faulkner Sen J.P.

talk.start.para: —The Chief of the Australian Defence Force, Admiral Beaumont, has directed that a random drug testing program be introduced into the Australian Defence Force from 1 July 1995. This action is being taken in recognition of the Defence Force's duty of care as an employer of service members involved in areas where there are substantial and demonstrable safety concerns.

para.tab: The introduction of random drug testing into the Defence Force working environment is an initiative with which I, as Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, and Senator Ray, the Minister for Defence, are in complete agreement. I firmly believe that all possible protection needs to be provided to service personnel who are performing tasks such as flying or servicing aircraft or helicopters, handling explosives ordnance, operating heavy equipment such as armoured vehicles or trucks, or being responsible for the safe manoeuvre of warships.

In introducing the program, a balance has had to be struck between occupational health and safety and civil liberties. Special care will be taken in protecting the dignity and the privacy of individuals who are tested. I have asked the Chief of the Australian Defence Force to advise me as to the civil liberties safeguards to be put in place, particularly taking into account those safeguards which operate where random testing has been in place for some time.

I stress the point that the introduction of this measure does not in any way indicate that the ADF believes that there is an unusual problem with drug usage by ADF members. Because of the nature of service life, I think it is more likely that drug usage in the ADF will be more apparent to service authorities and that the testing proposal will assist service authorities in fulfilling their occupational health and safety duty of care.

Although the testing program will be random in the selection of individuals, it will place emphasis on important and high risk areas, such as operational units and basic training establishments. The program will support current disciplinary and administrative practices and provide reinforcement to the Defence Force's no drug policy.

To ensure that ADF members' careers are not adversely affected by false screen test indications, no disciplinary or administrative action will be taken against a member before a confirmatory laboratory test is carried out and that will be analysed using gas chromatography/mass spectroscopy. This is a definitive test that can be substantiated legally. The US, Canada and New Zealand have all introduced workplace random urinalysis testing in their defence forces. I believe that this proposal will receive a very positive response within both the ADF and the broader Australian community.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer to the Trade Practices Commission report, which was released today, on the legal profession and the privileges, self-regulated restrictions and statutory protection not open to other industries. Does the minister accept that it would be desirable to bring the legal profession fully under the Trade Practices Act, regardless of the business structure employed? If so, will the government seek agreement from the states for appropriate uniform legislation? If that agreement does not eventuate, would the government consider using an appropriate head of power, such as could be obtained by deleting the profession's exemption from the CER treaty with New Zealand and legislate anyway?

—The government welcomes the draft report on the legal profession of the Trade Practices Commission that was conducted by Professor Fels and was part of the Trade Practices Commission's study of the professions. We believe that the report, which was released this morning, is an important contribution to the debate about how to reform the structure of Australia's legal profession and make it more responsive to the economic needs of the 21st century, but not just to economic needs.

para.tab: There is little doubt—it is recognised very widely in this place—that the legal process has become inaccessible and remote for many Australians. We recognise that governments have a responsibility to increase access to justice for all citizens. One way of doing that is to establish procedures which are simple, cheap and fair. In this context, the Trade Practices Commission report is one important source of information to facilitate the changes that are necessary in this profession. This report, together with the report of the Hilmer inquiry and the very eminent Senator Cooney Senate inquiry into the costs of justice, provide cogent arguments about the urgent need for state and territory governments to look at the structure of their legal systems and to identify anti-competitive practices.

In respect of certain aspects of the report, the government supports the argument of the Trade Practices Commission that restrictive trade practices which cannot be justified in the public interest should be eliminated. That point was also made by the Chief Justice of the High Court, Sir Anthony Mason, in a recent speech. We also believe that the draft report makes a persuasive argument for the need for an integrated national profession, a goal which both the Attorney-General and the Minister for Justice have been pursuing with some vigour.

There is also little doubt about the costs of our legal system and the fact that those costs have the potential to impact on our international competitiveness. For instance, the legal profession has an annual turnover in excess of $3 billion and employs some 55,000 people. The current situation, where there are some 17 representative bodies spread over eight jurisdictions, indicates that the profession is over-regulated and in need of reform.

We also note that regulation of the private legal profession is very much in the hands of the state and territory governments. There has already been significant cooperation between those governments and the federal government in respect of the mutual recognition scheme. We anticipate that we can build on that cooperation to achieve some changes that are highlighted in the Trade Practices Commission report.

We believe that the approach of the Trade Practices Commission to remove restrictive practices and to increase the scope of the profession by allowing lawyers to advertise and engage in multi-disciplinary practices is something which the government will seriously examine as part of our law reform agenda. We welcome the debate and discussions that the draft report will generate. We welcome constructive input by the profession and the community. We hope that the legal profession embraces the spirit of this draft report as an opportunity to examine its structures and to increase access to justice for all Australians.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his comments which show an appreciation of the fact that the legal profession requires considerable reform. However, he has not answered the second and third parts of my question. Specifically, can he please comment on whether the government will seek agreement from the states to put the legal profession under the Trade Practices Act? In the third part of the question, I have offered an alternative. If he cannot answer those two questions today, can he please take them on notice.

—We will obviously take those questions on notice. In the answer I gave, I said that we would be seeing the draft report as the basis for the generation of discussion and debate. In the context of that debate and in the context of our addressing those issues in cooperation with the state and territory governments, which I have also indicated, the points of view put forward by Senator Spindler will be taken into account.

—I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the operations of UNOSOM and the current violent circumstances in south Mogadishu in Somalia. How does the government assess the deteriorating situation in Somalia? Are Australians who are supporting the relief effort in that country safe? Does the Australian government have specific advice for Australian citizens engaged in such humanitarian work?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —The Australian government shares the international community's distress and concern at the continuing violence in Somalia and, in particular, the very bloody and destructive clashes that have been occurring in south Mogadishu between UN military personnel and the supporters of the warlord Aideed.

para.tab: There are 38 Australian Defence Force personnel currently deployed in support roles with UNOSOM in Mogadishu—30 movement controllers and eight headquarters staff. Ten ADF air traffic controllers will shortly join the UNOSOM operation. There are also a small number of Australian NGO representatives scattered throughout the country. We understand that all Australians in Somalia are currently safe, but, of course, we are keeping in very close touch with the situation as it evolves.

The acute policy dilemmas and difficulties now facing the UN in Somalia should not, I think, conceal the extent of the UN's achievement to date in that country. The humanitarian crisis threatening the lives of hundreds of thousands of people has been averted through a combination of civil relief and military

answer.para: support action. The situation throughout the country as a whole remains more peaceful and stable than has been the case for a long time. There is an obvious danger that any precipitate withdrawal by UN forces would cause a rapid deterioration in that situation.

para.tab: Any UN peace operation—whether it is in support of humanitarian objectives, as is the situation here, or otherwise—does need, in order to be fully effective, clear and achievable goals, widespread international support and maximum possible local support, adequate total resources, complementary peace making initiatives—where those are relevant—and clearly designated criteria for termination. It has to be acknowledged that by no means all those conditions have been clearly satisfied at every stage of the Somali operation to date. So far as the future is concerned, the UN is now working to a mandate spelt out in two Security Council resolutions—814 of 26 March, which mandates UNOSOM to disarm the Somali factions to facilitate national reconciliation and rehabilitation, and 865 of 22 September, which strongly endorses UNOSOM's performance to date while, at the same time, urging renewed efforts to achieve national reconciliation and further develop the Somali police, judicial and penal systems.

What has to happen now is the finalisation and implementation of a comprehensive and internally consistent plan to address the full range of Somalia's needs. This is a continuing need in the short term for security for humanitarian purposes, but the greater need is for a peace building process which will enable governing institutions to be recreated and a political process of reconciliation commenced.

The security dilemma posed by the recent action of Aideed's supporters is an acute one, and the temptation for the UN, and especially the US forces, to engage now in a massive military action is obviously very strong. I have to say, however, for my own part, that I continue to believe that peace enforcement action in Somalia should remain firmly fixed on the basic objectives of enabling peace keepers to carry out their protective and humanitarian relief mandates, should avoid using disproportionate force and, so far as humanly possible, should avoid becoming involved in an escalating cycle of retaliation.

Finally, the government can fully understand the decision of the US to reinforce its quick reaction force as a short term response to the recent surge of violence in Mogadishu. But we also very strongly support President Clinton's recent call at the UN to place greater emphasis on national reconciliation in Somalia to enable UNOSOM to eventually be brought to a successful conclusion with the withdrawal of all US and other, including Australian, peace keepers by March 1995, as was envisaged in Security Council resolution 865.

question.speaker: Hill Sen R.M.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the Prime Minister's promise at the Press Club in July of this year when he said:

question.para: These tax cuts will be delivered in full this financial year. They will be l-a-w law. And what is more, they are r-e-s-p-o-n-s-i-b-l-e responsible law.

The minister will recall that these tax cuts were claimed to be fully funded and would not require increases in indirect taxes. I therefore ask: by linking what is left of the increased tax cuts to indirect taxation measures, is the government not admitting that it lied its way into office? Do these government lies in fact contribute to the slump of Mr Keating and apparently to Mr Crean eyeing his job?

talk.start.para: —I remind Senator Hill of the nostrum often advanced by another Western Australian, not the author of that newspaper article, that one should never believe what one reads in the newspapers. Certainly that advice of former Senator Withers is something which is very pertinent in relation to that particular report. I do not accept for a moment what Senator Hill is saying about Mr Keating's statements last year.

para.tab: Of course we promised to deliver the direct tax cuts and of course we promised to deliver the first element of those in full this financial year. That remains our intention. Provided the parliament behaves in the responsible way that we would hope and expect—notwithstanding the huff and puff, the rhetoric and the irresponsibility demonstrated in some quarters so far—then it will be possible to honour that particular commitment.

As I said yesterday, one cannot square the circle, one cannot make black white and one cannot pay for things for which there is no appropriate funding if one wants to maintain appropriate economic responsibility. We made a very clear commitment to medium term deficit reduction of an order of magnitude that was fully spelt out. We made it perfectly clear that we would not be seeking to fund the tax cuts by any broadening of the indirect tax base, but we said nothing about ensuring that there was no tax increases at all.

On the contrary, it was made clear that while there would be no new taxes of an indirect kind and while the overall tax burden would be maintained at roughly its proportion of GDP, nothing more was said on that subject. Nothing more could have been said because obviously we were committed to a course of fiscal responsibility which could be achieved only by the combination of strategies that we have articulated in this particular budget.

question.block.title: Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science

talk.start.para:
—My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. I refer to the 1993 Congress of the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science, ANZAAS, held in Perth last week. What role does ANZAAS play in raising awareness about science and scientists, and what contribution does it make to the shaping of science and technology policy? Further, is the minister concerned about comments made by Julian Cribb in the
Australian
yesterday under the headline, `Dust of neglect settles on science's showcase'?

—Yes, I have seen the article in yesterday's
Australian
by Julian Cribb regarding the recent ANZAAS Congress held in Perth. The article by Mr Cribb drew attention to the fact that, in his estimation, there had been declining attendances at recent ANZAAS congresses and this was for him a disturbing trend. I think the evidence that he puts in the article is true. Compared with ANZAAS congresses of a decade or more ago when 2,000 delegates turned up to a congress, there has been a decline in attendance at the congress. Some of the suggestions he makes about why this has occurred are thoughtful comments; whether they are correct or not needs wider assessment.

para.tab: I would point out that the congress in Perth was still extremely successful and more than 700 delegates attended. Considerable press publicity was given to many of the major papers presented and the discussions that took place. However, it has been recognised that in the past few decades ANZAAS has been a peak forum for the promotion of science in Australia and in New Zealand and for the promotion in awareness terms for the general public; it gives the opportunity to our science community to explain what it is doing and to explain to the Australian community that in many areas of science research we are at the cutting edge of world developments.

As a result of the ANZAAS congress and my concern, partly raised in the article by Mr Cribb, I have arranged for officers of the science and technology awareness section of my department to have discussions with the organisers of the ANZAAS congress to see whether there are ways in which we can promote future ANZAAS congresses to get the attendance up and, above all else, to make it the fulcrum of science awareness in Australia. Certainly we as a government are committed to the ANZAAS congress as a major forum. At some stage in the future I look forward to being able to report on the results of those discussions between the officials in my department and the organisers of the ANZAAS congress.

I would again emphasise that we congratulate the organisers of the congress in Perth at which many worthwhile papers were presented. Many received publicity, but the one that drew some attention was a paper presented calling for the promotion of science by perhaps having soap operas dealing with science rather than with medicine. This might lead in future to our seeing soap operas on television called, say, `Country Chemist'.

talk.start.para: —You would have a starring role.
—As Senator Kemp has interjected, one could imagine that if his brother, the shadow spokesman for science, ever became the minister, the soap opera would be `Nightmare on Limestone Avenue'.

question.speaker: Gibson Sen B.F.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the minister to a statement by the current Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, who in 1982 labelled as absurd the suggestion that indirect taxes had to be increased to fund income tax cuts. He stated:

question.para: To say that indirect tax rises are needed to fund income tax cuts is to promise nothing . . . to taxpayers as a whole.
Why does the government not acknowledge that it lied at the last election? Why does it not accept the decision of the Senate yesterday to break the link between tax cuts and indirect tax rises?

talk.start.para: —What is perfectly obvious is that any given budget is a product of its time, a product of its economic circumstances, and has its own rationale depending on what those circumstances are. In the present environment, where we are talking about deficit reduction as an overwhelming necessity for the economic health of this country over the medium term, of course it is necessary for tax rearrangements of this kind to be essentially revenue neutral, unless we want to go down the path of massive government expenditure reduction, which is the path the opposition wanted to go down with its Fightback proposal. It would have had devastating consequences for the economy and the people in it.

para.tab: As Mr Willis said at some length and very effectively in the House of Representatives yesterday, in 1982 we had an economy that needed the stimulus of an increased deficit. That was the argument of the day. That was the economic context of the time. That is why we argued then, in 1981, that some of these things were both economically responsible and affordable. That is, no doubt, the context in which Mr Willis was making whatever remarks he was in 1981-82 about the payment for direct tax cuts. As I said earlier this week, context is everything in these situations. It is the crudest form of political cheap point scoring to try to turn remarks made in a totally different context back on their author years later.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Given that Commonwealth government outlays have risen by 3.9 per cent in real terms this budget, after rises of 5.3 per cent and 5.5 per cent in the previous two years, and given that all private sector firms—large, small and medium—are reducing costs in order to survive and compete, and also given that all state governments are reducing expenditure in order to survive, why does the government not reduce costs and outlays within its own sector rather than increase indirect taxes?

—There is a major effort under way to reduce those outlays in the longer term. They are simply not easily reduced in the short term because so many of those outlay increases in recent years have been cyclical in character—a response to the recession and a response to the demands made upon the social security system because of the situation in which we found ourselves as a consequence of the worldwide recession and its impact upon us. That is the environment in which we are operating. There has been no opportunity to carve into the underlying structural outlays because that job has been done with such remarkable efficiency and effectiveness over such a long period of time, in a way that was never accomplished by honourable senators opposite in their terms in office.

para.tab: We have absolutely nothing to apologise for in terms of the way in which the fiscal programs of this government have been put together or the way in which the outlay reductions have been managed throughout the 1980s. Of course there has been a blow-out in the last two or three years. Of course it has been a function of the particular transient economic circumstances in which we find ourselves. The underlying structural condition of the budget is as sound as it has ever been as a result of the efforts that we put into it right throughout the 1980s.

If those opposite think they can carve into outlays in the way they were blandly and blithely promising they would in the Fightback package, without causing monumental damage to many people in this country, then they simply do not understand the way in which the current budget is structured. They do not understand the degree of room for manoeuvre there is as a result of the extraordinarily tough limits that have been made over a very long period.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the minister aware of the increasing number of human rights violations occurring in Pakistan against Ahmadi Muslims? Can the minister confirm that under Pakistan's penal code and other laws Ahmadi Muslims are prevented from practising their religion and are discriminated against in employment, education and health, and that an increasing number of these Ahmadis are being arrested and detained? What is the nature of Australian government representations concerning these human rights violations? Has Australia urged Pakistan to conform with and respect all international human rights declarations? Finally, what hope is there that Pakistan's newly elected government will adopt a more positive and humane approach to human rights?

—A number of representations have been made to me by the Ahmadi community in Australia alleging human rights violations against Ahmadis in Pakistan, in particular through the application of that country's laws against blasphemy. It is a fact that the blasphemy laws as interpreted by the full bench of the Supreme Court of Pakistan have prohibited the Ahmadis from using Islamic terminology in respect of the observance of their religious practices and that members of that community have been prosecuted for contravention of the law on blasphemy.

para.tab: Ahmadis are clearly being inhibited in the practise of their religion. There is also evidence that they are being discriminated against in other ways, including arrest and detention. These allegations have been very well documented by Amnesty International and other human rights organisations.

We have followed with serious concern these developments and also a number of other related developments including the Pakistan government's moves to include religious affiliations on national identity cards and the introduction in 1992 of the death penalty for those convicted of blasphemy. We have regularly raised these concerns with the government of Pakistan, including by the high commissioner to the Pakistani Minister for the Interior.

On the issues raised by the national identity card, the blasphemy law and the death penalty, the high commissioner has given our view that discrimination against minority religious groups, not just against members of the four million strong Ahmadi community but also against Christians, is clearly contrary to universally accepted standards of human rights.

We were encouraged with the establishment on 27 September by the caretaker Prime Minister of a national commission on minorities to review legislation and practices which might discriminate against minorities and to recommend to the government ways to better integrate minorities into Pakistan society. I am not sure whether the brief extended to women but it might desirably do so, given the particular problems that have also been experienced by that half of Pakistan society.
In accordance with its universal policy on human rights, the Australian government will continue to monitor the situation in Pakistan and make representation to the authorities where we think that is appropriate and likely to be productive. I have specifically directed the Australian High Commission in Islamabad to maintain a close interest in the work of that commission on minorities and to ensure that the new Pakistani government is fully seized of our concerns and those of the international community generally about continuing violations of the human rights of minority religious groups in particular, including their rights to practise their religions freely and to non-discrimination generally on religious grounds.

question.speaker: Crane Sen W.

talk.start.para: —I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to a statement made in 1980 by the then shadow minister for minerals and energy. He said:
