question.para: It is a shocking thing that every petrol pump has become the office of the Tax Department—a shocking thing.

That shadow minister is today's Prime Minister, Mr Keating—he may not be tomorrow by the look of the heading of the newspaper I am holding. In view of the fact that this Labor government has upgraded the role of the fuel pump as a tax collector, has the government conducted any analysis on the socioeconomic impact of increasing the cost to every transport truck by, on average, a massive $6,000 per year as a result of the increases in fuel tax and sales tax? How much will this put up the cost of an average trolley of groceries?

talk.start.para: —Tell us about it again.
—Senator Boswell's interjection is in fact absolutely correct. I have already answered this question in here, in question time, before.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services—
—Is it without notice?

—It is. Is the minister aware of a press release issued by Senator Newman on 21 September in which she claimed that the minister does not have cabinet authority for the link between child-care accreditation and child-care assistance payments? Is there any basis for Senator Newman's claim? Is her assertion correct that the accreditation system will cost the child-care industry $4 million? I believe the minister is aware of a campaign opposing the accreditation system. Is the information being provided through that campaign to child-care providers and parents accurate?

—In Senator Newman's press release, like most of her press releases, there appears to be very little that is correct. It is typical of the misinformation and opportunism we have come to expect from Senator Newman on these matters. The accreditation and quality improvement system was developed through the establishment of an interim national accreditation council. That emerged after some two years of consultation and that has further been refined with the establishment of the national accreditation council. Both councils have included members of all sectors of the child-care industry—public and private, providers and parents. The interim council consulted very extensively throughout Australia in the development of the system. It is absolute nonsense for Senator Newman to suggest that the process has been deceptive in any way.

para.tab: Senator Newman made reference to lack of cabinet endorsement. Well, she is wrong there too. The cabinet endorsed the system, including the link with child-care assistance, in April this year. For Senator Newman to suggest that I have been subverting the cabinet process is something I would find offensive, except that I find it too stupid in the extreme. I remind the opposition and Senator Newman that no responsible government just spends money without some proper auditing or accounting of that money.

The child-care assistance that is provided to child-care centres is large and growing, and it is very proper for the government to be assured that it is being provided to the right people in the right amount. It is also important that we can assure parents that they are being assisted by receiving quality care. That is absolutely vital for the parents of Australia.

I would like briefly to tell the opposition and this Senate what the accreditation system is about because it is quite clearly being misunderstood. There is a link between the child-care fee relief, the child-care assistance, and the—

Opposition senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Crowley, ignore the interjections.

—I am doing my best. I am not being distracted by them; I just cannot hear over them. I will briefly explain to the Senate what the accreditation process is and what it is that establishes the link with child-care assistance. It would be only after two separate reports to me—which would follow two reviews of any child-care centre—indicating that a child-care centre had shown absolutely no intention to improve the quality of care it was providing that I would be in a position to make a decision about whether or not to cut off the child-care assistance. It is a very protracted and thoughtful process that assures the industry that we are not going to be rushing to remove child-care assistance.

para.tab: Large parts of the industry itself, certainly parts of the private industry, are strongly in support of accreditation. They know it assures the industry and parents of quality in the child care area. I wonder at the opposition putting out this misinformation and assisting the campaign by some sections of the private industry to oppose it. I would love to know whether the opposition will remove quality assurance from child-care centres. Is that what it wants to say to parents—that it is not committed to the insistence on quality for our parents?

Opposition senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —It is interesting to hear some interjections here, Mr President. I am not at all clear what the opposition would do about quality. But in the sense that it is supporting a campaign of misinformation, it is certainly not assisting to assure parents.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer the minister to the Senate estimates committee inquiry that heard evidence from AQIS about alleged travel rorts. We all understand that the minister stepped off a plane from Korea and came straight to the hearings, and we were very grateful for that, but he may not have been properly briefed by the department. I take this opportunity now to ask the minister: does he still believe that the travel irregularities within AQIS have been fully and completely resolved to the government's satisfaction? And does he still believe that AQIS has received a clean bill of health from the Australian National Audit Office?

—I think there is one qualification that I should give up-front—that is, standing orders do not require me to express a private opinion; it requires me to answer, in this case, for another minister. I am being asked in this question for a private opinion. Having noted that, I understand that there are ongoing inquiries into AQIS travel. When those further inquiries have been completed, I will be in a position to say something about it, if asked.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Would the minister agree to the officers who were originally requested to attend those hearings but did not have the opportunity to discuss the matters raised against them—and we did not name those officers—appearing before the supplementary hearings of Estimates Committee A?

—This is a question which canvasses an opinion on the conduct of estimates committee procedures. In those procedures I raised objections to the names of individual public servants being brandished around under parliamentary privilege, their names thus becoming public in the public record of
Hansard
. I think that is a proper and reasonable approach.

para.tab: I cannot take the answer any further because I understand further inquiries are going on into AQIS travel. Until they are completed and all the information is before the minister, I am not in a position to be advised as to what the appropriate response might be. It is best to wait for what is on foot to be completed before the government makes a decision, if a government decision is required, because the estimates really ought to concentrate on expenditure. The conduct of government departments is a matter for the secretary of the department in the first place and, if necessary, the minister.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the minister to the application for family reunion migration by the children of Zeenat and Kulsoom Rind. The minister would be aware that the Rind sisters are the Pakistan born daughters of an Australian Aboriginal.

para.tab: First, has the minister sought advice from the Attorney-General with regard to the citizenship status of people of Aboriginal descent who were born overseas? Secondly, did that advice show that one of the effects of the 1967 referendum, which conferred on the Commonwealth the power to make laws pertaining to Aboriginal people, was to confer citizenship on Aboriginal people? Thirdly, did that advice further show that Australian citizenship was conferred on Aboriginal people who were at the time permanently resident outside Australia or were born outside Australia? Fourthly, if the minister has not sought or received such advice, does he intend to do so in order to clarify the status of people such as the Rinds?

talk.start.para: —It seems that once again Senator Chamarette has put in a strong contention for question of the week with this one. I might have some information on this, but I suggest to senators that if they do have immigration cases, it might be more appropriate to write to me rather than to raise them in this place. I should also say that this matter has been discussed between my office and Senator Chamarette's for some time.

para.tab: As to background, the Rind sisters, Kulsoom and Zeenat, are Pakistani nationals. Their father was born in Australia but moved to Pakistan in 1930 where he married twice and had 13 children, including Kulsoom and Zeenat. The girls' paternal grandmother was a full blood Aboriginal and their paternal grandfather was from Pakistan. These two sisters entered Australia in 1989 and were subsequently given permanent residence. They are now eligible for citizenship by grant, having met the residence requirement. They or their supporters are suggesting that they should be automatically entitled to Australian citizenship by virtue of their Aboriginal descent—of course, their paternal grandparent. The Australian Citizenship Act does not provide for this.

The Rind sisters have sponsored their spouses and children for migration to Australia from Pakistan. Kulsoom Rind's spouse and four children have been approved; they arrived in April 1993. Her eldest son was refused as he failed the points test, but he did not appeal. Zeenat Rind's spouse and children still have migration applications pending. Her children encountered some eligibility difficulties because they are adult and not classified as dependants of Zeenat. The children's applications are at various stages. The eldest son was refused, and there has been no request for review. The eldest daughter was refused at the primary stage, refused at the review stage and refused by the IRT.

talk.start.para: —For a question without notice this is fantastic.

—I suggest to others, though, that I do not have every case at my fingertips like this one. Four other children were refused as not dependent. They were advised of their review rights, but they also did not proceed to review. In respect of the husband, his application is awaiting health and character clearances.

para.tab: Senator Chamarette asked some questions arising from this. It might surprise Senator Patterson, but I was not able in the short time that I have had to focus on this question, to find out whether there has been advice from the Attorney-General on the question of citizenship status of persons of Aboriginal descent who were born overseas. Senator Chamarette refers to the effects of the 1976 referendum. Of course, a referendum of itself cannot confer powers on the Commonwealth or confer citizenship; there has to be legislation to implement the result of a referendum.

With respect to those questions the honourable senator has asked, my department is looking into the matter and, as already indicated, looking into it quite comprehensively. We are looking into the matters that Senator Chamarette has raised and I will be able to advise her, probably in writing, when further information is available.

question.block.title: Women: Representation on Boards, Authorities and Instrumentalities

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. In 1983 Susan Ryan re-announced the government's policy of seeking to put 50 per cent representation of women on government boards, authorities and instrumentalities. This week, one decade later, the minister re-announced the same policy. Therefore, my question is twofold: will the minister explain to this parliament why her governments have been so consistently unsuccessful in delivering on that promise that they keep repeating; and, secondly, when can we expect some new and innovative policies in relation to status of women from a Labor government, now that Susan Ryan has left?

—This is an interesting question, because Senator Vanstone fails to tell us the facts of the matter. It was this government that put the appointment of women to boards on the political agenda; it was this government that put women on the political agenda at all; and it is this government that has introduced the affirmative action legislation, the sex discrimination legislation and the equal opportunity legislation.

para.tab: What Senator Vanstone has not told us is that the election to boards, while still short of 50 per cent, is dramatically more than it was 10 years ago. In some areas, the representation of women is now up to 24 or 25 per cent, which is a dramatic increase on the five per cent that was there in 1983. What we have seen is a considerable improvement, but an insufficient improvement. So I cannot see why, when it is quite clearly a commitment of this government to that kind of equal representation, I should not properly restate that continuing aim of government to see fair and 50 per cent representation.

I hope that Senator Vanstone actually notes the dramatic increase that has occurred in the 10 years since this government has been in office. The fact that representation is not at 50 per cent is a matter of such importance that of course I restate this commitment again. But I note that there has been a very significant increase, improving from the figures that were there when we came into office.

In about a week's time I will be announcing the outcomes of the review by the Office of the Status of Women that was asked for by the Prime Minister. At the moment I am preparing a report for the Prime Minister. It properly belongs to him, so after I have given that report to him I will be in a position to make public some further advances for women.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her answer and I have three questions that are occasioned as a consequence of that. Firstly, she said that Labor first put the appointment of women to boards on the agenda. Does she categorically deny the role of the Fraser government in that area? Secondly, does her government seek to implement that policy in its own appointments to its own ministry? If not, why is what is good for the goose not good for the gander? Thirdly, next time she re-announces this policy, will she have the good grace to admit that she is simply re-announcing a commitment and not pretend that this is some new initiative and push of her own when she is just dangling on the coat tails of Susan Ryan?
—It is absolutely undeniable that it is the Labor government, which has been in office since 1983, that has put women on the political agenda.

para.tab:
Government senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Order! I would expect that honourable senators on the government side would give their own minister a fair go.

—Thank you, Mr President. Whatever the opposition and Senator Vanstone think the Fraser government did for women, without doubt it was this government when it came to office, recognising what was still waiting to be done, that took the initiative. It maintains the initiative and, as I said, it will continue that initiative. It is we who have the credibility for women. It is beyond dispute that this government has put women on the agenda and made those achievements for women. We will continue to do that. As I said, details of forthcoming initiatives will be made available to honourable senators after I have told the Prime Minister about them.

—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the
Notice Paper
.

speech.speaker: Zakharov Sen A.O.

talk.start.para: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training on the effect of the operation of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act 1974, together with transcript of evidence and submissions received by the committee.

para.tab: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the report.

speech.para:
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in
Hansard
and to continue my remarks.

para.tab: Leave granted.

The statement read as follows
—

speech.para: The thrust of the recommendations of this report tabled in the Senate today by the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training is that industrial disputes must be settled within the framework of industrial relations legislation and sections 45D&E of the Trade Practices Act should not be invoked to deal with them. The report is a majority report, and contains a dissenting report by Senators Crane and Tierney.

The Trade Practices Act has a legitimate and important role in dealing with activity which deliberately sets out to corrupt fair trading operations, to manipulate prices, or to undermine free competition in the market. When it comes to industrial action, however, the use of sections 45D&E are entirely inappropriate. The vast majority of occasions on which 45D&E are either threatened or used involve disputes of an industrial nature—that is, they involve workers undertaking an action to achieve ends which they regard as being in the economic or social interests of themselves or fellow workers, and employers or businesses who are seeking to protect themselves from any economic harm which results from that action.

The sorts of actions which have typically drawn 45D-type responses are essentially industrial issues rather than trade or competition issues. This is not to say that there is no overlap between these two arenas, but to point out that such disputes and their resolution lie most appropriately and conveniently with the practice of industrial relations rather than the practice of corporate affairs. The Committee acknowledges that it is secondary boycotts which are the focus of attention here, but sections 45D&E have much wider ramifications. In order to deal with such actions, modifications to industrial relations legislation will be required. There must be an efficient mechanism established which will deal effectively with these matters by negotiation rather than penal action.

The Committee has found that sections 45D&E are in breach of ILO conventions and are not a satisfactory means of settling disputes. The Committee asserts that the legitimate rights of businesses to trade in a fair and competitive market should be properly secured by trade practices legislation, but that sections 45D&E are an unacceptable mechanism for achieving this because of their impact on the legitimate rights of others to take industrial, protest or other social action. The Trade Practices Act should be amended to recognise the distinction between the competition and non-competition aspects of sections 45D&E, and to deal with boycotts involving competitors where they have the purpose of restricting trade or reducing competition in a given market.

The report affirms the principle of a right to withdraw labour, and that any qualifications attached to that right should be spelled out in industrial relations legislation, and not in trade practices legislation. The Committee has also recommended that industrial disputes should be dealt with in the first instance under modified industrial relations legislation, but where a dispute cannot be speedily resolved by negotiation, then a certificate should be issued enabling the matter to be dealt with in a civil jurisdiction.

The report comes at a time when major industrial reforms are the subject of intense discussion between the government, employers and unions. It is important that Australia takes this opportunity to simplify and rationalise what has become a complex web of statute and common law surrounding how we run industrial relations in this country. The report sets out some clear principles for dealing with dispute resolution. We have identified in an unequivocal way the regulatory frameworks for dealing with industrial and competition matters respectively. It is up to the government and the parliament to ensure that the legislative details attached to those frameworks protect the legitimate interests of all industrial parties and contain mechanisms which can quickly and effectively deal with any problems which arise.

Sections 45D&E of the Trade Practices Act have been a controversial part of industrial relations in Australia. The submissions to the Committee from business and employer associations have argued strongly for the retention of 45D&E, which they regard as a vital legislative mechanism enabling them to prevent industrial disputation or to obtain damages for losses incurred as a result. The union movement and many others in the community regard 45D&E as a harsh piece of legislation, arguing that it works against the democratic right to take industrial and other social action, and that its provisions are contrary to ILO Conventions. Conservationists are unhappy with 45D&E because it exposes them to the risks of being sued as a consequence of protest action. They believe that peaceful protest action against companies involved in environmentally risky activity is a fundamental right which should not be impeded by legislation such as 45D&E.

The Committee has sought to identify clearly the legislative frameworks in which the competing, legitimate interests of various groups should be dealt with. The mechanisms established within those legislative frameworks must be consistent with the traditions of justice and fair play which our community regards as important. The community must have confidence that regulatory mechanisms will achieve what they are intended to achieve, and that they are both responsive and equitable in their operation.

The Committee has heard from a wide range of interest groups. We believe our recommendations establish clear guidelines for revised industrial relations legislation and trade practices legislation. It is imperative that the complexity and confusion which has dominated the operation of sections 45D&E be resolved once and for all by the repeal of these sections of the Trade Practices Act.

debate.title:
SALES TAX (CUSTOMS) (DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL 1993
SALES TAX (EXCISE) (DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL 1993
SALES TAX (IN SITU POOLS) (DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL 1993
SALES TAX (GENERAL) (DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL 1993
SALES TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL 1993

speech.speaker: Macdonald Sen S.

talk.start.para:
—The massive 55 per cent rise in sales tax on the wine industry strikes at the very heart of the Hunter region from where I come. The former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, agrees. In Today's
Australian
he said:

speech.para: "The 55 per cent tax increase is a massive disincentive to invest in one of our few expanding primary industries.
A Hunter Valley grower said to me last night that if something is doing well, the government kicks the proverbial out of it. That sums it up.

para.tab: The stability and economic growth of the Hunter Valley is under attack by this Labor government. It is an attack that the National Party of Australia will not wear. The Hunter Valley relies heavily on both its wine and tourist industries. Both are intertwined; tax one industry and they both suffer.

The Hunter Valley, boasting picturesque landscapes with rows of grapevines and dotted with boutique wineries, attracted 1 1/2 million people to the area last year. Approximately 60,000 overseas tourists are attracted to the Hunter Valley because of its superb wine, superb hospitality and its proximity to Sydney. It is also a very convenient staging point for tourists venturing further into New South Wales.

This insidious wine tax will strike at the very heart of the tourist infrastructure that has been built up so effectively over the last 15 or so years. It will wipe out small vineyards. We will be left with a region bereft of economic stability, which is built very much on tourism. These industries are of immense importance to the Hunter Valley.

The Hunter Valley is the sixth most popular domestic tourist destination in Australia. The increased cost of wine, combined with the increase in fuel prices and the wholesale sales tax, will make this wine growing area a much less viable tourist destination. This will impact on not only the wineries but also the tourist facilities and the infrastructure that has been built up around it.

Small wineries, which in reality are small businesses, will be particularly disadvantaged by the increase in their sales tax bill, which has to be paid for up-front. Sales tax billed in the current month must be remitted to the government by the 21st of the following month. If average credit is 60 days, the increase in sales tax will be a very heavy extra burden on the working capital of these wineries. One Hunter Valley grower said to me last night that under the present tax regime he presently owes $480,000 in sales tax. If the tax increase is to be introduced, that will increase to $750,000; he will owe $0.75 million dollars in sales tax.
The New South Wales wine industry is one of the few agricultural industries that presently has stability, growth and potential, especially in the export area. This new burden will stifle it.

It must be remembered that wine is a 7 1/2 times value adding primary product. By the year 2000 the industry believes it will be a $1 billion export industry. But that will require approximately $1.2 billion in expenditure. It has been explained to me that at least half of that $1.2 billion will be spent on wages. The other part of that equation is jobs, jobs and more jobs. They will not be created if this wine tax is increased.

Wine is a rural based industry contributing to regional economies in the towns of Cessnock, Muswellbrook, Singleton and neighbouring Mudgee and Orange. These towns rely on servicing the grape growers. These service towns also feed off the tourist and downstream industries such as packaging, the very important transport industry in the Hunter Valley and, of course, marketing.

This viable domestic market provides the necessary cash flow and profitability to support our much needed export growth. For every bottle of wine sold overseas, we have to have 1 1/2 bottles in the cellar because wine needs to mature over a period of two or three years.

The last thing the people of the Hunter Valley need at this time is increased taxation on their livelihoods. Each day this government drives another seven people in the Hunter Valley onto the dole queue. Enough is enough. On 18 August Senator Gareth Evans, in an answer to a question, said:

speech.para: The nature of the projections I have seen suggest that there will be no difference in consumption patterns and no impact at all on jobs in this industry.

There might not be much change in consumption amongst the white wine trendies whom the minister knows, but how can he maintain that there will be no impact at all on jobs when the Winemakers Federation estimates that $445 million in investment will be lost as a result of the wine tax increase. The government is on a loser here—both in what is right for growth and employment and what is good politics.

talk.start.para: —To indicate where the Greens WA stand on this set of bills, I make the point that the government's budget was framed to set out a four year strategy for reducing the budget deficit to around one per cent of gross domestic product, while delivering the first round of income tax cuts for middle income earners legislated in last year's budget, as well as the reduced company tax rates promised in the lead up to the election. Of course, this led to an unaffordable situation.

para.tab: The cut in company tax was put through parliament between the election and the swearing in of the new Senate, in order to be placed at the beginning of the current financial year and avoid any difficulties in getting it through the Senate. Whilst we understand that any action of the Greens WA and other parties in the Senate may affect the government's strategy for deficit reduction, I would like to remind the government that we have made suggestions, the most recent of which was last evening, about alternative revenue collection measures. We have suggested that there are alternatives available.

Therefore, while we are likely to flag opposition to some aspects of these taxes in an effort to decrease the level of wholesale sales tax and wine tax, I point out that we make these suggestions within the perspective of fiscal responsibility. The fact that the government is not currently taking up this level of fiscal responsibility is its responsibility.

In recent times there has been a lot of talk about certainty, the passage of bills and the role of the Senate. We have been criticised for not making commitments to pass the budget long before the bills were on the table and were able to be examined in detail. We agree that certainty is important, although it is by no means the only thing which is important.

One thing that everyone can be certain of is that the Greens WA will not support a grossly regressive budget. We have always said that we would support an equitable strategy to reduce the government's deficit in the medium term in a way that does not undermine the government's revenue base. The current package of bills fails in these two tests. The combined impact is highly regressive as it takes from the poor and gives to the rich. Furthermore, a shift from income taxes to indirect tax measures is a dead alley in terms of providing the revenue required to govern effectively and promote equity in the future.

Therefore, we foreshadow our amendments to this set of sales tax (deficit reduction) bills 1993. We intend to support the deferral of the second round of wholesale sales tax increases. This would be more than offset by delaying upper levels of tax cuts. There is no reason for the top one-fifth of wage earners to cream off that extra $1.3 billion in tax cuts. Like all taxpayers earning over $20,000 they, too, would get the basic $612 per annum tax rebate.

There is a popular myth that lower income earners do not spend enough to be really hurt by an increase in wholesale sales tax. In fact, they spend all their money on consumables. It is those people on higher incomes who have the luxury to save and invest. It reminds me of the wealthy man who believed he could help a poor man. The wealthy man asked, `How much do you spend on groceries?'. The poor man responded, `About a third of my wage'. The wealthy man said, `Ah, that's your problem. You need to manage your money better. I spend only two per cent on mine'.

Targeting the second increase in wholesale sales tax serves four purposes. It reduces the regressive impact that is the result of the shift from income taxes to indirect taxes, and that is not compensated for by the tax cuts or rebate for low income earners. It confronts the government with the need to find more equitable ways of raising the additional revenue required to provide important public services and reduce public debt as part of its medium term deficit reduction strategy. Not legislating to increase wholesale sales tax by a second one per cent in 1995 simply reinforces the need arising from the lack of funds to deal with Mabo legislation and labour market programs.

It allows the government adequate time to investigate and implement these revenue measures. It also reduces the inflationary impact of the budget in years to come. This reduces the need to rely on monetary policy and increased interest rates for economic management. Over-reliance on high interest rates hurts consumers and small business and should be avoided.

We also foreshadow our opposition to the sales tax on wine. The good point about the wine industry is that in Western Australia and many other parts of Australia it is locally owned, it has a high number of local employees and provides indirect employment in the hospitality, tourism and service sectors. These are specifically associated with the domestic market rather than the export market. Providing some sort of compensation for those parts of the industry simply for export does not deal with this kind of indirect employment.

Beer and spirits, on the other hand, are almost completely transnationally owned, high profit and centralised. The profits are repatriated overseas. The industry is currently retrenching employees at a vast rate of knots because it can mechanise and go for chemical production which allows for fewer employees. Much equipment is imported, as well as some materials, including hops.

It could be said that alcohol is alcohol is alcohol, but that overlooks all the details and the vast differences between these industries. In WA alone there are 500-plus wineries, mostly locally owned. In WA a number of the smaller wineries are working to establish minimum input viticulture. If they were forced by the nature of the industry to cut down costs, some of those wineries would be swallowed up by the larger operators which, generally, are not able to be as careful with their inputs as the smaller wineries can be.

The net effect of the proposed tax would concentrate the industry and make it go towards a more mechanised form of agriculture, one leaning heavily on pesticides and herbicides. Any fall-off in domestic sales would create pressure for amalgamation by those wineries going for export markets. A well-founded rumour has it that some of the bigger eastern states wineries, the transnational ones, do not in fact mind the tax; it is their chance to increase holdings here and they can mark down profits and pay less company tax.

Concern over the proposed Industry Commission study is based on the fact that the Industry Commission, in our estimation, has not shown itself capable of giving a wider picture in an industry study. The commission tends to be very narrow in its focus and does not look at the spread effects, negative or positive, of any particular aspect of industry to be studied.

An example that springs to mind is the Industry Commission's study on the greenhouse effect. Most of the first part of the study said how important it was for Australia to look carefully at reducing greenhouse gas emissions, but finally came to the conclusion that it was not possible because it would adversely affect the coal industry. The report ignored totally the number of jobs that could be created by energy efficiency, energy management and energy conservation, and also ignored any prospect of a cost efficient, revenue neutral cutback in greenhouse gas production. It did not look at those matters at all. So I do not have great faith in any government proposals for Industry Commission studies into the wine industry. If the government is serious about promoting regionally based development, it should find out which industries are relatively successful in regional development.

The government is left with a number of options. First, and best, is that it can accept our suggestions and majority suggestions of other parties in this place and support the budget bills in their amended form. This would result in an increase in revenue in the current and the next financial year and the development of more equitable means of raising revenue in the following years to offset the loss of the second increase in the wholesale sales tax.

The second, more simple, option would see the government either accepting that the 1995 increase in wholesale sales tax will not go ahead or proposing additional measures to compensate low income households for the impact of the budget package in the 1995-96 and 1996-97 financial years. Should this latter path prove too difficult, we would be happy to leave the second round of wholesale sales tax increases until next year's budget, where they might be discussed as a possible part of a larger package of measures.

The third, and least desirable, option facing the government is to persist in attempting to push through this ill-conceived and regressive future increase, together with an increase to be backdated to 17 August this year. If the amended legislation returns from the House of Representatives with the 1995 increase reinserted, we will not support the bills. This would cast grave doubts over the additional tax revenue currently being collected in the expectation of the legislation successfully passing into law.

talk.start.para: —I support the taxation bills. I think it is appropriate at this time to draw the attention of the Senate to some of the real measures that are actually being proposed here rather than to dwell on fear and hysteria, as honourable senators opposite have been doing.

para.tab: These propositions are essentially very simple. They involve three measures: an increase by one per cent of general rates of sales tax, increases in wine tax and changes in the tax regime for luxury cars. While these proposals are modest and involve only small increases in the existing wholesale sales tax rates, they will make a major contribution towards the government's fiscal objectives.

These measures will have a very small impact on prices. For example, the rise in the rate from 10 per cent rate to 11 per cent will increase the retail price of goods taxable at that rate by less than one per cent, and it will increase the price of a good currently taxable at 30 per cent by less than three-quarters of one per cent. These measures will have no effect on goods which are currently exempt from sales tax such as food and clothing. There has been no decision to extend indirect taxation to services. Passenger motor vehicles will continue to be taxed on a concessional basis. Although the concessional rate of 15 per cent introduced in One Nation will increase to 16 per cent and then 17 per cent in line with other rates, it will still be five percentage points below the general rate of sales taxes.

In view of what is being said by the doom and gloom merchants opposite, it is important to bear in mind what we are actually talking about. The merchants of doom are attempting to undermine the budget wherever they can and to frustrate the work of this government. We have heard a great deal from those opposite about how people were robbed at the last election and how promises were broken. What they do not say is that as political parties they went into that election with totally unacceptable political policies and as a result were rejected by the people of this country. They do not say that they went in with industrial relations policies which were totally unacceptable to most people in this country; which were against the traditions of this country; and which would have led this country into a period of profound confrontation.

Those opposite do not say that they went to the election with education policies which were designed to increase the levels of disadvantage and inequality in this country. They do not say that they went in with a policy to massively increase the levels of indirect taxation far above those that we have today. They do not say that they went in with policies which were alien to the people of this country. That is the real reason why they lost the last election. It was not because they were robbed; it was essentially because they went in with policies which were unacceptable. As John Howard has indicated many times, they were politically outclassed in the last election so their talk about their loss at the last election as if it was something strange surprises me no end.

We have heard a great deal about wine taxes. What we have not heard is the simple fact that the wine industry is booming and it is booming, essentially, because it has benefited directly from government policy. It has benefited directly from government support and favourable taxation policies over a long period of time.

When we talk about wine, we should make sure we understand the full implication of what is actually being said. The industry itself states that exports of Australian wine have increased dramatically in recent years from about 40.4 million litres in 1988-89 to 103.2 million litres in 1992-93. This represents an increase of 155 per cent in export sales over that period in volume terms alone. So it is a bit hard to talk about the effect of taxation on exports because we all know that those taxes do not apply to exports.

In real terms, wine exports have increased by 130 per cent over the period I have just indicated. The value of Australian wine exports in 1992-93 was $289 million. The major markets for Australian wine are the United Kingdom, the United States, New Zealand, Canada and Japan. If we look at international comparisons we can see that the Australian wine industry is doing extremely well. The wine industry has a very enviable record. There is high recognition of the quality of its produce. It has made excellent inroads into international markets as a result of its quality, not just its price. It has a major level of value adding in this country which has to be recognised.

It also has to be understood that in terms of other beverages, other competitors, the wine industry is treated very favourably indeed. Australian beer, which is the main rival of wine, is produced by Australian breweries which make this point very clearly: the favourable treatment of Australian wine is inequitable. They say that rather than the yeoman farmer image that those opposite are so keen on—the notion of the peasant farmer, the poor little battler out in the sticks—the fact is that the Australian wine industry is run by four major companies. Ninety per cent of its output is controlled by four major companies.

What we are talking about is the way in which the conservative parties once again come to the aid of big capital. What we see again and again in this place is their concern to protect privilege and vested interest. We do not see any concern for what the taxation will be spent on. We do not see from them any concern about the way in which people should express their social responsibilities to the economy and to society as a whole.

I must say that I am not too keen on either wine or beer, so I find the preoccupation with alcohol on the other side quite a strange thing, but if we compare beer and wine we see that wine incurs only about half the federal tax collected on beer. We see that 17.5 per cent of the purchase price of a four-litre wine cask goes in federal tax while 32 per cent of the purchase price of a similar quantity of beer is taken in federal tax. That does not include the state licence fees, which make that gap even greater.

It is important to remember that 90 per cent of the output of the wine industry is controlled by four major companies. When those opposite come in here bleating on behalf of wine interests they should bear that in mind. Who are they talking for? They should make it very clear that the economic interest is dominated by so few. That approach to vested interests runs consistently throughout the Liberal and National parties' policies. I am surprised that the Greens have not clearly understood just what are the economic relationships in this industry.

It is not surprising, in a sense, that people will try to go for the cheap shot. As Senator Cooney indicated this morning, it is a bit hard not to accuse people of trying to develop a constituency from within a vested interest that occurs from time to time. I guess that that is the nature of opposition. But it is a bit hard for the opposition to then turn around and say that it is behaving in an economically responsible manner. It has to get its position clear. Is the opposition seeking out new constituencies—as I believe the Greens are doing—or is it talking about the genuine economic benefit of this country? It is saying that this budget has to be undermined, but what is it saying about where the revenue is actually going to come from to pay for social programs? One does presume that there is some measure of economic responsibility on the other side of the chamber.

talk.start.para: —An heroic assumption.

—Perhaps that presumption is, in itself, wrong, as Senator Richardson has indicated. No industry really does like taxation. It is not surprising that industries should come to political opportunists and seek their support and seek an opportunity, a populist cause, to try to undermine the budget strategy of the Labor government.
We have to appreciate that in the context of the political situation in this country at the moment.

para.tab: The conservative opposition in this chamber is taking every opportunity to undermine the work of government. It is essentially trying to cut the sinews of government. That is the same strategy that Jeff Kennett undertook in Victoria. It does not surprise me that the same personnel have appeared here. Petro Georgiou is now on the staff of the opposition. It would follow that the same sorts of tactics which were followed in Victoria would be followed here. The only difference is that the federal opposition does not have nationally the same control over the media that was exercised in the run up to the Victorian election by the Liberal Party and the conservatives. Over a two-year period every action of the Victorian Labor government was held up to public ridicule and, of course, public confidence was undermined in the key institutions of society. That same sort of political advantage does not occur at a national level, so the opposition will find the task a lot tougher.

The other factor is that, at a national level, the Australian Labor Party is more coherent, more cohesive, much stronger in its attitude and much clearer in its determination to turn back the conservative tide. We all understand what the last election really was about, with the clear ideological divide that occurred. We understand just where the people of this country stand, because they rejected the opposition so completely. I do not suppose one can expect the opposition to understand this, but the Labor government is not about attacking the wine industry; it is about continuing to support it. It is about saying, however, that a fair level of taxation has to be applied to all industries.

I turn to luxury motor vehicles. Once again, we can see the point: the conservatives have to defend vested interests. Attacking the tax on luxury motor vehicles is a popular cause. The changes in taxation rates would see vehicles costing over $300,000, in some cases, being taxed more heavily than vehicles at a base rate of about $53,000. The concessions to the passenger vehicle industry will continue. However, there will be changes to ensure that the greatest share of taxation is paid on the larger, more expensive vehicles. I find that a very worthwhile proposition and I would find it difficult for anyone to suggest that that should be rejected. However, in voting on the matter today, that could happen. But I am sure that the Greens will be able to explain that in terms of the great social justice principles that are involved.

The obstructionism in this Senate will continue, but it will be resisted. As we have seen in recent times, the Labor Party in this chamber will fight vigorously for the principles that it believes in and for the defence of the Labor government. It will fight to ensure that proper policies are pursued in this country and that we get some lasting changes in this country to allow a much better and stronger society to develop. Proposals that seek to undermine the government's budget strategy, that seek to rip away at the government's right to govern in the way this chamber has been operating in recent times, will ultimately fail.

While people might enjoy momentary popularity in opposing taxation measures—as they are doing on this occasion—in the long haul they will be judged for their obstructionism. As the polls are turning—as they did in 1975—on the question of Senate obstructionism, there reaches a point when the electorate at large says that it is not good enough for minority senators to become the real opposition for a short time.

People will say there is clearly a responsibility on all senators here to allow the government to govern and to ensure that proper measures are undertaken to protect the fiscal position of this country. However, if opposition senators come into this chamber, after going to an election arguing for a GST, and say that a one per cent increase in some sales taxes—which protects the necessities of life and which means that basic, essential items of food and clothing that ordinary people need are exempt—is not good enough, they will stand condemned for being the hypocrites that they are.

speech.speaker: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

talker.name: Senator BROWNHILL
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

talk.start.para: —I will direct some of my remarks to the impact that the changes in these sales tax bills will have on the wine industry in Australia. It was very interesting to listen to the comments of the senator opposite about the industry and about how it is run by a few big winemakers and that the increases will not have any effect on the little people. I do not think he has the facts right whatsoever. The wine industry is a rising star in the rural portfolio area because it employs so many people.

para.tab: Despite an economy that Senator Carr's government has been ruling over—an economy that has been poorly mismanaged for a decade now—and despite the unfair imposts which this and other small industries, particularly in the rural sector, have had to endure, the wine industry has not done too badly. In fact, it has actually expanded. The Australian wine market—and this has been said before—is worth over $1 billion. It is one of our most successful domestic and export industries. There are about 5,000 wine grape growers and about 600 winemakers in Australia. They have a turnover of in excess of $1.5 billion.

To say, as Senator Carr said a moment ago, that the industry is just run by a few of the big boys is absolutely incorrect. There are a lot of people in the industry. There are people in the industry, for example, at Cowra—a new wine growing area—and at Orange in the foothills of Mount Canobola in the new wine growing areas of the cold country grapes. Wine has really burgeoned at Mudgee, although it has been produced there for a long time. The industry has really increased dramatically in the Hunter, and even out where I am, on the Liverpool plains just north of the Hunter Valley and south-west of Tamworth, wine is now being grown by Murray Tyrrell. He is one of the people who have advanced the industry, along with Brian McGuigan, Murray Robson and all the rest of them.

It was interesting to listen to Senator Carr say a moment ago that the government is looking after the wine industry. It is interesting—and I think Senator Tierney mentioned it—that some of the Labor Party members of the House of Representatives from the Hunter Valley voted in favour of this increased wine tax, which absolutely astounds me. For example, Mr Fitzgibbon, Mr Morris, Mr Brown, Mr Horne and the other Mr Morris all voted in favour of a wine tax, and they all represent wine growing areas.

talk.start.para: —Is that the Mr Fitzgibbon who increased his majority at the last election?

—Senator Richardson really came right in there because they did not mention it once during the election. They lied their way through the election and did not, at any stage, say they were going to hit the wine industry with increased taxes. I think that somebody who can sit in this place with a smile on his face while putting a tax on the wine industry is absolutely despicable.
—I have no problem at all.

—Senator Richardson had better not smile again because he might crack the mirror. Honestly, it behoves him very little to be talking about the wine industry the way he is, and denigrating it by saying that his party members from that area actually told the winegrowers during the election campaign that there would be a wine tax. They did not say they were going to put a wine tax on, but now they have.

para.tab:
The wine industry has a very high value added product, which is something I understand the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has been harping on about to rural industry for quite some time. I add here that it is quite interesting to see what a former minister for primary industries said about this wine tax. An article in the
Australian
on Thursday, 7 October states:

Former Labor treasurer and primary industries minister Mr John Kerin yesterday claimed the proposed wine tax increase was based on "ignorance, stupidity and prejudice", and described the Government's arguments for it as dishonest.

speech.para: That is exactly what I have said—dishonest, because there was no mention of it during the election campaign. This was said in a letter in response to the winemakers' complaints about the tax increase. An embittered Mr Kerin said it would be a `massive disincentive' to invest in the industry, and so it will be.

para.tab: The wine industry has done a great marketing job and consumption of Australian wines has increased here and overseas. In the UK, for example, it has done an outstanding job. It has taken five per cent of the United Kingdom market and Australian wine is much envied for its quality by the French winemakers. In fact, the French winemakers are making a direct drive to try to get back what the Australian winemakers have taken from them. In the face of all that success, the federal government has now decided to milk this industry—an industry that has been doing so well—and milk it for all its worth.

Like the fuel tax that will cripple some industries and make others even more uncompetitive, this tax has been assessed as costing the industry hundreds of millions of dollars in lost sales between now and the year 2000.

The week before last I visited some of the small winegrowers in the central west who do not have their own crushing facilities. The cost of transport to those people because of the fuel tax will slug them even before they get slugged producing the wine. The Winemakers Federation has predicted that its overseas sales target to the year 2000 will have to be revised downward from $1 billion to $500 million—a cut of 50 per cent simply because of the imposition of the tax. That is the impact it will have on our export sales. Surely this government must understand that and understand the reasons why we are against this extra tax on wine.

Exports are largely—and I agree with Senator Carr here—the domain of the big four winemakers who produce 90 per cent of the total Australian wine production. I agree with that, but what about all the other smaller ones that are keeping people in jobs and actually starting to expand? In addition to those, there are the ones that I am talking about, the approximately 500 or 600 small wineries that have recently formed themselves into the Independent Wineries Association. They are responsible for about 10 per cent of total production. The 55 per cent increase is particularly unacceptable to them because they have not enjoyed the export boom and they rely entirely on domestic sales to remain profitable.

It is interesting that earlier today in this debate Senator McKiernan said that it was not that big an increase anyway because it was only increasing from 20 per cent to 31 per cent. I was sitting next to Senator Panizza at the time and we could not quite understand how he worked out his mathematics when he said that was not a 55 per cent increase.
Those small winegrowers have to pay sales tax on all their promotional and tasting stocks, which can be a large part of their production. Those small winemakers would simply go out of business if they were forced to pay that extra 55 per cent on all of their stock as a tax.

Another group that has been left out of this equation is the wine sellers who, for the past six weeks, have been in a dilemma trying to determine whether or not they should apply the sales tax to stocks in hand. A letter from a constituent just the other day points out the dilemma he faces as a wine merchant. The letter is from Mr Frank White from Riverina Cellars and states:

speech.para: Wine accounts for approximately 33% of the total sales from my store. With fierce price competition in the retail liquor market the margin on wine products is essential if my business is to be profitable.

Any tax increase affects all wine purchased by me since the budget announcement. I urgently need to know what the level of the tax on wine is to be so that I may make accurate decisions on the prices of the products I sell.

Sales tax has a direct effect on the amount of State licence fee I have to pay and therefore has a multiplication effect on the calculation of my retail prices . . . If I make the wrong judgment now about what the sales tax will be I may not be able to pay the licence fee and will therefore risk losing my business.
So it affects everyone at all levels all the time. It is people such as this wine merchant who are pawns in the games this Labor government is playing.

para.tab: I would also draw the Senate's attention to a paper prepared by Byron Sharp from the Elton Mayo School of Management of the University of South Australia. The paper states:

speech.para: It is now well accepted that domestic market conditions can have a substantial impact on the international competitiveness of an industry . . . The effect then, of an increase in the wholesale sales tax on wine has the potential to harm the international competitiveness of the Australian wine industry.
The paper goes on to state:

There is little doubt that reduced profitability and potential for profitability will result in scaled down investments in new vineyards and winery up-grades, with such action already foreshadowed by a number of wine industry spokespeople in post-budget commentaries. It is also highly likely that reduced revenue and profitability will result in reduced marketing budgets affecting, primarily, advertising and sales support spending, market research, the recruitment of marketing qualified staff and new product development budgets.
So this government, this anti-business government—and, frankly, it is becoming more anti-business by the day—has given another slug to an industry which is getting up and having a go.

para.tab: The government has brought in a budget which it knows is not acceptable to the Senate—and it knows it does not control the Senate. The government consults the ACTU about everything, but it never actually comes and talks too much to the Senate about things. However, the coalition, the Greens and the Democrats have all been asked by the government to capitulate, to keep the peace and keep the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) happy. Well, tough luck, fellas! This time we will actually look after an industry which is on the way up and having a go at looking after itself.

I cannot believe that the Labor Party is not receiving the sorts of letters that we are all receiving on this side of the chamber. We are receiving letters from builders, bankers, bakers, candlestick makers and self-funded retirees. Everyone is having a go about this budget. It worries me—as much as it does Senator Burns opposite, judging from the frown and the worry on his face—that it is hurting all those people for whom I know he has a bit of feeling. No-one has written to support the budget, and I bet the Labor Party has not received any fan mail about it either. The Labor Party, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and the Prime Minister are irresponsible in their efforts to cajole, beguile and wheedle their way around this chamber, trying to get through legislation that they know is flawed and will hurt an industry that is trying to help itself.

We do not need prima donnas running the country. We want a government which will get out there and help industries that are trying to come up with export programs. Why always knock somebody who is having a go? Why always knock an industry which is getting up off its feet, getting out and giving us an export income? Give Australia a fair go, let this extra tax that those opposite are talking about be defeated, and let them admit that they made a mistake in the first instance.

speech.speaker: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

talk.start.para: —Senator Margetts, as economics spokesperson, has already introduced the Greens (WA) assessment of the budget; I will be commenting on the social justice aspects. The government has proposed to achieve its twin objectives of reducing the deficit and cutting income taxes by increasing indirect taxes principally through increases to wholesale sales tax, which are covered by these bills, and excise rates on fuel and tobacco, which will be debated later.

para.tab: This is highly regressive because indirect taxes have a far greater impact on low income earners who consume a greater proportion of their income and are less able to respond to price increases. In addition, low income earners are more likely to own cars that require leaded petrol and live in outer suburbs, exacerbating the impact of fuel price increases. The hardest hit group is low income households which pay little or no tax and do not receive social security benefits, as these people will not benefit from the new tax rebate or the indexation of benefits. Therefore, this budget has proven to be very unpopular. The people of Australia feel abandoned by this government.

I give just a sample of the letters that are flooding into our office. They are personal letters, so I will quote from them rather than stating which people they come from. In part, a letter from New South Wales states:

speech.para: For far too long Australia has been governed by men in grey suits and economic rationalists, whose power comes from the almighty dollar and the stock market.

I believe that Australia has lived for far too long, from exploitation of our natural resources with no thought for our future. Where economic models are discussed without considering the effects on people.
A second letter, also from New South Wales—and I did select these at random—states:

The preoccupation of the last decade with economic rationalism at the expense of social, ethical and environmental factors has served this country of ours very badly. An even sadder aspect has been the fact that the brunt of the dislocating effects of these policies are being borne by those who are already disadvantaged compared to the norm whereas those bureaucrats and businesspeople who have pushed these inappropriate policies have probably been promoted and/or rewarded themselves with massive remuneration increases.

This budget is clearly regressive. Independent analysis suggests that low income households will generally suffer the losses. The worst hit group, as I mentioned earlier, is people on low incomes who are not on social security benefits and who have little or no tax liability. These people receive neither the income tax rebate paid in the following financial year nor the lagged CPI indexation of benefits.

para.tab: I will quote here from the Women's Economic Thinktank. Honourable senators on the benches beside me will be pleased to see that that organisation is fairly objective and it does agree that the government has put some good news in its budget. It states:

speech.para: . . . the good news, and there was some!

They kept some good promises on child care and the Arts; there are some initiatives for the unemployed, but not enough and there are small changes in social security, aged care and other areas which are going to be helpful. The problem is not the spending but the taxing.

They were right in their general strategy, they needed to do something about the budget deficit but they missed the plot completely in the way they tackled it. They used regressive strategies to raise taxes and cut programs, so the rich inevitably did better and those in the middle and lower middle income groups did badly.

The Government got caught in a trap between the rock of accumulated bad advice on reducing the deficit and the hard place of believing in cutting the size of the public sector and some silly election promises. So they tried to make an impossible balance by cuts in progressive personal taxes, giving the biggest dollar gains to top income earners and raising money through regressive sales taxes. Shades of Fightback, indeed!
That was the Women's Economic Thinktank.

talk.start.para: —That is absolute rubbish.
—I am glad Senator Patterson is hearing these comments. I do think Fightback has a lot to answer for, and its emulation by our current government is not a very good indicator.

para.tab: The modifications to the budget, such as dropping the last 3c per litre increase in the excise on leaded petrol, have attempted to lessen the regressive impact of the budget package. However, we remain concerned about the impact of the budget in years to come, in which the government has proposed further increases in wholesale sales tax and fuel excise rates, with no further measures to cushion the impact of these on low income households. We, the Greens, therefore, cannot commit ourselves to supporting the government's purported strategy which places the greatest burden on the poor, gives benefit to those who need it least and, in the final analysis, does not deliver the financial responsibility it trumpets.

The two senators for the Greens (WA) had planned to introduce four amendments or requests to the budget bills. Firstly—and this one will be considered in the committee stage of this debate—we propose dropping the second increase in wholesale sales tax proposed for July 1995. Secondly, we attempted yesterday to introduce a top-up tax of five per cent on incomes above $100,000 at the same time as the other income tax cuts were introduced—and, once again, it was the Greens and the Democrats against the rest. Thirdly, we would like to support the dropping of the proposed taxation of credit unions. That will be debated later. Fourthly, we supported the dropping of the link between the passage of the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 3) 1993 and the other so-called deficit reduction bills, which was referred to the other place yesterday as an indication of its lack of support.

None of these amendments would reduce government revenue or increase government expenditure commencing this financial year or next financial year. The second amendment, if we had succeeded in passing it into law, would actually have provided additional revenue.

We targeted the second increase in wholesale sales tax for four reasons. The first reason was to reduce the regressive impact that is the result of the shift from income taxes to indirect taxes and that is not compensated for by the tax cuts or rebate for low income earners. It confronts the government with the need to find more equitable ways of raising the additional revenue required to provide important public services and reduce public debt as part of its medium term deficit reduction strategy, such as it is.

Not legislating to increase wholesale sales tax a second one per cent in 1995 simply reinforces the need arising from the lack of funds to deal with the Mabo legislation and the labour market programs. It allows the government adequate time to investigate and implement these revenue measures. It also reduces the inflationary impact of the budget in years to come. This reduces the need to rely on monetary policy and increased interest rates for economic management. Over-reliance on high interest rates hurts consumers and small business and should be avoided.

Honourable senators will notice that there has been no mention of a wine tax. This is because it did not figure in a major way in our approach to the budget, partly because we knew it was being opposed by the opposition and the Democrats. The wine tax was a complex matter for the Greens. We received varying lobbies. I will again summarise the two aspects that are of concern to us that would have led us to support an increase in wine tax if we had responded to them. Those views deserve consideration, even though I will later tell honourable senators our reasons for not following them. In a letter from Kalamunda in Western Australia we were told:

speech.para: I don't agree with you on revoking the proposed sales tax on wine. The proposed increase from 20 to 31 per cent is not enough and should at least be doubled because of the long term cost of alcohol usage associated with social problems plus the short term financial cost of $6 billion a year nationally to Australian taxpayers. As a Greens Senator you should also be aware that the wine industry is a type of land developer, acquiring valuable land for the production of wine, especially clay-soil based wetlands which were and I am sure are still filled in for vineyard developments.

We will respond to the environmental concerns later. They represent one genuine concern about the wine industry. A second concern—which, I am sure, has also been referred to earlier—is the health impact of alcohol in our society. A letter from the WA branch of the Public Health Association of Australia states:
We believe that alcoholic beverages should be taxed according to their alcoholic content so favouring the substitution of lower alcohol variants for higher alcohol variants.

I would have to agree with this point. One of the pleasing aspects of opposing the wine tax is that we will also be opposing the increase in the tax on low alcohol wines at the same time. The letter further states:

This issue has raised the need for a comprehensive examination of taxation on alcoholic beverages, with a view to reducing overall alcohol related harm. Until such an examination can take place we believe that the current, highly favoured tax position enjoyed by wine producers would justify support of the proposed increased sales tax on wine.

That is another aspect of this quite complex debate. It was because of that complexity that, when we initially challenged this budget, we wanted to defer the wine sales tax pending an inquiry, with a result coming down in one year's time. We did this because of the impact of the proposed increase and the importance of the wine industry in terms of local employment and tourism. We wanted consideration of any increase deferred at least a year to enable a full inquiry and to allow opportunity for those people who expressed the concerns that I mentioned earlier on environmental, health grounds and social behaviour costs to be heard and responded to appropriately.

para.tab: As I said, we proposed an inquiry but because that has not been raised as an amendment to this bill we are planning to support a request for an amendment opposing the increase in wine tax that will be raised later in this place. Our reasons are as follows. We did not believe the government's claim that an increase in tax would actually help the industry to expand overseas, and we certainly knew that it would not help it locally. The claim was based on anecdotal evidence of what happened after the last increase in tax on wine from 10 per cent to 20 per cent, and I think the argument is tenuous.

We believe that the wine industry is significantly different from the rest of the alcoholic beverage industry, firstly, because it is largely Australian owned. There is some multinational and foreign ownership in the industry but this is significantly lower than in the beer industry, which is largely foreign owned, and the spirit industry, which is almost entirely import oriented. Secondly, it is regionally based, it is rurally based and provides significant employment and industry in the towns that service the wine growing areas. Thirdly, it is relatively labour intensive—people friendly, in fact. The industry provides high levels of employment on a seasonal basis and cannot become as automated as other sectors of agricultural industry, such as wheat farming. Fourthly, it has higher levels of stock holdings. The industry maintains stocks of wine for around 17 months, whereas the beer industry has a turnaround time of 43 days. This has a significant impact on the cash flow and capital investment required.

While we have some significant concerns about environmental problems in the industry, such as the use of herbicides and pesticides, these are not uncommon in any agricultural based industry and an increasing number of wine makers are modifying their practices to make them more environmentally sustainable. The wine industry is far more sustainable in terms of its use of land and the effects on the soil than most other agricultural pursuits. It is a high value added use of an agricultural product which draws in a wide variety of other industries to support it. The multiplier effect of the wine industry is possibly more significant to many regions of this country than any other.

Many tourism based enterprises throughout regional Australia rely on the wine industry. The Barossa Valley in South Australia, the Hunter Valley in New South Wales and the Margaret River region in Western Australia are three obvious and successful examples of this.

We are concerned about the public health aspects of increasing levels of consumption of wine, particularly by teenage girls, but we are concerned that an increase in revenue is not necessarily an ethical way of addressing that; neither is it effective in this case. The government needs to do more to stop this. However, a percentage increase in wine has less overall effect on the price of cheap wine bought in casks—that being the wine consumed by teenage girls—than higher priced wine. Therefore, a percentage increase in the price of wine is less of a deterrent to teenage drinkers than to other consumers. We need to avoid the double standard of condemning the detrimental effects of alcohol in our community, and then taxing it and gaining revenue from something we have condemned, without actually putting into place genuine preventive, educative and treatment oriented approaches to the problem.

There has been a lot of talk, as my colleague Senator Margetts remarked earlier, about certainty, the passage of bills and the role of the Senate. We have been criticised for not making commitments to pass the budget—lock, stock and barrel—long before the bills were on the table and able to be examined in detail. We agree that certainty is important, although it is by no means the only thing which is important. The one thing that everyone can be certain of is that we will not be supporting a grossly regressive budget—ever. A fax we received from Victoria pointed out some of the underlying concepts of the Senate that are being picked up by ordinary people in the community. It states:

speech.para: Like many Australians, I believe there was great wisdom in our "founding fathers" who created a States house—the Senate—and could foresee that without the natural controls imposed by honesty and propriety, a single house system of parliament would only represent one party, or perhaps only one strong and wrong leader.

Even if it is only coincidental that our Senate and our Senators were given such a powerful role, surely there has seldom been a more important time, for those who believe in personal and political integrity, to have legislation amended or rejected, providing it sends a clear signal to the government, and even if there is a double dissolution of Parliament as a consequence?

None of us really want a de-stabilised government or more political and economic uncertainty, (particularly when it has the potential to further distress the already disadvantaged, or delay economic recovery), but as every good doctor knows, sometimes the patient has to lose a limb to save a life. If making our elected governments more honest, accountable, and equitable falls on two Senators—
that is, with the support of the majority, seeing we cannot do anything on our own—
who act in the national interest, so be it, and so much the better will be our political system.

We have always said that we would support an equitable strategy to reduce the government deficit in the medium term in a way that does not undermine the government's revenue base. The current package of budget bills fails these two tests. We acknowledge the government's attempts to lessen the regressive impact of this financial year's increases in fuel excise and wholesale sales tax. While these are not perfect, they are acceptable.

para.tab: We are not willing, however, to accept the second increase in wholesale sales tax because of its regressive impact. That is why, as we have foreshadowed, we will make a request for the legislation to be amended in the committee stage of this debate. Why should we vote now to increase wholesale sales tax rates from July 1995 when the government does not intend to legislate to ameliorate the gross negative effect of those increases on particular sectors of our community at the same time?

If the government wants our support in respect of legislating to increase any tax, it must at the same time introduce measures to reduce the impact on those sectors of our community which can least afford it. Unless this regressive impact is reduced, the government can be certain that we will not vote for any bill containing increases in wholesale sales tax beyond the one per cent rate increase that is already being collected but is not yet law.

speech.speaker: Ellison Sen C.M.

talk.start.para: —My comments will only be brief, as I realise there are other speakers to come, and it is most important that this matter is resolved today. I rise to speak on behalf of the wine industry in Western Australia and to voice my opposition to the increase in the tax on wine. Much has been said about the national situation, so I will not traverse that ground again.

para.tab: Many small wine producers in Western Australia will suffer disastrous effects should this increase come into effect. The industry in Western Australia is a fledgling industry and, as Senator Margetts pointed out, it is largely locally owned. I will not go over the positive aspects of the industry, as mentioned by Senator Chamarette some time ago, other than to say that a winegrower has to wait some five to seven years before realising a vintage and some 15 years before breaking even.

During my visit to the south-west region of Western Australia, in particular the Margaret River region, it was demonstrated to me that the wine industry is quite a tough rural industry. What concerns me about the industry is not so much the price of wine; it is the effect that the increase in price will have on that industry which, in turn, will affect unemployment. Mr Bruce Tomlinson, the President of the Margaret River Wine Industry Association, in a recent letter to me, wrote:

speech.para: . . . bottled wine produced by the regional boutique slice of the wine industry as a whole has created employment out of all proportion to volume produced.
