Not only the permanent jobs and seasonal picking, pruning and cellar sale jobs, but the consequential jobs in tourism and transport, in schools reopened through the rejuvenation of our region, through chalets and restaurants and the service industry—

There we have the full flow-on of this most beneficial industry. The Margaret River area has become a showcase for tourism in Western Australia and has demonstrated how development can be environmentally sustained. The wine industry employs a youth work force. Some 80 per cent of its employees are young people. Any cutback in the industry could leave them unemployed.

talk.start.para: —There is already high unemployment there.

—That is right. As Senator Panizza pointed out, there is already very high youth unemployment and this would only exacerbate the situation. It was therefore disappointing to see in an editorial in the
Australian
of 5 October this year a case put for the increase in the tax on wine. The editorial stated that the impact on exports would be minimal.

para.tab: The case was put to me by the small winegrowers of Western Australia that 15 to 20 per cent of their produce is exported and that the remainder is consumed by the domestic market. We cannot export unless we have shored up ourselves at home and unless we have increased our domestic production; then we can go offshore. That is the problem that these small winegrowers will face. In order for the industry to become a large exporter, it firstly has to consolidate at home. At present, the annual production of wine in Western Australia is worth some $60 million a year. I urge the Senate to oppose this increase in the tax on wine so that that industry can be left alone to develop and, in the future, to bring home to Australia hundreds of millions of dollars of export earnings.

I also advise the Senate that, since this measure was talked about on 17 August this year, there has been some feedback. Mr Tomlinson, whom I mentioned previously, has advised that sales in the Margaret River area alone are already down by 20 to 25 per cent. Winegrowers are discovering that restaurateurs are not buying wine; they are holding on to present stocks and they want to see what exactly will happen with this increase in the tax on wine.

Market research in Western Australia has shown that there are two psychological barriers in price: one is $10 and one is $15. The majority of the market tends to buy bottled wine under the value of $10. This increase in tax will push those prices up so that a bottle of wine, which was previously under the value of $10, would then go over that psychological barrier and a share of the market will be lost. The small wine producers do not have the economy of scale that the larger ones have and they have overheads which could force them into the higher brackets of the market price and thereby cause them loss in the market share. The flow-on from that is obvious: a loss of jobs, as I have mentioned, and a loss of support to tourism in the areas which I have mentioned.

The increase in the tax on wine will be disastrous for Western Australian winegrowers. They cannot be compared with multinational brewers or distillers. They are only small businessmen who are trying to make a go of things and who are in the process of bringing some great benefits not only to their state but also the country at large. There is absolutely no comparison between the money that we will get by increasing the tax on wine and the benefit. By increasing the tax on wine we will be kicking an industry whilst it is still growing, and that is just untenable.

With those points in mind, I urge fellow senators to oppose this increase in the tax on wine. I endorse the comments made by the Green senators in relation to this matter as it pertains to Western Australia. I reiterate that this will have a disastrous effect on winegrowers in the state which I represent.

talk.start.para: —The sales tax bills that are before the Senate represent a part of the government's overall budget strategy. They are not just a tax increase but part of a comprehensive approach to the obvious need to reduce the deficit and provide services to the people.

para.tab: Australians have been continually told by the opposition and its friends in the media that this budget is purely about increasing taxation. This is not the case. This budget is not just about reducing the deficit. It is also about maintaining the standards of education and further improving them; providing training places and furthering our attack on unemployment; and continuing our support for the underprivileged in society and our commitment to social justice. All of this is set in place, yet all those in the opposition can talk about is an increase in the price of wine.

The five sales tax bills that make up this package which is before the Senate represent the government's belief that there needs to be a small general increase in the level of sales tax. There will be tax cuts and support given to low income earners. Under the legislation, there will be a modest general increase in sales tax of one per cent and a later increase of one per cent. There will also be other targeted increases in sales tax.
The bills before us increase the tax on wine and cider as well as on in situ pools. There is also a further bill which will provide for a split rate in the tax on luxury vehicles.

I will deal first with the wine tax. I am sick of being told that, as a South Australian, I must oppose the increase in the sales tax on wine. I am very proud of the South Australian wine industry; I patronise the industry and promote it whenever I can. There is no doubt that my state produces the best wines in Australia and in the world. The industry has gone from strength to strength—not because of the low tax regime but because it is a quality product that has been marketed well. The key to success is a good product.

The wine industry has been very lucky not to have borne a higher sales tax level earlier. Wine is an alcoholic beverage, and we must maintain standards and consistency in our taxation of such products. Even under the changes, beer and spirits will be taxed much more than wine because of the excise on beer and spirits.

There must be a balance. The government recognises the importance of the wine industry at domestic and export levels. But there cannot be such a large disparity. Wine will only be taxed at the domestic level. This taxation increase of 11 per cent will only be imposed on sales in Australia. There will be no excise on wine. This should not affect the price overseas.

Anyone would think from the propaganda that the wine industry will be destroyed by the increases in price at the domestic level. I believe that if there is a drop in sales it will be because the wine industry has publicised the increases so well. The extra cost of a bottle of wine would be around 50c for a $10 bottle. The different prices at different bottle shops, pubs and restaurants means that people pay a wide variety of prices for wine anyway.

I know that if I go out to a modestly priced restaurant in Canberra I will pay twice as much for a certain bottle of wine than I would pay at my local pub. A glass of wine at a nightclub costs much more than a glass of wine at a hotel. And after 9 p.m. it costs even more. Would ordinary Australians who have the occasional bottle or cask notice this increase? I very much doubt it. I certainly would not.

It is also disappointing to see the massive campaign being organised by the wine industry. A number of constituents have said to me that the wine industry cannot be too broke if it can spend all that money on a campaign. This seems like even more of a waste when one considers that the government has put proposals to it which would stagger the tax increase and other compensation. These proposals have been rejected out of hand. The government is still willing to sit down and discuss these issues with the industry.

The opposition continually refers to the 55 per cent increase in the rate of sales tax on wine. Talk about twisting the use of statistics! This is like saying that if a lolly goes up from 1c to 2c it represents an increase of 100 per cent. Of course it is mathematically correct, but it gives the impression that the increase is more severe than it is in reality. This is sensationalising the issue. The overall increase in the price of wine and cider will be 12 per cent by 1995.

It is also interesting to note that the Greens have become opponents of the wine tax. Surely some balancing of the taxes on alcohol would be seen as fair by those honourable senators. Or is this an indication of their personal drinking preferences? Perhaps self-interest is involved.

I also wish to mention my support for the changes to sales tax on luxury vehicles. The Sales Tax Assessment Amendment (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 aims to provide for a reduction in the taxable value of luxury vehicles by a proportion of the motor vehicle depreciation limit. This will have the effect of having split sales tax rates on luxury cars. Currently, when a vehicle exceeds the depreciation limit by a small amount it is taxed at the higher rate of 30 per cent.

The new regime will see that the component of a passenger luxury vehicle less than the depreciation limit will be taxed at 16 per cent, and 17 per cent in 1995. For other luxury vehicles, this rate will be 21 per cent, and 22 per cent in 1995. The part of the price of the vehicle that exceeds the depreciation limit will be taxed at the new rate of 45 per cent, with no change in 1995. This will see those with particularly expensive cars paying more and those who were marginally over the limit paying a more reasonable amount.

The budget must be passed by this Senate. In another place, government ministers sit on treasury benches for a reason. They are responsible to the people. We have the mandate and we must be able to use it. The government has to worry about the big picture. It must be able to provide the services that it is committed to providing. We have our constituency and we must work towards achieving the goals of our party in the interests of our nation. The environment, sport, health, social security, support for the elderly, employment, education, training and a whole range of other areas need the financial support of government. We have a responsibility to raise revenue to fund our initiatives in the way that we see fit.

The Australian Democrats have shown over the years that they will be reasonable about most matters. I only hope that the Greens also will come to their senses. I understand that the Greens want to be famous. But there are more important issues with which we must contend. Opposition members must also stop playing games and try to act like members of an alternative government rather than as spoilers.

The conventions broken by the opposition, in its opposing major sections of this budget package, and its bitterness because it lost the election, has created much unnecessary bad blood in this place. People in the community are getting the idea that the Senate is where the problems of the parliamentary process lie. It is very difficult to tell the good people of South Australia that this is not the case. I commend the bills to the Senate and I hope that the measures contained within them are allowed to proceed.

talk.start.para: —I also rise to speak against the 55 per cent increase in the sales tax. I remind Senator Foreman that an increase is an increase is an increase.
—You know how to do your mathematics.

—I do indeed. The domestic price of Australian wine is set to rise by a minimum of 10 per cent, and there will be a corresponding drop in domestic sales. Wine companies will suffer a diminution of their domestic market and therefore a contraction of their export plans.

para.tab: I point out that in New Zealand, despite excellent export potential, there has been no new investment for the last five years. That is because the government there has imposed regressive tax measures. Today, New Zealand is Australia's second largest market for wine exports as New Zealand simply cannot produce sufficient wine to meet its domestic and export requirements.

I particularly wish to speak about the impact on rural and regional Australia, where the imposition of this tax would be another body blow for the battlers in small businesses and rural enterprises. There are 600 small winemakers in rural and regional Australia and every single one of them will be affected by the imposition of this tax.

This is more than just an increase in the price of a bottle of wine. This tax is not only an attack on the export industry but it will also impact on rural and regional economies, particularly regarding the seasonal employment of rural workers, especially women. There are very few other sources of seasonal employment for people who live in the vineyard areas and there are very few other opportunities to augment the family income.

I will mention two vineyards in Victoria of which I have had particular experience, namely, the Drumborg vineyard near Heywood, which employs between 70 and 80 pickers, mainly female, during the season, and the Crawford River vineyard, located slightly to the north of that in Condah, which employs between 20 and 30 pickers, also mainly women. This scenario is repeated across rural Victoria and Australia, especially in the areas of the Pyrenees and the Yarra Valley. Most smaller wineries tend to be labour intensive—that is, they use less machinery—and any fall in volume from this type of vineyard will have a disproportionately high effect on employment. The South Australian Centre for Economic Studies has estimated that the effect of the sales tax will be a 3.6 per cent decline in sales in the short term for smaller wineries and up to 11.8 per cent in the long term. Such a decline may make their operations unsustainable and therefore they will all lose their jobs.

It is important to realise that other industry sectors in rural and regional Australia also contribute to the momentum of the wine industry. I am thinking particularly of timber and forestry industries, which contribute such things as posts and trellises. Sawmills are also associated with that sort of activity. The machinery and equipment suppliers of bore and irrigation equipment are already suffering from the rural recession. They do not need another body blow like this. The fabricated metal manufacturers and, as my colleague Senator Sandy Macdonald pointed out, the tourism industry, in which the vineyards play an integral part, are also affected. The construction industry generally is also concerned.

During the last couple of months Senator Kemp and I visited the Mitchelton winery near Nagambie. They assured us that if this tax goes ahead they will be contracting a very large amount of their investment potential that they had hoped to put into new areas over the next year. We would not want to have this happen across the rest of Victoria and the rest of Australia.

All the industries I have mentioned have significant inputs to the wine industry and they are all part of the interlocking employment-production-investment network so typical of rural and regional Australia. The wine industry is a rural based, high value adding, technologically superior, sustainably internationally competitive and well organised industry. I would have thought that this was exactly what we were trying to encourage. I believe that the government should abandon this regressive measure and that it should treat the wine industry as a national treasure, as other civilised countries do, and not as a tax cow. I urge honourable senators to vote against this measure.

speech.speaker: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

talk.start.para: —What we are debating is a package of five bills which, in generic terms, is referred to as the sales tax deficit reduction package. That title carries two important messages with it in this debate. Firstly, it is a package. Secondly, it is a package that is an integral part of an economically responsible deficit reduction policy. It is very important that in the context of considering economic measures such as these we consider the economic implications not only of acting in a certain way but also of failing to act. There has been a fair bit of dwelling on the history of who said what and to whom about what the Senate should do.

para.tab:
Let us have a look at the economics of the implications of the Senate failing to act responsibly and pass these measures. In the September 1993 edition of its
World Economic Outlook
document the International Monetary Fund made some comments that were not particularly related to Australia, but related to western economies as a whole. I will refer to only two sections of that document. Firstly it stated:

speech.para: A failure to reduce substantially these imbalances—
by that it means budget imbalances—

over the medium term would likely cause renewed upward pressure on long term interest rates, reduce capital formation and the scope for new job creation in the private sector, lower the rate of growth of a potential output and income, and continue to impede the flexibility of fiscal policy in the event of adverse cyclical developments.

What that is essentially saying is that it is all very well to take a nitpicking little sectional responsibility and say, `There are a few people in this suburb, a few people who live near that town, who might vote for me if I oppose this tax bill'. Tax bills are always unpopular. There has never been a popular tax increase. Everybody thinks the government needs to fund services, but nobody welcomes the fact that the taxes on them will be increased. That is hardly surprising.

para.tab: Nevertheless, what the IMF is saying is that if we take that nitpicking industry-by-industry, town-by-town, vote-by-vote, opinion-poll-driven approach, we will in the long term significantly adversely affect the people whom, as the rhetoric would have it, we are seeking to assist. We are talking about the pressure on interest rates, which is much worse for any of the industries than a very small increase in sales tax. We are talking about the reduced capacity for job creation which is much more fundamental in the overall economic situation. The overall job possibility for the unemployed, those coming into the labour market and those seeking to re-enter the labour market is much more fundamental than the impact of any particular regional or industry measure. It has significant long-term effects in lowering the rate of growth in output.
The second point the IMF made was this:

speech.para: As recent experience in several countries shows, early announcement and legislation of credible medium term deficit reduction measures have immediate beneficial effects on long term interest rates and on economic confidence, even when recessionary conditions make it difficult to undertake significant deficit cuts in the short run.
. . . postponing action to deal with the fiscal imbalances would continue to impede a recovery of confidence.

That describes exactly the situation in which Australia finds itself. Even though, as we recover all too slowly from the recession, we need to increase the deficit this year to provide more stimulus, to generate more jobs, at the same time we need to announce that over the medium term we will be reducing the deficit so that the long-term job potential is generated, the potential for growth is maximised and the long-term advantage of Australia is enhanced. That is what we are sent here to do.

para.tab:
It is all very well to make populist appeals to an industry in a particular state or electorate. It is all very well to make simple populist appeals against any tax increase. That is exactly what led the United States into the budget gridlock it now has. There was an interesting sentence in an
Economist
editorial recently. It said that the hardest thing for anybody in government to do was to be tough on taxes, particularly to raise taxes to cut the budget deficit. That is the test of one's mettle. That is the test of whether one has what it takes to be a responsible government.

Do we recognise that it is necessary to do something because it is right, even if it is unpopular? The Senate is being put to the test with regard to that matter right now. That is probably why Malcolm Fraser, of all people, said:
The present course—

speech.para: he is talking about the Senate's present course—

will do significant damage to the governmental and constitutional processes of Australia and will give the Senate power beyond that which was envisaged by our founding fathers. It will give minority parties an influence beyond their electoral support.

para.tab: At the end, it will depend on the respect that Senate members have for the institution of which they are a part. What is more important—protecting the institution, and its value to Australian democracy, or conducting a guerilla campaign against the Government's Budget?

speech.para: That is the context in which we are dealing with this matter. I also want to deal with some questions about the equity of the tax changes. Some rhetoric that was very familiar to me came from those saying that these are not equitable measures, because that is what we were saying in the last election about the GST. They failed to appreciate the difference between the GST and the wholesale sales tax.

para.tab: It was said correctly that all the evidence is, as logic obviously would argue, that lower income groups spend a higher proportion of their income and save less than upper income groups. That is why a GST is unfair because everything is taxed. Therefore, those who consume a higher proportion of their income pay tax on a higher proportion of their income.

In terms of the wholesale sales tax, that is very deliberately, as a matter of conscious policy, not so. The necessities of life are not subject to the wholesale sales tax. Broadly described, food and clothing are not subject to the wholesale sales tax; nor are things like electricity, water and those other basic necessities which make up a disproportionate part of the expenditure pattern of lower income groups. Senator Margetts' little anecdote was absolutely right when she spoke about the percentage of income that is spent on groceries, which is a correct description of the different pressure that is put on budgets by spending on the necessities. The difficulty for her is that those things are not subject to the wholesale sales tax, even though they would have been subject to the GST.

talk.start.para: —Packaged food; processed food; it's all there.

—It does not tax food and Senator Margetts knows that it does not. As a matter of conscious policy, it distorts the pattern of imposition of wholesale sales tax on those things that are disproportionately purchased by upper income people.

para.tab: One of the ironies is that in the name of equity it is proposed to oppose a tax increase on swimming pools. It is very hard to argue in the interests of equity that the tax on swimming pools should not go up. One can see the poor and underprivileged in tears about the increase in tax on swimming pools, but that is what is being argued in the name of equity. What a farce!

It is equally farcical to argue the case about wine. Quintessentially, wine should be subject to indirect tax because upper income people spend more of their income on it than lower income people, and they buy more expensive items than lower income people. There is a much higher level of tax paid by upper income people than lower income people, but in the interests of equity some people are proposing to oppose this increase.

It is true that the wine industry is important and the government is engaged in discussions with the industry about industry assistance. But it does not make sense to use an inequitable tax measure to subsidise an industry when we could generate the revenue through an equitable tax measure and spend as much of it as is needed on industry assistance.

The other thing that needs to be assessed in looking at the equity of the tax changes is the context of the government's record. Over the past 10 years the priority has been to assist lower income individuals and families. This has been achieved by the way the tax cuts have been targeted, by the way the welfare measures have been introduced and targeted and now by the introduction and—by agreement with the Democrats—the increase in the tax rebate for low income people. But on this occasion, after 10 years of focusing those measures on lower income people—properly so—this time the bulk of the personal tax cuts are quite deliberately targeted at middle Australia who have not benefited as much from the previous tax cuts. In my view, so they should be.

What we are faced with here is the circumstance in which honourable senators are being tested. Senators are elected to discharge national responsibilities; that is, to look beyond the short term interest and beyond the popular to what is right and appropriate in the national interest. Everybody in this chamber knows that the deficit reduction strategy is in the national interest. Some people know it and will vote against it, but the responsible people know it and will vote for it.

We do not need opinion polls to tell us that people would rather not have tax increases. We know what would be popular in the short term, but we know what is right in the national interest. It will be interesting to test who will vote for it and who will vote against it. I commend the bills to the Senate.
Question put:
Question so resolved in the negative.

speech.para: At the end of the motion, add:

para.tab: ", but the Senate:
(a)condemns the Government for including in the bill measures which jeopardise the future of Australia's wine industry;
(b)calls on the Government to abandon the measures imposing increases in sales tax on wine;
(c)condemns the Government for continuing policies which put at risk the livelihoods of Australians in rural communities, this time seeking to impose increased sales tax on wine; and
(d)calls on the Government to negotiate with Australia's winemakers for a comprehensive wine industry development plan to safeguard the future of the wine industry".
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The committee is considering five sales tax bills. It has been suggested that we take three of them together—the Sales Tax (Customs) (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993, the Sales Tax (Excise) (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 and the Sales Tax (General) (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993. There being no objection, it is so ordered.

para.tab: The bills.

speech.speaker: Short Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —So far as the expeditious consideration of the amendments that have been circulated is concerned, I think the Democrats and the opposition have identical amendments to each of the three bills that we are now taking together. The Democrats have some amendments which basically duplicate ours in some respects but not in others.
—Yours were in different form when we had to put ours in.

—That is right. I point out for the benefit of the chamber that I had circulated yesterday a revised set of the amendments that I had earlier circulated. So for each of these three bills the committee should be looking at a one-page amendment sheet with `revised' at the top of it.
—Unless it is otherwise stated, would it be satisfactory if we regarded each of these amendments as applying to each of the three bills before us?

—Yes. The nine opposition amendments are identical for each of the three bills we are now considering. If it suits the convenience of the committee, it may be easier to look at them together, in that sense.

para.tab: I also suggest a bracketing of the amendments for consideration because some of them relate to the imposition of the sales tax on wine, some relate to the first sales tax increase of one per cent and some relate to the second sales tax increase of one per cent. Of the nine amendments circulated by the opposition, amendments Nos 4 and 8 relate to the wine tax, amendments Nos 3, 5, 6 and 7 relate to the first of the sales tax increases and amendments Nos 1, 2 and 9 relate to the second increase. If it were considered convenient, we could deal with each block as we come to it.

talk.start.para: —I agree with that.
—by leave—In those circumstances, I move:

para.tab: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:
(4) Schedule 1, page 3, paragraphs 4(b) and (c), omit the paragraphs.
(8) Schedule 1, pages 3 and 4, paragraphs 7(c) and (e), omit the paragraphs.

speech.para: We have had a very long and full second reading debate on these issues. We also had a full debate which was relevant to these bills in the context of the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 3) yesterday. I do not propose to reiterate the remarks that we have made other than to say that, so far as the government's proposal to put a massive 55 per cent increase onto the sales tax on wine is concerned, I think there are few people in Australia, other than those in the government, who believe that that will not do great damage to an industry which, to use Senator Kernot's words, is on the cusp of a major development, particularly so far as exports are concerned.

para.tab: Putting this tax on wine, although it does not apply to exports, will have an enormous impact on the domestic side of the industry in terms of production and sale and consumption. That, in turn, will have a major, debilitating, very damaging effect not only on the domestic side of the industry but, just as importantly—more importantly in some respects, if one looks at our national needs in terms of exports and our balance of payments crisis with foreign debt exceeding $200,000 million—on the international side. Taking it all together, it is an impost of enormous impact which would be very devastating and very damaging to the industry. There is no way that we as a parliament should be prepared to allow through a measure which we know is going to be so devastating. It is for those reasons that I move those amendments.

I will not say any more about the amendments specifically other than to pick up very briefly on a comment made by Senator McMullan when closing the second reading debate. I will just lay to rest another furphy that Senator McMullan and this government have been propounding for some considerable time—ever since the budget, indeed. It is the proposition that these taxes are absolutely integral—I think he used the word `integral'—to the government's overall macro-economic strategy.

talk.start.para: —I didn't, but it is right.

—That is patently incorrect. What we are talking about with the totality of these bills is something approaching one and a half per cent of the government's total revenue collections for this financial year. Sure, it builds in the future, but there is every scope and every opportunity for the government to so rearrange the rest of the huge totality of its fiscal policies, both on the expenditure and on the revenue side, as to be able to cater for that very simply.

para.tab: I can cite no better authority as to the non-vitalness, if you like, of these bills than the current Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans. In 1981, with the parties on opposite sides of the chamber, he participated in a similar debate when the then Fraser Government was attempting to pass sales tax bills. At that time, Senator Evans made it absolutely clear, in a very good second reading speech, that there is no moral, conventional or other requirement or expectation on oppositions not to oppose bills of this nature. They are non-survival bills, to use Senator Evans's words at that time. There is no reason at all why, if they are bad bills, bad law, bad policy, the Senate should not oppose them. These bills are bad law; they are bad policy; and they are very damaging. For that reason, we have no hesitation at all in requesting these amendments.

speech.speaker: Lees Sen M.H.

talker.name: Senator LEES
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

talk.start.para: —The Democrats will be supporting these requests. As has already been outlined

speech.para: by Senator Short, they are identical to th requests we had circulated yesterday. The Democrats will be supporting them because we believe, firstly, that the question of whether or not there will be damage to the wine industry has been proven beyond doubt: there will be damage. The only thing left to debate is the extent of that damage. Even some of the government speakers have acknowledged that there will indeed be damage to the wine industry.

para.tab: However, when we come to budget strategy, we do not believe there will be any major impact on the major thrust of this budget strategy or, indeed, on the total amount of revenue collected. It is very interesting to note that the government, in its continuing negotiations with the wine industry over the last few days—indeed, over the last couple of weeks—has basically acknowledged that it is prepared, in the short term, to live with no additional income from the wine industry. Therefore, the Democrats do not have any problem, as far as the deficit reduction strategy goes, in opposing this measure.

talk.start.para: —Along with Senator Short, I take this opportunity to lay to rest a few untruths before we finish this debate. Senator Foreman said that those on this side of the chamber spoke only on the wine tax. That is totally incorrect; I can guarantee that at least 90 per cent of my short delivery of 10- to 12-odd minutes related to the approximately $915 million—nearly $1 billion—of other sales tax that will result in the next full financial year. The wine tax accounts for only about $85 million in a full year. So let me put that to rest. Those on the other side of the chamber seem to have a bit of trouble with mathematics. Again, it might have been Senator Foreman who insisted that it was a rise of only 11 per cent.
—It was Senator McKiernan.

—Senator McKiernan also has trouble with mathematics. I thought it was simple arithmetic, because the rate in the dollar is increasing from 20 per cent to 31 per cent—the 11 per cent increase. For the simple-minded on the other side of the chamber, it is divided by 20 and multiplied by 100; without using a calculator, even without writing it down on the back of a stamp, it comes out at 55 per cent. Even Senator McMullan, who is feigning disbelief at what I am saying, will find it correct if he can be bothered to work it out.

para.tab: Senator McMullan in his delivery—he ignored my interjections—said that our proposed GST applied to everything. That is wrong; that is a lie. At the time, we certainly exempted food and other things from our proposed GST.
Finally, the government has used a totally wrong description of this bill. I do not know who came up with the name `deficit reduction bill', but I think it is—

talk.start.para: —It might have been if we were not changing every bit of it.

—I thought it might have been better described as a bill designed to pay off the government's bankcard bill. That is all it is, because the deficit was raised by this government. The government told us during the lead-up to the election that there would be no new taxes, no increased taxes. I still say that the government should find better ways of cutting the deficit. It should cut the deficit by cutting irresponsible government spending.

—I have a number of questions to put to the minister. It might be convenient for the minister to answer them one by one rather than wait until he gives his final address. Could the minister tell the chamber who in the industry—either an association or an individual producer—was consulted before the government position was firmed up and the announcement made? Is it correct that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Simon Crean, was not consulted and did not know about this particular move before the government announced it?

para.tab:
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)
—The question is that the requests be agreed to.

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

talk.start.para: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I take your hint that the question has nothing to do with the motion before us, and essentially it has not. The question is also to do with what process the government went about in developing its budget. I have absolutely no intention of explaining now to whom we spoke, from whom we got advice or whatever in the development of the budget. Nobody ever has; Senator Spindler did not really expect me to, and I am not going to.

—The minister's response confirms what I believe is general knowledge: the government did not consult the wine industry before making its announcement. On a related point, is the minister aware of statements which have been made by a number of government spokespersons that a drop in domestic wine consumption—it is forecast to be in the order of nine per cent—could not really be made up for by exports? We are talking about high premium quality wines for export and, largely, a different quality of grapes is grown for domestic consumption, although there is some overlap. I also ask the minister whether the government is prepared to institute a process to develop an industry plan for the wine industry in the months following this parliamentary session. In other words, is the government prepared to hold an industry inquiry to determine what needs to be done to establish an industry plan which will improve the position and the future of the wine industry?

—Unfortunately, because of the drop off in the list of speakers I did not speak during the second reading debate, but I feel obliged to speak now to indicate to colleagues in the chamber why I propose to vote against the motion moved by Senator Short. I do so because I believe that, in the long term, this action will jeopardise the wine industry. I say that because, unlike beer and spirits, wine and cider are not subject to excise. If we adopt this motion and it is rejected by the House of Representatives, the government has indicated that the excise exemption currently applying to the wine industry will be looked at. In fact, if I understood his statement correctly, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) is considering looking at ways and means of applying the excise to the wine industry.
—He cannot do that.

—That is another argument for another time. Timing is involved there. Certain things can be done that at a later stage this chamber could disallow. That gets into a whole range of arguments and discussions that I think we have had before on one occasion or another.

para.tab: There is about $14 excise per litre of alcohol on beer, and regular beer contains about five per cent of alcohol and light beer, say, 2.5 per cent. There is about twice the excise on a can of full strength beer as there is on a can of light beer. I had hoped this would be discussed at the committee stage, because I wanted to make the point that what the government is doing here has a number of problems.

Let me come back to the first point. I believe that adopting Senator Short's proposal does not enable the committee to get into the meat of the proposition put forward by the government. If we did get into the meat of the proposition I believe we would see that it increases the percentage of tax on low alcohol wines to a greater extent than it increases the tax on full strength wine. That is not a good thing. As the explanatory memorandum says, the government is increasing from 20 per cent to 31 per cent the tax on wines that do not have a low alcohol content, but for those that do it is increasing the tax from 10 to 21 per cent. I do not have my calculator handy, but anybody would realise that that is a greater increase on sales tax on low alcohol wines than it is on full strength wines.

talk.start.para: —A 110 per cent increase.

—Yes. To me this is a problem, at all events, and perhaps at some stage the government should have a good look at that. There are other aspects of this measure that we could have discussed in the committee stage—for example, the propositions that have been put up about door sales not being subject to the increase in tax, and perhaps having a volume threshold for a particular producer below which this increase would not apply. All of those things will not now be able to be subject to propositions put forward in the committee stage because there is not much point in doing so.

para.tab: The opposition has indicated that it will press ahead with its requests to the House of Representatives that there be no increase at all in sales taxes on wines. It appears that will be agreed to by the Democrats and the Greens, so there really is not much point in pursuing this. But I do ask the government to consider that in the event the whole issue is considered in the House of Representatives again, not necessarily on this occasion but on some future occasion.

I reiterate my concern that the measures that are being proposed by the opposition will, in the long term, have the effect of exposing the industry to excise action or some other action that a government in the future will impose upon the industry to redress what does appear, on the face of it, clearly to be an unfair advantage to the wine industry over, for example, the beer industry.
As to people being consulted, that is a valid point. I remind the committee that beer drinkers, for example, have had to cop rise after rise and very little has been said about it.

talk.start.para: —It's probably a cultural thing.
—Well—
—I am not disagreeing with you.

—I understand the points that have been made in the debate, not least about the fiscal time lapse and the cash flow availability in the beer industry as compared with the wine industry, but the bottom line is: what is the consumer paying? The bottom line is that the consumer of beer, which is generally of much lesser alcohol strength than wine, is paying something like double the taxation that a wine drinker is paying. I think that is unfair. I suppose future governments will think that is unfair too.

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

talk.start.para: —I will not delay the committee long because we did traverse all these issues in the second reading debate, and I will not recapitulate them. I want to comment only on some new things that have been said.

para.tab: I think Senator Short finally made clear what the essential underlying political rationale of the opposition strategy is. It has always been clear to those of us who have been observing it closely but not publicly. He said that the measures overall—and he was not talking just about the wine tax; he was talking about these amendments overall—over the three years will cost us about $4 billion.

talk.start.para: —I didn't say that at all.

—But Senator Short knows it is correct. He said that it would cost us up to $1.5 billion a year by 1996-97, et cetera. My point is that what Senator Short did say was that we have the scope in subsequent budgets to come up with new measures to revisit such a deficit problem as this causes. That was the essence of the point made. I do not want to argue about the numbers, although the numbers are right.

para.tab: The point that is now apparent publicly, which has always been apparent to me, is that the opposition's real concern is that if these revenue measures pass and the government's medium term deficit reduction strategy is put in place as a result of this legislation, we will not have to bring in the sorts of punitive taxes in the budgets close to the election that the opposition would like to see us bring in, so that it can score political points about it closer to the election. That is a gloriously irresponsible matter.

talk.start.para: —Tax the rich; it's easy.
—Senator Margetts is opposing the measures that do. She does not even want to tax swimming pools.
—Who said?

—We will see. The circumstance is simply that the IMF makes it quite clear that it is important not just that we live year by year but that we map out a medium term deficit reduction strategy. I am pleased to have that on the record.

para.tab: Senator Spindler raised some questions about a plan—an inquiry. I did not respond then because it seemed to be more of a speech to which I might respond now. The government has made its position clear: if the industry is prepared to talk to us, we are happy to talk to it. At the moment it is pursuing what I think is a very short-sighted policy that is against its own interests. I happen to share Senator Harradine's assessment—not every dot and comma of the things he said, but the broad assessment—that this is not a measure that is in the long-term interests of the wine industry. I think some people are pursuing it for whatever reasons. I am sure that they believe they are doing the right thing; I think they are not.

Senator Harradine traversed some other interesting options. As he said, they really do not relate to the motion before us. But, broadly, they are interesting, and they are matters that the government will need to consider in the future in its taxation of this whole area.

What Senator Harradine did make clear was that we are not here talking about an equity measure at all. The equity is quite clearly in favour of this motion; the redistribution of income is quite clearly in favour of this measure. It is a tax measure that will tax the wealthy much more than lower income earners. But the people who come in here spouting equity will oppose it for reasons to do with the local politics of South Australia and Western Australia. That is fair enough, but I just wish we would not pretend that we are being pious when we are being opportunist. That is all.
Question put:
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I seek a point of clarification. Prior to the counting of the last division you ordered that the bells be rung for one minute only. Senators obviously had left the chamber and were as far as the stairs, and I know that two of my colleagues missed the division for that reason. I would like you to give us clarification of when you have the bells rung for one minute and when you do not.
—For the last division the bells rang for four minutes.
—No, for the previous one.
—The previous one was in the full Senate, not in committee, and the President was in the chair at that time. You might like to put your request to the President.

speech.speaker: Short Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:

speech.para: (3)Schedule 1, page 3, paragraph 4(a), omit the paragraph.
(5)Schedule 1, page 3, omit the item, substitute the following item:

para.tab:
"5.
Schedule 3
:
Omit from subitem 1(1) `Schedule 5', substitute `Schedule 6'.".

speech.para: (6)Schedule 1, page 3, omit the item, substitute the following item:

para.tab:
