Schedule 4
:

speech.para: Omit from item 1 `and 5', substitute `,5 and 6'.".
(7)Schedule 1, page 3, paragraph 7(a), omit the paragraph (a).

A couple of these amendments are very minor, being consequential upon others in terms of changing the numbering and so on. Collectively, they seek to remove the first of the two one per cent increases in sales tax that are contained in the bill. I will not speak at any length on these amendments, other than to say that this increase in sales tax, this first tranche, means a 10 per cent increase in sales tax on a very wide range of goods for which the existing rate of sales tax is 10 per cent, for example, and a lesser percentage increase for those goods where the sales tax rate is higher. It is a hefty hike in sales tax on a very wide range of goods, despite the fact that the government told the electorate throughout the election campaign—including in the election policy speech—and in the months leading up to the campaign that it would not increase taxes.

para.tab: The government can try to argue with that and Senator McMullan can try to argue the contrary until he is blue in the face, but the debates we have had in the parliament and elsewhere for weeks have made it absolutely clear that the government has no mandate at all to increase broadly based taxes of this nature—indeed, any taxes. For that reason alone, this measure deserves to be defeated. But there are other reasons why it deserves to be defeated. The paramount reason is that these sales tax increases are harsh, regressive and unfair, and they hurt low income earners in particular.

The government will argue that it is giving tax reductions which compensate for these indirect tax increases. But when we do the arithmetic, it works out at nothing like a fair compensation. It is only a partial and inadequate compensation. For all those people who earn less than $20,700 a year—that comprises 60 per cent of the total female work force in this country and about 40 per cent of the total work force—the only compensation they will get for the very significant flow-through in price increases that will occur as a result of this increase in sales tax is a measly $2.88 a week. It will go nowhere near compensating for the price increases that are being forced on the electorate in the budget's proposals. Not only is the increase only $2.88 a week but, worse still, because it is a rebate they will not get it until they put in a tax return after the end of this financial year. It will be June or July or, in some cases, closer to Christmas next year before they get this measly, partial and inadequate compensation for a whole range of price increases that will occur as a result of the sales tax increases from now on.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and other government ministers have been talking about goodies for Christmas in the sense of the income tax cut. By the way, that cut has now been put in jeopardy by the government's obduracy in the last few days. Even if some taxpayers get that tax cut before Christmas, a vast majority of low income earners will not get it for a minimum of eight or nine months, many of them closer to 12 months. They will have gone through all the price increases in the meantime. That will hit very hard.

I say to the committee as a whole and, in particular, to my friend Senator Harradine that this tax proposal is harsh, unfair and regressive, and particularly hits single low income families with children. We will not have a bar of agreeing to tax increases which do that. For that reason, I have moved the amendments standing in my name.

talk.start.para: —Amendments 3, 5, 6 and 7 relate to the first tranche, as was mentioned by Senator Short. The wholesale sales taxes are currently being collected, as are other items in the government's proposed budget. The Greens will not be supporting this request for amendments, simply because in the medium term that would make it difficult for this government to keep to any reasonable deficit reduction strategy. Because we are cognisant of that desire and have obviously made requests on other aspects of the budget, we believe that in this instance we can live with this tranche. But we will, as we have foreshadowed, oppose the second tranche, which gives the government time to find alternative sources of revenue.

talker.name: Senator KERNOT
talker.role: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

talk.start.para: —I made my remarks in my speech in the second reading debate. We will not be supporting this request either. The choices are not entirely up to us. The opposition proposed a GST, and because it could not have that it is now saying that the government does not have a right to propose its own agenda. I do not agree with that agenda either, but I do agree that the government was elected, however slimly, and this is the economic direction it has taken. We have had some influence on that, although nowhere near enough. We wish we could have more. When we come to speak about the second round of tax cuts I would like to say more about the cumulative effect of rejecting a whole range of government revenue-raising proposals.

—I wish to add to my colleague's comments. We are not supporting these amendments. We have already spoken about the regressive impact of the wholesale sales taxes. Despite our disagreement with them, we feel that it would be regarded, with some justification, as fiscally irresponsible if we were to support these amendments. However, let that serve as a warning that, unless the government heeds the requests of the Senate, any further delay in the passage of these bills will be fiscally irresponsible; that is, if the passage is delayed and it creates a hole in the deficit right now. Whereas the cutting of the second round of wholesale sales taxes will have no impact this or next financial year, the passage of these amendments or any delay by the government in the passage of the bills because it holds up the request of the Senate will also jeopardise the legal ability, or even the moral legitimacy, of the government to collect the money that it has been collecting since 18 August.

—If these requests were accepted by this chamber, and in the unlikely event that they were accepted by the other chamber, then that would be a complete vote of no confidence in the government. I am talking about the first tranche that we are considering here. If we were fair dinkum about it and we stuck to our guns, then the government would not have the money to continue to exercise its rights as an elected government. This would create a great problem for members of this chamber and the government. That does not worry me a great deal, but I believe that we have to look at our responsibility in respect of tax measures such as these. I do not agree with them. I do not like them for the very same reason advanced by Senator Short: they are regressive, particularly on single income families. I have made that point, both in this chamber and outside the chamber.

para.tab: I feel hopeful that the government, when considering its approach to the whole taxation area, will have a look at what I think we all agree is very important. The taxation system should in some way recognise that income is spread and shared amongst the family group which depends on that particular income. In respect of the first tranche, there is a real argument, frankly, against allowing this measure to go through. That is the reason I am voting reluctantly against the requests proposed by Senator Short.

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

talk.start.para:
—I will be very brief. I thank the majority of the chamber for its recognition of fiscal responsibility. Quite clearly, I do not agree with all the queries that were raised about the measures, but I accept the responsible way in which the arguments were put and the recognition that this measure, unlike some of the others, about which I still feel strongly and which I will be strongly arguing, is central to the funding of this budget. That is what distinguishes it from some of the others.
We are talking about hundreds of millions of dollars this year. That is what is fundamental about this, and nobody can responsibly pretend otherwise. I thank the majority for its recognition, even if some of it was more reluctant than mine.

para.tab: Question put:
Question so resolved in the negative.

speech.speaker: Short Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:

speech.para: (1)Clause 2, page 1, lines 6 to 9, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

para.tab:
"
2
.This Act is taken to have commenced on 18 August 1993.".

speech.para: (2)Part 3, page 2, lines 18 to 26, omit the Part.
(9)Schedule 2, page 5, omit the Schedule.

The remaining requests for amendments that I have moved relate to the government's proposal in the three bills we are debating to impose a second tranche of sales tax increases of one per cent from 1 July 1995. Amendments 1, 2 and 9 of my nine circulated amendments relate to this. Most of what I want to say in relation to this has already been said.

para.tab: As far as the first tranche is concerned, I repeat that the government has no mandate for this increase. These taxes are unfair, harsh and regressive. They particularly hurt low income earners and low single income families with children. There is totally inadequate compensation for any of this in the government's budget proposals as a whole. Indeed, the impact will be very significant on a range of people, particularly low income families, as we approach this Christmas. The clauses we have just passed will have an impact this Christmas.

As a result of what the Senate has now done, there will be an increase in the cost of children's toys and games, flavoured milk, soft drinks and baby foods, which for many people are necessities. We have passed an increase in sales tax for such items through the committee's failure to adopt the opposition's requests for amendment. I urge the committee very strongly to look at this second stage of sales tax increase that has been proposed by the government. It is proposed that from 1 July 1995 the sales tax be increased again by a like amount to the increase coming in this year.

In moving these amendments on behalf of the Opposition, I point out that the Greens—Senator Chamarette and Senator Margetts—have also circulated amendments that are identical to the opposition's amendments. So although I am moving them on behalf of the opposition, I publicly acknowledge and recognise that identical amendments have been proposed by the Greens.

Senator McMullan said in relation to the last group of amendments for the first tranche that the sales tax increase for this financial year is central to the funding of the 1993 budget. There is no way in the world he can say that the second tranche being proposed to apply in 1995-96 is essential in any way, shape or form in that context. I know that this is a government of enormous incompetence, but I would have thought that even it, in the intervening period between now and 1995-96, would have been able to so adjust its fiscal policy and budgetary strategies as to be able to more than encompass the potential loss in revenue two or three years down the track which acceptance of the opposition's amendments on this occasion would incur. Therefore, there is no way in which the government can say that this second unfair, harsh, regressive, uncompensated, very damaging further tax hike for low income earners and families can be justified or required in a fiscal sense in any way.

talk.start.para: —Senator Short correctly identified the fact that there are amendments circulated in my name which also have the same effect as the amendments requested by the opposition. We have heard that the government is beginning to realise that it is necessary in the medium term to frame budgets in a different way—to be more consultative and to involve more people in the way that budgets are framed—while still being fiscally responsible and meeting the needs of the community. This is a welcome move. There is no need to think that will necessarily throw fiscal policies out the window. I believe this is one thing that time will prove.

para.tab: However, as we have stated, we are concerned about the retrograde and regressive aspects of the budget. By submitting an amendment in this regard, we have given the government time to look at alternative revenue measures, which I believe are more than abundantly available and which can be implemented in a much fairer and wiser way for the benefit of all Australians. We are also looking at the general employment aspects of government strategies, which we hope may improve with time. We certainly support these measures.

talker.name: Senator KERNOT
talker.role: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

talk.start.para: —This is where the debate and the vote get pretty serious. We have had a bit of anecdotal evidence put forward in the second reading debate today. People have been producing letters and faxes and have told stories of talking with individual winegrowers all around Australia. I also have had my share of faxes and phone calls. My experience is that although 50 per cent of people are saying, `Yes, block the budget, it is a great thing', 50 per cent are saying, `Pass the budget; this country requires certainty'. I am not talking about investment advisers and those who might have a vested interest in these things. I am talking about ordinary Australians who are saying, `Pass the budget'.
—This doesn't affect the budget.

—That is Senator Kemp's view. He is only thinking quite selfishly in one-year terms. We are talking about reducing the deficit in this country—something I would have thought the opposition would welcome. But it wants to have it both ways: pretending it supports that and gutting the budget in the meantime, not just this year but well into the future. Therefore, we have this tension. We have the populist approach of opposing everything on the grounds that it is bound to attract somebody, an approach that appeals to the larrikin in Australians, or we have the idea of hanging out as long as possible for more change.

para.tab: Then there is also the tension between those views and the view of making responsible change at the same time as attempting to give some certainty. Senator Watson is using the words `responsible change' and I am too. In this country it is easy to appeal to that cultural sentiment propagated by Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen that there should be no new taxes. It is a great line. We cannot go on for ever saying, `No new taxes in my backyard, thank you very much. I want all the services, but I do not want pay for them'. We have to have the capacity to raise taxes.

What we are arguing about is how we do it and who has the right to do it. That is where the Democrats and the opposition really differ. It comes down to our view about the legitimate role of the Senate. Is it a house of review? Is it a house of government? Where do our rights begin and end? Are 1,550 votes considered to be a mandate? Is winning the election a mandate? Who has the right to dictate the economic direction of this country? Is it our right? If we want to take on that right, why do we not face an election every three years, as the House of Representatives does?

Senator Short interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Senator Short, it is not just about the effect of knocking off the second round of sales tax increases. We are talking about the cumulative effect of what the opposition in particular is doing. Those opposite want no wine tax, no sales taxes rounds one and two, no petrol tax and no tax on annual leave. That amounts to $3.16 billion. The second round—
—No retrospective tax on cumulative leave.

—I accept that interjection. The second round of sales tax will cost $1.2 billion. It will be increasing by $600 million a year. Those opposite are insisting on the government finding the money for the second tranche of income tax cuts, which will cost $3.5 billion. We are talking about $6.7 billion of revenue. Those opposite cannot have it both ways. They cannot agree that the country is in a mess with its debt but then deny it every opportunity of raising revenue of $6.7 billion.

para.tab: What this is really about is gutting a budget and being obstructionist. It is about taking every opportunity possible to maybe crack the big one, get a double dissolution and go to an early election to have another go at the one those opposite did not win.

talk.start.para: —Absolute rubbish.

—I am sorry Senator Watson but I have great difficulty in believing that the opposition's primary motivation is equity. Yesterday the opposition voted against Senator Margetts's amendment, which was identical to the one we moved last year and which it voted against then. In the name of equity, to redistribute income those opposite voted against the amendment. Those opposite had the opportunity to display their credentials and they voted—

—We had advice otherwise, Senator Watson. We were only imposing a new rate of tax. A lot of this is dressed up in the name of equity. It is short term and selective. Equity also extends to the whole notion of reducing debt and redirecting resources towards more productive uses, such as public infrastructure and assistance for important and peculiarly successful burgeoning Australian industries.

para.tab: I argue that the budget is not the be all and end all of our opportunities to inject equity in the name of low income earners. As each piece of legislation is presented to us we have an opportunity to amend it. We have done that and will continue to do that. I think the particular situation we should be mindful of is that the Treasurer has said that he is going to bring next year's budget forward to May or June. Planning for that is going to start soon. I am sure that we will have an opportunity to have some input into the planning of that budget.

I think we have learnt something from this experience. I think the government has heard the message from the electorate that many of us have articulated. But those opposite cannot stand here in the name of equity, in the name of commitment to a more secure economic future for Australia and in the name of certainty, and take out a wine tax, two rounds of sales tax, petrol taxes and a retrospective tax on annual leave. What are we left with? What is the government left with as the core of its budget? It is left with a luxury car tax and a few changes to the fringe benefits tax; the credit union tax has a question mark over it. That is why we ought to think long and hard about our rights and responsibilities and the role of the Senate.

I think what the opposition is proposing is absolutely irresponsible. I am happy to speak for those 50 per cent of people who say, `Sure, we do not like the budget. It is not a perfect budget, but we want to get on with it'. The Democrats want people to have confidence in Australia's future. We want them to feel that they want to make investment decisions. I want to say to people that there are some great Australian ideas that are worth investing in and they will promote employment. At the moment, this is jeopardised by the lingering uncertainty about the fate of this budget.

That is where the Democrats and the opposition differ. That is why the vote on this matter will be very important. It is dishonest to talk simply about one year's budget when we all know that this one year is an important part of a four-year strategy. What the opposition is doing represents blowing a huge hole in the budget. Those opposite might not call $6 billion huge, but I do.

talk.start.para: —It's $3 billion.
—No. I am talking about the opposition insisting on the second round of personal tax cuts as well. That is why we should think long and hard about our vote on this particular request.

—I want to make a few brief comments in relation to the remarks Senator Kernot made. Senator Kernot outlined the dilemma that undoubtedly the Democrats feel about what the Senate should be doing and what the role of the Senate is. That is a debate which has gone on for a long time and will go on in the foreseeable future.

para.tab: I wish to contribute a little towards the sort of dilemma Senator Kernot is talking about. Senator Kernot and her colleagues have seen fit to amend this budget. They have seen fit not to accept the government's claim that the Senate does not have a role in making adjustments of this sort. To a certain extent, the Democrats have moved away from that hard and fast government principle. We have just voted to reject the government's wine tax.

talk.start.para: —What does that measure cost?
—Senator Kernot, let me finish my point. I will then come to the point Senator Kernot made. May I finish my points first?

para.tab: The second issue that Senator Kernot and her colleagues have to face up to is the mandate. Senator Kernot touched a bit on the issue of the government's mandate. I do not think there is any argument in the wider community—and I do not think there is a great deal of argument in this chamber, apart from the exchanges during question time—that the government went to the election opposing and eschewing any rise in taxes. There is no argument about that. We have produced quotation after quotation from the Prime Minister, Mr Willis and their colleagues to show that the government went to the election saying that it would not increase taxes.

What we now have, of course, are these taxes which show that the government has decided not to keep to that particular election commitment. In terms of keeping governments honest this is a very important principle. It is my view—and I think most of the Australian public share it—that the moral authority of this government has collapsed. It has collapsed essentially because, as many have said, the government lied its way into office. It is not the only issue, but it is important that we make an attempt to keep the government honest. One of the Democrats' great principles in ancient days, under former Senator Chipp, was that governments should be kept to their commitments and promises. I do not say that this is the only consideration, but it is an important consideration. There is no question that the government has comprehensively broken the commitments that it made to the Australian people.

Senator Kernot raised the issue of confidence in the Australian community. She said that it was important to restore confidence and that, therefore, we should pass this budget. I put a counter view to Senator Kernot. I have had the experience of sitting on the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration and looking at the evidence that came forward from a wide variety of sectors of the Australian economy. The evidence that was given to that committee about these tax rises was absolutely devastating.

If Senator Kernot wants to increase the level of investment in the Australian community, she should not vote for taxes which severely discriminate against industry. That is precisely what this tax bill and the other tax measures which have come before this parliament will do.

talk.start.para: —Are you talking about the wine tax?

—No. I am talking about the overall package involved here and how it will affect successful Australian industries. It is beyond my comprehension how increasing taxes on industry will increase confidence and provide them with the encouragement which the Democrats have urged so often in this chamber.

para.tab: Senator Kernot also raised the question of equity. I do not think there is any argument that these taxes are regressive taxes. I have gone through the important principle of her argument, and we can debate that, but the big issue is whether the government should be kept honest and, if it fails to keep its promises, whether we should not encourage it to keep true to the mandate which it went to the election on.

On equity grounds we would have to vote against these tax measures. Everybody recognises that they are regressive. If we are after restoring confidence in Australian industry, the last thing we should do is increase taxes on industry. Senator Kernot has raised some important issues which we have to consider. In conclusion, I remind honourable senators that in 1981 a whole raft of indirect tax increases were thrown out of this place. They were thrown out by the Labor Party with the support of the Australian Democrats.

talk.start.para: —I think we moved it.
—The Democrats actually moved it. In joining with the Labor Party in 1981 the Democrats set a precedent. There is no new precedent being established.
—One measure—not the whole budget.

—We have found that the one-year effects of these measures, which the government has conceded, are precisely the same. There is no argument, even between ourselves and the government, that the first year effects of the 1981 rejection of the tax measures and the proposed rejection of the 1993 tax measures would be precisely the same. I am certain that the figures will show that the out year effects will also be precisely the same. So the precedent is there.

para.tab: I think we are acting in a highly responsible and principled manner. Above all, we are asserting the need for honesty in government. We are asserting the great Australian value of equity and the principle that, if we want to encourage employment, we have to encourage industry. One way not to encourage industry is to whack more taxes on it.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak very briefly in support of these requests. The government provided some buffers to the introduction of the first round of wholesale sales tax, some of which were attributed to the involvement of the Australian Democrats. I refer, for example, to the $50 increase in the rebate, the lowering of the fuel excise and the dropping of the proposed change to optometry benefits available under Medicare. On that basis why, therefore, is it legitimate to support an increase in wholesale sales tax in July 1995, in 18 months time, without also legislating in advance for social equal compensation measures? That is the point I would like to put to Senator Kernot.

para.tab: Senator Kernot says that we cannot have it both ways. Neither can she; nor the government. The Democrats and the government have shown that they are prepared to legislate in advance. As has already been detailed, they are prepared to show compassion for the regressive impact that this first round of measures will have. Why, then, are they not prepared to make available ahead of time measures that will compensate for the second round when it hits the community and those in the community least able to afford it.

Senator Kernot cited figures which indicate that 50 per cent of the people she has been hearing from do not indicate concern over this budget; they are concerned, but they simply want the budget passed. I have heard other figures which state that 67 per cent want the government to change its budget in recognition of the regressive impact of its plan. The point is: it is not the number of people who want the budget passed; it is who is asking and why. I maintain that these requests, if supported, are signals to the government that, in the eyes of the community, these budget measures do not represent equity or compassion. I therefore will be supporting the requests.

talk.start.para: —The proposition that is put forward by Senator Short is that the second tranche be referred to the House of Representatives for reconsideration; in fact, more than reconsideration, that we in this chamber request amendments that would abolish that part of this legislation that is before us. Frankly, I would have liked to have debated a number of other measures before these sales tax bills came before us. I would also have liked to have received a number of answers to questions that I asked in estimates committee hearings in respect of measures in those bills.

para.tab: For some reason or other—I think it was the wine industry question that they wanted to get out of the road—the opposition sought to have these bills come before the chamber in a different order from what was supplied to us yesterday. As I recall it, that order had the fuel tax, the customs tariff and the excise tariff bills being considered before these measures. Honourable senators might ask: what does that have to do with the question as to whether or not I am going to support the amendments?

I am personally concerned about the effect of the overall budget on my own state and, doubtless, all honourable senators would have a similar view in respect of the people in their own states. In the estimates committee hearing I asked Treasury about its Prismod model and how, for example, the increase in excise on shipping fuel could be factored in and how that would affect the ordinary householder in Tasmania. The response really was that that specific effect could not be gauged from the Prismod model. Under those circumstances, something has to be done about that question which has a specific effect on my state.

Coming to the question that is before us, I think that it is inappropriate for a minister or ministers to commit the government to expenditure on controversial policies for more than a short period—and certainly not for a four-year period, well beyond the term of this parliament.

talk.start.para: —The measures that we are dealing with have various titles, but the term `(Deficit Reduction) Bill' is included in each one. One can understand the need for any institution, whether it be a home, a business or a government, to engage in deficit reduction. It is a commendable task. But what the parliament—and, indeed, the government—always needs to be aware of is whether the burdens of that effort fall fairly throughout the community; that is, whether they are shared properly. I have already mentioned that burdens are falling—unfairly, I believe—on the shoulders of the one-income family. I also believe that they are being shared unfairly by the unemployed.

para.tab: Many people in the community consider that we are not in a recession but in a painful transition to a situation of continuous drops in standards of living, with a permanent underclass of unemployed and underemployed. I do not think that situation should exist and I do not think we should allow it to exist. I realise that all parties and all members of the community are concerned about that. There needs to be a combined approach to see that that does not occur and that the unemployment situation improves. As elected representatives of our various states, we need to ensure that the burden is not unfairly shared. For example, we need to ensure that people in my state are not unfairly burdened by any of the deficit reduction bills.

Another of the government's obligations is to rein in expenditure on rather suspect policies, particularly if the government's commitments on those policies have no legislative base and have not been approved of and discussed by the parliament. There is an obligation on the government to rein in expenditure in this instance, if for no other reason than to offset the losses in tax receipts which have been occasioned by the reaction to the budget, by the various discussions that have been taking place between members of parliament and the government, and by the actions of the Senate today.

I remain to be convinced of the need for the second tranche of the sales tax measures. In some respects we are being asked to buy a pig in a poke. It is not prudent for people to buy a pig in a poke unless they are absolutely certain about, or have reason to believe, the bona fides of the seller and the reasonableness of the price.

I intend to vote for the proposition put forward by Senator Short that we make a request to the House of Representatives. I think it is reasonable. It will give the House of Representatives an opportunity to have another look at this question and at the desirability of the second tranche of the sales tax measures. After all, even on the government's own measure, they do not come into effect for two years, so there is plenty of time to consider them. They do not affect the ability of the government to fund measures in this budget. Accordingly, I indicate to my colleagues in the Senate that I will be voting for Senator Short's motion for a request to be made to the House of Representatives.

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

talk.start.para: —We have a very important matter before us. I have listened carefully to the speeches made by honourable senators and I recognise the consequences of the collective representations of views that they have put. But honourable senators would not expect me to do other than put the government's case in a circumstance where we are talking about at least $1 billion, in round terms—maybe more, but certainly not less—within the period of the deficit reduction strategy. It is important and it needs serious consideration. I think the arguments for and against need to be put on the table.

para.tab: It becomes a bit rich when those opposite come in here speaking in anguished tones about these deficit reduction measures and about equity, when their proposition for reducing the deficit is predicated on slashing outlays and when they know—and every objective commentator knows and every piece of evidence confirms—that that is the most inequitable mechanism for reducing the deficit.

Slashing outlays is the thing which most significantly adversely affects the welfare and interests of the low paid, the poor and the needy—those most in need of government support in this society. I reject the credentials of those opposite who come in here and say, `This is inequitable. What you should be doing is slashing outlays'. That is comprehensively contradictory to the facts. I reject that proposition with contempt.

Other people have been putting equity arguments from a different perspective. I will not reiterate what I said with regard to the first tranche, except to say that I went through what I think is the context within which the equity of the measures needs to be seen. I put that on the record then and it would be wasting the Senate's time to do it twice. I talked about some of the elements of wholesale sales tax that influence the manner in which its equity implications need to be considered.

What I want to talk about is the deficit reduction strategy. While I disagree very strongly with some things Senator Short said—and I do not in any way wish to mislead honourable senators—he did say that this is not a bill about funding this year's budget. That is quite correct.

talk.start.para: —This amendment.
—This particular matter we are discussing now.
—This amendment now, yes.

—That is right. I am not contradicting that; I accept it. But it is about the deficit reduction strategy. I read in the conclusion of the second reading debate on these measures—I will not read it all again but I want to reiterate the point that it made—some lengthy economic commentary about the fundamental macro-economic significance, not only of getting the deficit down but also of making clear, firm, unequivocal legislative commitments at this stage to do so.

para.tab: The international evidence makes it absolutely clear that economies should be able to indicate to investors and to the rest of the international community, as we are, that, for proper reasons, the deficit is going up in the short term for the purpose of providing stimulus, and that there is in place a medium term deficit reduction strategy that has beneficial implications, most obviously on interest rates—and we should not ignore the equity implications of interest rates.

Deficit reduction also has quite clear linkages to investment, jobs and growth. A secure, established, legislated deficit reduction strategy has profound positive equity implications and economic implications in the areas of jobs and interest rates. The most significant equity measure that can be taken is the creation of jobs. That is the most significant redistribution one can take, and having a secure deficit reduction strategy gives the capacity to do that. It also has beneficial impact in the other areas that I mentioned.

It has immediate macro-economic benefits as well as long-term implications. That is why some people are comfortably arguing—and I understand, on the face of it, why it is an appealing argument—`This is not a measure to fund this budget so we have more time. You can come back next year and have another go'. I am not referring to those who want us to come back next year because they want us to have to bring in a tough budget next year for their political advantage. I am referring to people who are genuinely saying, `Come back and have another go next time because these measures do not take effect until 1995, 1996 or some other year'.

What we have to do is recognise that there are immediate macro-economic implications as well as profound long-term implications. I accept—as is recognised by the Greens and Senator Harradine, as well as by us and the Democrats who are supporting these measures—that obviously there are profound long-term implications of deficit reduction. That is recognised, at least by 40 senators. I am concerned that some of those 40 are not recognising the short-term implications of it. I think one can summarise the opposition's concern about the deficit reduction strategy as being a fear that it might work. I understand the motivation; it is the product of having been in opposition for a long time.

But I want to say to the Greens and to Senator Harradine that these measures in their context and their macro-economic implications—as part of a whole budget, as part of a series of budgets and as part of the deficit reduction strategy—are, in fact, part of a package, the net effect of which will be beneficial to Australia and will have positive beneficial implications for the people whose interests they are seeking to represent, particularly low paid workers. Those who are seeking to be paid workers in the low to middle income range, that is the unemployed, will be the beneficiaries of this budget overall and of this deficit reduction strategy in particular, for which this measure is so important. I realise that that is a nebulous argument, but that does not make it any the less valid and important for the Greens and Senator Harradine to consider.

It is important to recognise that, as a result of the decisions the Senate has made today and the indications of support with regard to other measures, the overwhelming majority of the legislation required to fund the revenue requirements of this budget has been passed and that revenue has been achieved. I welcome that. That is an important step forward for economic stability in Australia. Notwithstanding that the opposition opposed it, I thank the Senate for supporting it. But I do want to reinforce the importance of the deficit reduction strategy, and of this bill as a part of it, immediately as well as in the medium term.

Every member of parliament knows that you can always make yourself popular by opposing a tax increase, but I think on this occasion that, on balance, the chamber should resolve that of much more significance than the popularity one can achieve by opposing these tax increases is the responsibility we would show by passing them. While recognising, quite obviously, from what people have said, the arithmetic of this place at the moment, I am urging the Greens and Senator Harradine to consider the significance of it and its implications, and to reconsider their position now and on the subsequent occasions on which I think they will get to indicate that reconsideration, should this request be carried.

talk.start.para: —I want to refute what has been repeated by Senator McMullan over and over again in this place over the last few days. It is quickly becoming in my mind what I might call the McMullan doctrine; that is, that we have across the globe and across the nations of the Western world an acceptance of the fact that the only responsible way to reduce a deficit is to increase tax, and that it is not possible to help reduce deficits by cutting expenditure. He, of course, uses the political flourish—
—No, it is not the way to do it. He didn't say that you can't.

—What I am going to argue is that one needs to do these things in a balanced way. What I want to suggest to the chamber, for the record, and so that Senator McMullan will not get away with his doctrine being accepted without being challenged, is that expenditure can of course be cut while still ensuring that government expenditure is more appropriately directed to those who most need it.

para.tab: There is absolutely no doubt that within Australia and within expenditure of federal and state governments, enormous amounts of money are expended by governments that go not to helping poor people, not to helping people who require income support, not to helping people who do not have good enough access to a quality education or quality health care, but instead go to people who are less needy.

It would be glib and stupid to suggest that there is any easy way to slash government expenditure. It is something that has eluded the most avid expenditure cutters and deficit reducers across the globe. But I want to challenge the McMullan doctrine that it is not responsible to seek to reduce government expenditure—to reduce outlays—as a way of reducing deficits. What this government must remember is that, particularly in the years since Senator Walsh left the ministry of finance, it has been most unsuccessful in reducing the expenditure side of the budget and has continued to rely on the revenue side to try to reduce the gap.

The problem with relying on increases in indirect taxes and other forms of taxes—and tonight we have had the example of the wine industry—is that in many ways they reduce employment. They detract from the very proposition that Senator McMullan quite rightly put—that the way to deliver to the people who are in most need in this community is, in the end, to create job opportunities, to create employment. The wine tax, which we defeated tonight, was an example of a tax which would have affected employment within the industry.

In recent months, we have had examples of the sort of expenditure that does not help people in most need in Australia. The two very obvious examples were the local capital works program, which was a pork barrel operation leading up to the last election, and, in Canberra, the construction of the new headquarters for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, colourfully known as `Gareth's gazebo'. These sorts of expenditures do not help people living in the outer suburbs of suburban Australia who do not have good access to education, quality health care and income support where they really need it. Those examples help to illustrate the fact that there are expenditures of the Commonwealth, the states and local governments which can be reduced and then redirected to properly help those most in need in this society.

speech.speaker: Short Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —I do not want to unduly delay the conclusion of this debate. There are a couple of things I want to say briefly in response to Senator McMullan's remarks because, like Senator Campbell, I cannot, in honesty, in conscience, let them go uncommented on. Senator Campbell has covered the first point that I would have made relating to government expenditure. I will not go into that any further—Senator Campbell made the point very well—other than to say that Senator McMullan is totally wrong in his assertion that the Opposition's policy position is based essentially on slashing outlays. That is simply not true, and the evidence shows that quite clearly.

para.tab: The second point I make—which relates a little to the first—centres on what Senator McMullan said about deficit reduction strategies. We all agree with the need to reduce the deficit. He omitted to point out that, over the last three years, including this financial year, the accumulated deficit resulting from the deliberate policies that this government has pursued is $40,000 million. In three years, this government has cranked up this debt; it has put the nation's savings into hock; it has put its sticky fingers into the nation's cookie jar to the tune of $40 billion. For Senator McMullan to come in here now and cry crocodile tears over deficit reduction strategies and the like is hypocritical in the extreme.

Senator Harradine very rightly made the point that we need in our policies, in our approach to government, to ensure that burdens fall fairly throughout the community. Senator Harradine is absolutely correct. We in the opposition are so critical of the policies and performance of this government over the past few years precisely because the government has not allowed the burdens to fall fairly on the community.

The government's approach does not produce equity. So as to not prolong the debate, I ask rhetorically: where is the equity when the government adopts measures which so hurt low income earners and families, as this government has done? Where is the equity when the government pursues policies that have the result of putting one million Australians out of work, with another one million Australians unable to find full-time work or who have dropped out of the work force altogether—the underclass which Senator Harradine was referring to? What we are all about is trying to remove from our society those evils that produce the dreadful inequities and distortions.

To suggest that the government is going to help any of those things by jacking up sales tax in the way that it is proposing is an absolute nonsense so far as the individuals that it hurts are concerned, so far as the investment that it talks about trying to encourage is concerned, and so far as the jobs that it talks about trying to create are concerned. On all those counts, the government has failed. I reject totally the government's suggestion that it will now have its strategy for a better Australia put at risk by the acceptance of the opposition's requests for amendment. It is a nonsense.
Question put:
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bills agreed to, with requests.

speech.para: SALES TAX (IN SITU POOLS) (DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL 1993

para.tab: The bill.

speech.speaker: Short Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —This bill is here as a separate bill because of the way the government imposes sales tax on in-ground pools as a result of the loss by the Australian Taxation Office last year in the High Court in the so-called Mutual Pools case. Without going into the technicalities of it, I would point out that to impose sales tax on in-ground pools the government had to have a separate act.

para.tab: What the government is proposing in this bill is a two stage increase in sales tax—one per cent as from the night of the budget and one per cent as from 1 July 1995—which is identical to the way that it was proposing to apply the sales tax increases contained in the bills that we have just dealt with. As I say, it is just due to a technicality, in effect, resulting from that High Court decision last year, that in-ground pools were not included in the preceding three bills. For that reason, I have circulated requests for amendments to this bill. As I say, they have exactly the same effect as the amendments that we have just been discussing so far as sales tax is concerned.

Of the eight amendments circulated in my name, amendments 5 and 7 relate to the first sales tax tranche increase; amendments 6 and 8 relate to the second tranche increase; and amendments 1 to 4 relate to both. If the Senate is to be consistent with the way it has voted in terms of the last three bills in its approach to the sales tax increases, one would expect the Senate to vote the same way in relation to this bill as it did then. To take the amendments in sections, I seek leave to move amendments 5 and 7 together.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: The the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:

speech.para: (5)Clause 5, page 2, lines 10 to 17, omit the clause.
(7)Schedule 1, page 3, omit the Schedule.

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

talk.start.para: —I feel that it might be useful if I came into this debate a little earlier than on previous occasions. Senator Short's description of the legal history of why we have this bill is accurate. I will not waste time on that, but one of the advantages of it, although it was an unfortunate decision at the time from the government's point of view, is that it exposes the weakness in the argument that increasing indirect tax is necessarily inequitable.

para.tab: Here we have, starkly for everybody to see, people purporting to be arguing in favour of the interests of the poor and the unemployed—`We do not want to put up tax on swimming pools'. Although I understand the origin of this argument, it just exposes the fact that those opposite need analysis which is a little more sophisticated than, `Putting up wholesale sales tax is inequitable'. One of the good things about the wholesale sales tax that distinguishes it from the goods and services tax is its capacity to distinguish—and here is a classic example. It is an interesting equity argument to say that there is something inequitable about putting up tax on swimming pools.

talk.start.para: —You don't believe this, Bob.
—I very much do.
—You don't Bob; you know you don't.
—I enjoy and I am quite pleased—
—I know Paul wants you to say this, but—

para.tab:
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)
—Order! Senator Kemp, interjections are out of order, and your further interjections just compound your error.

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman. I welcome the opportunity to be a member of a government which is making clear that part of its revenue package seeks to put up tax on luxury items. It is appropriate, I am quite proud to be associated with it and I am interested in the contrast that is shown by those who think it is somehow inequitable.

—I will take just one moment to deal with what Senator McMullan has had to say about being quite proud of a government that puts sales tax on luxury items. Certain items are a luxury in one place and not in another. Let me go into the question of swimming pools. I do believe that in the city of Perth, where Senator Chris Evans, who sits opposite, comes from—
—Without a pool.

—Without a pool—I do not have a pool in my city home or my country home either. I believe that for people in Perth to put in a swimming-pool is a luxury when that city has the beaches that it enjoys. But in regard to houses in the country that are 500 and 600 kilometres from the nearest beach and 200, 300 or 400 kilometres from the nearest public swimming-pool, I do not believe it is a luxury to put in a swimming-pool. I reckon it is hypocritical of this hypocritical sort of minister to be saying that, in places like remote areas of Australia, a swimming-pool is a luxury. Since he says these things surrounded by the manicured lawns of Canberra, it shows just how hypocritical he is.
—In view of the fact that this is a wholesale sales tax, how much does the government believe this will return to it in the first tranche?

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

talk.start.para: —I am sorry, I do not have a separate figure for the swimming pools; the figure I have is for the first tranche in total. But I do not want to mislead the Senate: it is not a lot of money. We are not talking about undermining the deficit reduction strategy with this one. I think it is a proper thing to do, but I do not want to pretend that it will blow the deficit out if we do not do it.

para.tab: Requests negatived.

speech.speaker: Short Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:

speech.para: (6)Clause 6, page 2, lines 19 to 26, omit the clause.
(8)Schedule 2, page 4, omit the Schedule.

I have moved this second set of requests for amendment on behalf of the opposition. They relate to the second tranche, the further one per cent increase due on 1 July 1995—a tranche which we now well know the Senate has rejected in terms of the other three bills. I repeat the point I made earlier: if there had not been the High Court decision last year which produced a technicality in terms of the requirement for a separate act for the taxing of in situ pools, we would not be having this debate because we would have already acted on it as part of the preceding amendment.

para.tab: The only point I want to make in addition to those I have already made is that, given the way the Senate has decided on the first three bills that have we discussed, if the Senate does not reject this second tranche, we will have the situation where, come 1 July 1995, excluding a zero rate, we will move from a rate scale for the wholesale sales tax of five per cent to a rate scale of nine per cent—in fact, 10 per cent if we count zero. On 1 July 1995, if this second tranche is not rejected, we will have zero, 11 per cent, 12 per cent, 16 per cent, 17 per cent, 21 per cent, 22 per cent, 31 per cent, 32 per cent and 45 per cent. No rate structure could be more ridiculous, more complicated and unnecessary, in my mind.

On the basis of the principle that was adopted in the voting on the first two bills, for consistency and to avoid this nine per cent or 10 per cent rate scale, I urge the Senate to vote on this tranche the same way as it voted for the second tranche in relation to the other three bills—namely, to reject it.
Question put:
Question so resolved in the negative.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)
—The question before the chair is that the bill be now passed without requests.

talk.start.para: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I seek your clarification on a point relating to the Sales Tax (In Situ Pools) (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993. I have in my hand an amendment that was circulated by Senator Margetts on behalf of the Greens which is identical to the amendment that we just voted on and against which Senator Margetts and Senator Chamarette voted. Do the Greens need permission to withdraw that amendment?
—The amendment was not before the committee. It has to be formally moved.
—On behalf of Senator Margetts, I wish to move the amendment circulated in her name.
—Order! It is not in order for a senator to move a request on behalf of another senator.

—For future readers of
Hansard
, I put on record that, in relation to the Sales Tax (In Situ Pools) (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993, identical amendments were moved by the opposition and circulated by the Greens in relation to the second tranche of sales tax increases.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. The amendment has not been moved and we would like to withdraw it.
—That is a point of explanation, not a point of order.
—A point of order is that you are misrepresenting the facts, senator.
—That is not correct.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman, because I am not quite sure under which standing order Senator Short is making that point. The amendment has been ruled out of order and he is not in order to be making the point at all.
—We still have the bill before us; any honourable senator may speak to the bill.
—I will not delay the Senate any longer, other than to put on the record that Senator Margetts and Senator Chamarette have voted against an amendment that they themselves circulated.

—Yes, there are two of us, we have voluntary staff and we did ask for a number of amendments. In this particular case it was not our intention to vote against the tax on below ground pools. We are embarrassedly withdrawing the amendment.
—There is no need to withdraw it because it is not before the committee at the moment.
—Could I move the amendment circulated in the name of Senator Margetts?

interject.speaker: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

talk.start.para: —No, Senator Macdonald, you cannot. I just ruled earlier that an honourable senator cannot move a request for another honourable senator.

para.tab: Bill agreed to.

interject.para: SALES TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL 1993

para.tab: Bill agreed to.

speech.speaker: Hill Sen R.M.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate calls on the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) to—

(a) heed the conclusion of the Coalition and Democrat Senators on the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs with respect to Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) 1993 and withdraw and redraft the bill in a form that is unambiguously valid under the terms of the Constitution; and

(b) desist from the constitutionally irresponsible and provocative behaviour of asking the Senate to consider and pass legislation which four of the eight members of a multi-party committee have concluded is of questionable constitutionality.

speech.para: There was some misunderstanding in the chamber yesterday. Yesterday I sought in similar terms to suggest that the government should withdraw and redraft both the first and the second bills in its package of eight bills, which are a division of the original single omnibus taxation bill.

para.tab: As I understood it, the Australian Democrats were prepared to support us in relation to the first bill, but not the second bill. The second bill was the test bill and the Democrats' argument was that, even though there was a question about the constitutionality, the government is entitled to that process. However, Senator Spindler's amendment to my amendment to withdraw the test bill was to be supported by the government but, due to some communication difficulty on the other side, the government voted the wrong way. As a result of that, Senator Spindler lost and he was then faced with the prospect of having to support our motion in full, which included the part that he did not like; therefore, he had to vote against it.

The end result of all that is that the position of the Senate yesterday was correct, in that a majority of senators apparently do not believe that both bills should go back and be redrafted, but it was wrong in that, as I understand it, a majority of senators believe that the first bill should go back and be redrafted. That is why I have moved this motion in these terms tonight.

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

talk.start.para: —I will be very brief because, essentially, the facts, as Senator Hill has outlined them, are correct. In the normal course, I may not have even commented. This is a motion that criticises the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and requests him to do something that I suspect he will not do. If he asks my advice, I will advise him not to do it.

para.tab: I accept that what Senator Hill says reflects accurately the majority position of the Senate. It was only a procedural glitch that interfered with it being accurately reflected last time. So we are prepared to give leave. We will vote against the motion, but we will not divide. We divided last time as an indication of our opposition; it would be wasting our time to do it again. Obviously, our doing that does not mean that we agree with it; we do not. We will vote against it, but we will not divide for the reasons I just outlined.

talk.start.para: —I confirm that what Senator Hill said correctly reflects what happened yesterday, and the Australian Democrats will be supporting his motion.

para.tab: Question resolved in the affirmative.
