speech.speaker: Campbell Sen I.G.

talk.start.para: —The Senate is now considering the Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill 1993, which fundamentally seeks to give legislative provision to the sale of a further 19 per cent of the shares currently held by the Commonwealth of Australia in the Commonwealth Bank. The shares are to be sold in a float which has already been advertised and will occur within the next few weeks.

para.tab: The opposition will be supporting this bill because we are, and have been for many years, committed to privatisation as a way of, firstly, encouraging more people to be owners of shares in Australia and to participate in the economy in that way and, secondly, getting governments out of businesses that they do not need to be involved in and ensuring that government concentrates on its core business, which is to provide a broad economic framework and support to those in need. This bill will also ensure that the government is not tied up in business enterprises that it is not really best qualified to be involved in.

The Commonwealth government has sold 30 per cent of the equity in the Commonwealth Bank so far. The opposition believes that the sale of a further 19 per cent is a measure which has purely been taken to create more revenue for the government at a time of fiscal crisis created by this government.

The opposition takes the position that, if the Commonwealth is serious about privatisation to achieve micro-economic goals, it should be moving to the sale of the full remaining 70 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank. That is our policy; it is the policy that we took to the last election. We predict that the Commonwealth government will move to a full sale of the Commonwealth Bank because of fiscal pressure and the diminishing opposition to privatisation within the government's own ranks, particularly the left wing, which has opposed privatisation for many years.

In Sydney, on 9 June 1993, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration held an inquiry into the Commonwealth Bank's annual report. We took evidence specifically from Mr Ian Payne, who is a senior director of the bank. At that hearing I asked for Mr Payne's broad views about the taxpayers of Australia having 70 per cent equity in the bank, and whether the government maintaining equity in the bank, be it 70 per cent or 51 per cent—which will be the case once the current tranche is sold—will `achieve any real public policy input'. I also asked whether government input into the policy of the bank would be any different should the Commonwealth own 70 per cent, 30 per cent or any other amount. Mr Payne agreed with my proposition that, effectively, the government could no longer, and does no longer, use the Commonwealth Bank as a vehicle for public policy.

I am sure there are people in the chamber tonight, members of the Senate and members of this parliament broadly, who would like to see the Commonwealth Bank used for social and policy objectives. I am sure that is the quite genuine, if not misplaced, objective of members of the left in the Labor Party. I will not put words into the mouths of the Australian Democrats—I am sure that Senator Spindler will contribute his party's views on this debate—but definitely the motivation of the Democrats is to seek to ensure that this privatisation does not proceed.

My view is that public policy should not be delivered through these quasi-autonomous government institutions. It is far better for the government to develop specific programs to help those who have specific needs and to administer those programs as efficiently as possible with very clearly set out social goals and clearly measurable accountability structures, so that those social policy objectives can be measured effectively. It is very hard, if not impossible, to measure whether some public policy objectives, delivered through a 51 per cent ownership of a commercial trading operation—in this case, a very large and successful bank—can deliver public policy goals, particularly social objectives which the Democrats and the left of the Labor Party would seek.
That is where we are coming from. I have circulated an amendment to the second reading. I hope that honourable senators have it. I move:
At the end of the motion, add
", and the Senate calls on the Government:
(a)to proceed immediately to full privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank; and
(b)to ensure that the proposed changes to the charter of the Commonwealth Development Bank will not lead to the Bank moving away from its current role as a lender of the last resort".

speech.para: I am informed that Senator Boswell will address the second part of that motion in his contribution and I will limit my remarks to the first section.

para.tab: As I have said, the opposition will not oppose this bill. We simply point out to the Senate and the government that the objectives of this bill are not to enhance micro-economic reform or competition within the banking sector. They go only a very little way towards assisting the Commonwealth Bank in achieving its commercial objectives and do not really assist the government that much in achieving its revenue objectives.

The other point that needs to be made in any debate on privatisation in Australia—and a number of them are coming up in future deliberations of this Senate, particularly in relation to the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation and the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories—is that one of the other fundamental differences between the government and the coalition parties on privatisation is the use to which privatisation funds are put. We have always argued that privatisation revenue should be immediately offset against long-term government debt. The benefit of this to the community and the taxpayers of Australia is that using the once-off sale proceeds to reduce government debt, reduces in out years the debt servicing requirement which has been a significant part of Commonwealth government outlays in the budgets of the past few years and which will be a part of budgets in future out years.

The policies that we took to the last election ensured that something like 90 per cent of the proceeds of sales that we had in our policy and manifesto were used to offset Commonwealth debt. They would have made a significant contribution to reducing the burden of debt servicing payments on Commonwealth taxpayers in future years. They would ensure that the proceeds of sales of Commonwealth assets, including significant assets like the Commonwealth bank, which have built up goodwill and significant business in Australia and internationally are not just squandered in one year. They would ensure that all Australian taxpayers and future generations benefit from the proceeds of a sale for many years, if not generations to come.

I am not sure of the Democrats' view on this, and I would be interested to hear Senator Spindler put that view. We think it is extremely important when selling great national assets like the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories and the Commonwealth Bank—which is before us tonight—that the benefit of the sale is not squandered on a once-off deficit program in the way that the funds from this sale will be used. To use an old cliche, you are selling the family silverware, the table cloth and the napkins to pay for—

talk.start.para: —To pay the rent.

—The rent or that week's groceries. Each week after that you have to find something else to sell, and something else and, in the end, the cupboard will be bare and you will not be able to buy the groceries. A prudent household under fiscal stress, like many Australian households, that was unfortunately forced to sell the silverware and other valued treasured assets would use the proceeds to reduce the mortgage and outgoings so that it could afford to buy the groceries.

para.tab: Australia is very much in that situation at the moment. We have an enormous debt. Proceeds from privatisation can help to reduce that debt and reduce debt servicing. This has occurred right across the globe. It is a policy that has been implemented in Western nations. The fastest privatisers are now the Eastern European countries. We see it even in China. We had the pleasure of having lunch with the President of the Republic of Chile only yesterday. The South American republics that were referred to only a few years ago by our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) as banana republics have used privatisation to reduce their debt and return growth and wealth to their citizens.

One very important thing that privatisation can do for a country like Australia is enhance competition and, therefore, increase service and benefits to consumers. A vital objective of the opposition within our privatisation policies is to ensure that consumers receive better service for cheaper prices. There is no doubt that in the financial sector it is crucial that we have fair competition between all our financial institutions.

There is absolutely no doubt at the moment that the Commonwealth Bank is, in some ways, being held back by the dead hand of having the Commonwealth on its share register. This point was reinforced by the director of the Commonwealth Bank, Mr Payne. It restricts its capital raising ability and its ability to compete in the marketplace with the other banks—the National Australia Bank, Westpac and the ANZ—which are all desperately trying to make themselves internationally competitive, reduce their costs, deliver better services to their consumers and compete—

talk.start.para: —This was all said in Fightback.

—Senator Loosley, that will ensure that business and domestic consumers receive the best banking facilities at the cheapest transaction cost and also ensure that the whole country becomes more efficient. That will ensure that the Commonwealth Bank can be part of that and, therefore, increase the benefits to consumers of banking and financial services in Australia.

para.tab: As I have already said, the opposition expects that the Commonwealth will, over the course of the next two or three years, move to sell further tranches of the Commonwealth Bank because it will be under increasing fiscal pressure. The opposition will encourage that process. We have moved a second reading amendment to encourage the government to move to completely selling the Commonwealth Bank. The directors of the Commonwealth Bank would like to see that take place.

I am sure many of the current private shareholders, individual Australian citizens, who were so enthusiastic to buy shares in the Commonwealth Bank during the last sale would be happy about this. We see from reading today's newspapers that the bank was totally flooded by inquiries from members of the public before 11 o'clock yesterday morning. The bank has been rushed for prospectuses. This shows that there is a keenness by Australian people and employees of the Commonwealth Bank to buy shares in this fine institution. We think that there would now be a demand to sell the balance of the bank.

There is one further point I should make which I overlooked when going through my notes. In any debate on privatisation in federal parliament at this time, it is pertinent to point out that the former policy of this Labor government was to encourage privatisation and micro-economic reform in the states. In the last few months the states have suffered a drawback by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister announcing that they will allow the states the proceeds from one privatisation to receive the benefits of a preferential compensation deal to compensate the states for the revenue from their financial institutions—whether a state bank or state insurance office—that they would otherwise receive. That revenue will be lost by the states and it will move to the Commonwealth in the form of taxes that will be derived from those institutions.

What was an incentive for the state governments to privatise and achieve the benefits of micro-economic reform across Australia have now been limited by the action of the Treasurer. We have made it clear that we think that is most regrettable. There are a range of privatisation ventures that need to take place in the states to ensure economic efficiency and micro-economic reform.

The government is at the moment blaming the states for a lack of progress in waterfront and shipping reform. The states failing to reform their port authorities is an example of that. There are a range of privatisation ventures that need to take place in the states. Unless the Commonwealth is committed to talking to the states about sensible financial arrangements to carry out those privatisations, then the whole cause of economic efficiency and international competitiveness will be held back because of this regrettable change of policy from the federal government. I conclude my remarks on the basis that I have foreshadowed that Senator Boswell will be speaking to the second part of the amendment.

speech.speaker: Spindler Sen S.E.

talk.start.para: —The Senate is debating the Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill 1993. This bill facilitates the reduction of the Commonwealth shareholding in the Commonwealth Bank from around 70 per cent to 50.1 per cent, as the explanatory memorandum so elegantly states. I think we should call a spade a spade. We should say that what is happening is yet another step along the road to selling the people's bank—
—To the people.

—I would not mind, Senator Kemp, if it was simply being sold to the people. I will return to that point later. I will ask the minister to show me where the safeguards are to avoid sales to foreign interests. I believe in this current bill this is not the case. I know that Senator Kemp probably would not mind if that were done; however, I think it is something to be considered.

para.tab: Apart from not objecting in principle to the sale of assets that the Australian people as a whole own to individual Australian people, one must consider that we are giving up yet another instrument to control the financial system and financial transactions in our economy. That is a continuing trend.

Our government is quite happy, aided and abetted by the opposition, to hand our financial system to foreign speculators. The bill also facilitates the announced decision to provide the Development Bank with a capital injection and to relax the legislative constraints on its lending activities. It enables a capital injection of $30 million and a subsidy of $20 million per annum. What should be said about that is that the Development Bank is a fully owned subsidiary of the Commonwealth Bank, and one wonders whether the functions that this bank has as a lender of last resort—to provide mainly small to medium businesses with loans that they cannot otherwise get—would not now be substantially affected by the further sale of the Commonwealth Bank and by the relaxation of legislative constraints on its lending activities.

In debating this bill tonight, it takes me back to December 1990 when it was legislated that the first 30 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank was to be sold to finance the acquisition of the Victorian State Bank. Even then it was possible to see that that was simply a subterfuge to start the process of privatisation. As we showed at the time, the financing of the acquisition of the Victorian State Bank could have easily been achieved by other means. Exactly as we forecast then, creeping privatisation is now taking place.

I find it somewhat amazing that we are talking about national identity and that the opposition very strongly objects to dropping the monarch from our oath of allegiance because it feels that we should hang on to what is in our past. It has absolutely no compunction about selling an instrument that could contribute substantially to decisions which affect this national identity and substance, the future of the nation and the future of the people.

talk.start.para: —They'd probably sell it to a foreign bank.

—Senator Coulter suggests that the opposition would not mind if it was sold to a foreign bank. As far as I can see, there are actually no restrictions in the further privatisation for at least some of the capital to be acquired by a foreign bank. Again that would be the start of a development that we can foresee being stretched in the future by this government, aided and abetted by the opposition.

para.tab: It is quite clear that when the Commonwealth Bank was established it had certain objectives. Most of those objectives are still valid today. They relate to the setting of standards in the banking system rather than simply relying on regulation. Regulation has now been done away with; we no longer have that. We could still exert some influence on the standards of services provided by private banks by having, in competition with them, a bank that is obliged to look after the interests of the nation as a whole rather than private shareholders and speculators.

We should also say that this is a profitable enterprise. Why should we deprive taxpayers and citizens of Australia of an asset that is turning a profit? It was said by the previous speaker that we should look at where the $1,500 million that the government expects to raise is going. In our view, it would be advisable to have, say, a national development fund that could be used to lend funds to enterprises that require venture capital to provide jobs. However, what will happen is that this $1,500 million will simply be part of the current account arrangements and will disappear into a big black hole.

In December 1990 I had occasion to include in
Hansard
a history of the Commonwealth Bank. Honourable senators will be pleased to hear that, in view of the time constraints tonight, I do not propose to recount that history in detail. However, I wish to advert to just one or two points which will indicate that we are indeed selling today part of the Australian people's birthright.

The origins of the Commonwealth Bank can be traced back to the economic disasters of the 1890s. In those days, the Labor platform contained a policy of establishing a national bank, although the specific purposes of the institution were defined later in history. The legendary King O'Malley led the call within the Labor Party to establish a commonwealth bank. This culminated at the federal conference of the Labor Party in July 1908.

Among the objectives of the bank that was then established was to exempt from all fees the accounts of local government bodies, friendly societies, churches, charities, non-profit associations and state and Commonwealth government accounts. This is just an example of the policy objectives that can be pursued through a national bank that belongs to the people as a whole. But at this stage we are even asking the Industry Commission to look at charities to ensure that they turn a profit. I guess, if they do not turn a profit they should not be exempted from fees in the nation's bank!

I might also mention as another historical vignette that the bank was instrumental in Billy Hughes's acquisition of a shipping line for the Australian government. To further Australia's interests, Hughes decided to create an Australian shipping line to sever our reliance on the British controlled fleet.

I turn to a question that I think is relevant to the consideration as to whether this bank should be placed on the market in the way in which it is being done. The suggestion was made that we are selling what is the property of the Australian community as a whole to individual Australian citizens. I would like the Minister representing the Treasurer, the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan), to point to the constraints in the bill we are debating today which might prevent the sale of part of the Commonwealth Bank to foreign interests.

It is also interesting to note that the decision to sell the bank originated in an ALP caucus resolution of 28 August 1990 which sanctioned the legislation, subject to the undertaking by the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, that no further privatisation take place and that no sales to foreign interests take place. However, even then we were able to point to loopholes in the legislation that was then passed whereby both undertakings could be circumvented by the government of the day. Ostensibly, the sale to foreign interests was prohibited by the proposed section 27K. However, subsection 11 provides:

speech.para: The issue of shares is not affected by the fact that the application for the issue was made in contravention of this section.
So, even then, the ground was laid for further privatisation and for the sale to foreign interests.

para.tab: I believe that, for the reasons outlined, this is a further step down the slippery slope of financial irresponsibility and of abdicating the government's responsibility to control the financial system for the benefit of the Australian community as a whole. The Australian Democrats will be voting against this legislation. We will also reject, obviously, the second reading amendment that was moved by the opposition.

speech.speaker: Watson Sen J.O.W.

talk.start.para: —Before commencing my contribution tonight, I must declare an interest in the Commonwealth Bank and in the new shareholding on behalf of myself and my wife. The Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill 1993 before the Senate reduces the government's equity in the Commonwealth Bank from the current 70 per cent to a minimum of 50.1 per cent. The bill also provides for a one-off capital injection plus an on-going subsidy to the Commonwealth Development Bank to expand its lending activities to small business. The charter of the Commonwealth Development Bank is also amended to allow it to meet the full credit requirements of its small business proprietors, instead of being confined to the role of provider of supplementary finance as at present.

para.tab: The aborted sale of Qantas potentially left a huge hole in the federal government's finances, which had to be filled if this deficit was not to blow out beyond the already horrendous $16 billion or more that we have been saddled with during this financial year. As a result, the sale of the Commonwealth Bank has been brought forward to fill a gap which would otherwise have been left by the failure to sell Qantas.

The government's handling of this further float—this is the second we have had—of equity in the Commonwealth Bank has been botched from the outset. The government has done an appalling job in providing the market with appropriate information on the structure of the sale, which has led to under-informed, if not misinformed, trading in trading bank shares. In fact, so little information has been provided by this government that the Australian Stock Exchange took the unusual step of requesting from the Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, further details of the structure of the proposed sale so that the market could be reasonably informed. In particular, there was the issue of what rights existing shareholders would have to the new share issue, which obviously has an impact on the price of existing shares in the marketplace.

The response from the Minister for Finance was to advise that the proposed offer structure had not yet been determined and that the government would advise the Stock Exchange of its structure in due course. Further, Labor's inability to supply these and other details had led to the market for CBA shares being driven by speculation and inadequate information. The directors of the bank have been put in a very difficult situation since they are contractually obliged to immediately disclose any information that is necessary to ensure an informed market in CBA shares.

Of more pertinent concern to me, though, is the manner in which the government has decided to sell the shares. The government has opted against a firm underwritten price. This represents a gamble that could affect many people—I speak in particular on behalf of the small investors—since the government plans to make up to 65 per cent of the offer open to retail investors, with the balance allocated to a bidding process by international investors.

I am not saying that the percentages are wrong. I think the government has got that sort of thing right. Minimums of 35 per cent for institutional investors and 20 per cent for firm allocations to broker clients have been set aside. Existing shareholders have a guaranteed priority to an allocation of $3,000 in shares. If all shareholders exercise this right, it will account for a further 35 per cent, leaving a minimum of only 10 per cent for new public investors. I welcome the fact that the small investor has been considered in such a way, but I think an examination of the process being used is needed.

The structure adopted is unusual and groundbreaking. The government has elected not to have a floor or cap price. I can understand that the government is probably seeking to minimise the opportunity for arbitrage, but once the price has been set the arbitrager will move in and by that stage the tender will have been closed. While it is theoretically possible to issue shares in this manner, without a floor—or a cap in this case—there is no indicated pricing of any kind.

I am concerned that the obtaining of a premium price could be a remote outcome. Retail investors will bid not on price but in terms of dollars that they are prepared to commit. They will only find out how many shares they will have at the end of the process. This may be deemed a clever process because many shareholders think in terms of how much they can afford to invest rather than the value that it will bring to them. The retail investor has been encouraged to invest by being guaranteed a discount on top of any discount in terms of the market procedure by the outcome of the institutional bidding. In the case of $25,000 or more, I think the 25c discount is somewhat unfortunate. If the government were prepared to offer that arrangement to the small investors, I would be quite happy with it. In his second reading speech, the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) said:

speech.para: . . . the amendments contained in this bill will benefit a wide cross-section of the Australian population. Taxpayers will benefit from the proceeds of the sale, while the wider Australian public has a further opportunity to buy shares in one of Australia's premier financial institutions.

There is no doubt that it is one of Australia's great financial institutions. We all recognise that it is a premier institution. I acknowledge that the government is very anxious to maximise its revenue from the sale of 19 per cent of its investment in the Commonwealth Bank.

para.tab: I hope I can get a response from the minister on this matter because it is concerning a lot of small investors. In setting the price, which basically will be determined at the peak of the market—I think it has crashed through the 2,000 barrier in recent days—in terms of the small shareholders, particularly those who cannot afford to take 25,000 shares and get a 25c discount, I ask that we be assured that there will be a sufficient differential between the issue price and the market price so that in the medium term, when a market correction which will inevitably occur does take place, small investors who do not really have access to professional advice will not suffer a capital loss.

Undoubtedly, the government felt that it might have set the last price a little too low. Shareholders did quite nicely. I want to make sure that it does not go to the other extreme and set the issue price so close to the market that, in terms of a market correction, all these small investors who have been lured by the premier investment opportunities that have been stated do not make a loss in the medium term. I believe that its long term holding will be quite satisfactory and it will be a good investment, but in the long term a lot of us will be dead. I would hate to think that a lot of the small investors who do not have the opportunities to access a lot of money were being misled as a result of this activity. I would be very happy if the minister drew attention to this fact.

I am concerned at the bidding process by Australian international institutions effectively determining the price of the shares because these people can adjust the market to their own advantage. The other thing that I have some concerns with is a state government denial of revenue derived from such things as stamp duties as a result of this arrangement. The minister said:

speech.para: To avoid these issues the bill provides that the sale of the shares in the Commonwealth Bank and related transactions to the sale are to be exempted from state and territory taxes and charges.

This is an aspect that I do not think will be particularly attractive to the states. I think it is my duty as an opposition senator to express some concern about this aspect of the legislation. I think it is an unfortunate clause to be included. Nevertheless, at the end of the day I look forward to shares in the Commonwealth Bank being widely held, particularly by staff of the bank and small investors. Anything that can be done to increase the spread of Commonwealth Bank shares amongst the Australian population is to be welcomed. I again ask the minister whether in his summing-up he could respond to the issues that I have raised, particularly the setting of the price.

talker.name: Senator BOSWELL
talker.role: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

talk.start.para: —I enter this debate with some concern on behalf of the small business and primary industry communities. The Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill amends the Commonwealth Banks Act 1959. It reduces the Commonwealth shareholding in the bank from 70 per cent to 50.1 per cent. I have no objection to that, but there are other concerns that should be raised. The bill provides a one-off capital injection of $30 million in 1993-94 to the Commonwealth Development Bank to expand its lending to small business and also gives the bank an ongoing annual subsidy of $20 million to assist primary industry and small business. These measures are to lift the capacity of the bank to service the small business community.

para.tab: Due to the government's absolute failure to provide for small business, or any type of business for that matter, there were 16,800 bankruptcies last year, which was a record on a very high base the year before, which was a record on a very high base the year before that. Those sorts of statistics used to make headlines. Now they have become part of the overall mismanagement of the government. Very few small businesses are surviving. The ones that have gone through the mill because of the government's incompetence need all the assistance they can get.

The charter of the bank is to be extended to enable it to meet the full credit requirements of its business customers rather than to provide supplementary finance. There are 48,000 farmers, fishermen and small business people using the Commonwealth Development Bank as a last line of defence or a last lending institution. My concern is that, if the bank were able to provide full banking or credit facilities, it would be fundamental that the small business people, the farmers or the fishermen who were able to offer a first mortgage would be the people to receive the bank's first loans. The others—those who have a second and a third mortgage—would have to get in line. That has never been the case before.

What guarantees can we offer those 48,000 small businessmen and fishermen who have to have their requirements for top-up loans met? What other provisions are there to ensure that primary producers will have their banking needs met? Let me put the hypothetical example of two graziers applying for loans, one having a first mortgage on his property and asking for a top-up loan or a second or third mortgage from the Commonwealth Development Bank and the other able to offer the bank a first mortgage. It is probable that the bank would lend the second grazier the money—because he can offer the first mortgage. That is why Senator Campbell has moved the amendment.

The second part of the amendment he has moved is to ensure that the proposed changes to the charter of the Commonwealth Development Bank will not lead to the bank's moving away from its current role as a lender of last resort. That second reading amendment was moved in the lower house and I believe it was supported in the lower house. I am not quite sure whether that is the case. I hope the Democrats will support that amendment. I listened to Senator Spindler's contribution and I know he shares the concerns I am voicing now.

talk.start.para: —Yes, indeed; and we would if you had set out the second amendment separately.

—The amendment we are moving takes into consideration the valid concerns that Senator Spindler has expressed. The Commonwealth Development Bank has been in the market for a great number of years and has been providing a very useful service to people who have needed a lender of last resort.

para.tab: The manager of the development bank has given me his assurance that the bank will not be moving away from its original charter and that it will stand in that market as it always has, but with the addition of the $20 million annually and the $30 million injection that this bill will offer it. In fact, he explained to me that the bank will be able to provide a better service to the small business and farming community. I wish him well in that project. I think that gentleman was very genuine in telling me that is what he intends to do. Of course, if we lived in a perfect world that would probably happen, but when credit gets tight the person who has the best proposal to offer a bank obviously will get the limited funds that are available.

I am very concerned that the change of charter could lead to the removal on the part of some people who use this bank of one of their last methods of finance. As a senator who represents the primary industry areas of Queensland and the small business community, I believe that I should put these concerns on record. The only thing I can do is ask the Senate to support this amendment. I believe it will serve to keep the bank in line when it observes that the parliament of Australia through this amendment wishes to see the bank sticking to its original charter.

The development bank has proved a very useful means of finance to the community that not only provides people with a living but much of Australia's export earnings. It would be a great pity and shame if Australia were to lose this bank, which has provided facilities to so many people.

speech.speaker: Kemp Sen C.R.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak briefly on the Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill 1993 and to perhaps tackle a couple of issues that my colleagues did not cover. I say initially that it was most useful for Senator Spindler to draw the attention of the chamber to the history of the Commonwealth Bank. I treasure Australia's history and I was pleased that Senator Spindler enlightened us once again on the history of this bank.

para.tab: This is quite an historic occasion and indeed an historic bill. Who four or five years ago would have believed that the Labor Party would be presenting such a bill to this parliament? Senator McMullan is in the chamber and may well have been present for the Chifley speech in 1987. I know that Senator McMullan is interested in Australian political history and I am sure he will recall Mr Hawke saying then:

speech.para: What in the name of reason is the justification for breaking up and selling off the great and efficient national assets, like the Commonwealth Bank, Telecom, TAA and Qantas? As the people of Australia come to realise the extent of the economic and social vandalism proposed by our opponents. . .

The vandalism he was talking about of course was the selling off of the Commonwealth Bank, Australian Airlines and Qantas. In the rhetoric of the Labor Party, the true believers—they all get together and get rather excited about these things—Mr Hawke continued:
. . . it will be necessary for us, Ben Chifley's great heirs and successors, to keep fresh and green the memory, the example and experience of this great Australian.

As recently as 1987 we on this side of the chamber were being attacked for proposing the very policy which the government has brought before this chamber this evening. Whereas I do not agree with the conclusion of Senator Spindler, he has at least been consistent in relation to privatisation. He is one of the sole surviving Marxists in any parliament in the world. Senator Spindler has been a great constant in our life in this parliament. He has opposed the selling of assets such as Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank.

para.tab: We on our side all through the 1980s proposed that, in the interests of the Australian people, in the interests of service to Australians, it would be better for the Commonwealth Bank and indeed some of the other commercial assets that the government holds to be sold to the Australian people. But, no, the Australian Labor Party all through the 1980s said that this was social vandalism. It is quite an historic moment that this bill is brought before this parliament, not, I regret to say, by a Liberal and National party government but by a Labor government, so soon after the rhetoric of the Chifley lecture.

talk.start.para: —Hawke was right about his opponent though; it was his opponent who brought it forward.

—As Senator Campbell said, it was not quite Mr Hawke who brought it forward, although I must say that in the Commonwealth Banks Restructuring Bill of 1990 as distinct from this bill it was indeed the Hawke government which sold off the first tranche of Commonwealth Bank shares. So it is an historic moment. It is interesting that history will record that not one Labor Party backbencher stood up in the chamber and defended the policies which it pursued for such a long period of time.

para.tab: I thought that Senator Campbell put the case for privatisation extremely well and I would not query the approach that he took. Senator Watson raised a very sensible issue of the small shareholders involved. Senator Boswell raised a number of other social issues in relation to small business. Because no Labor Party member will rise in this chamber and speak on this bill, I will raise an issue which I would have thought any Labor Party member worth a cracker would have been on his feet about.

talk.start.para: —Where is Kim Carr?
—Senator Carr is one Labor Party member in particular. I want to speak briefly about a lot of union members who work for the Commonwealth Bank.
—Speak to your amendment.

—Firstly, I will speak about the people Senator Chris Evans should be concerned about—the 8,000 people being retrenched by the Commonwealth Bank and the forced redundancies in Victoria that have occurred as a result of the merge of the Commonwealth Bank and the State Bank of Victoria. I have drawn attention to the great broken promise of the Labor Party in privatising the Commonwealth Bank. I happen to support that; nonetheless, one has to acknowledge that the Labor Party, once again, has reversed its history; it has done a 180 degree turn in supporting a policy which, in recent memory, it so vigorously opposed.

para.tab: I have said this before and I will say it again: when the Commonwealth Bank and the State Bank of Victoria merged, assurances were given by Mrs Kirner and Mr Keating to the employees of the State Bank of Victoria. In a joint press release issued by Mrs Kirner and Mr Keating on 26 August 1990, Mrs Kirner said that clear undertakings had been received from the Commonwealth Bank that there would be no compulsory staff retrenchments resulting from the sale of the bank.

We have raised this matter with bank officers in a Senate standing committee hearing and we have received replies. We know that that promise to State Bank employees in Victoria was not kept. I would hope that when the minister at the table, Senator McMullan, who is here this evening, responds, he can make it clear whether the promise that Mr Keating and Mrs Kirner made to the State Bank employees in Victoria was a promise which he will acknowledge in this chamber. Can Senator McMullan explain to us why that promise was not kept? Senator McMullan has been blessed this evening in the chamber with the great advantage of very good advisers. I hope he will seek that advice and that he will be able to answer that question.

The second issue I wish to raise with Senator McMullan relates to yet another broken promise by Mr Keating. Not so long ago Mr Keating said that the time for large-scale retrenchments in industry had come to an end. Senator McMullan would remember that speech and I remember that speech. We learnt just after the election in April how convenient it was for the Commonwealth Bank to announce that 8,000 employees would be involved in the downsizing of the bank.

The issue of why the Commonwealth Bank board happened to delay that announcement until after the election was canvassed at a hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. Answers have been received—answers which I do not regard as satisfactory. We know that the Commonwealth Bank has a major retrenchment program. I do not dispute that, in view of the Commonwealth Bank becoming more competitive, it may have to retrench people. I draw the Senate's attention to the Prime Minister's complaint about private sector organisations downsizing. I would like Senator McMullan to seek advice on whether the announcement by the Commonwealth Bank of this massive downsizing program is in line with the policy announced by Mr Keating in a speech given two or three weeks after the election at the Institute of Directors.

The final point I raise with Senator McMullan relates to a complaint made to me by a constituent. I stress again that not only am I in favour of this bill and the amendments that my colleagues have moved, but I believe that we should go the whole hog and privatise the bank. I want to make it clear where I stand on this issue; although I thank Senator Spindler for giving us the history of the bank, I differ on where the bank should go from here on out. I ask Senator McMullan whether he could seek advice on the propriety of Mr Willis writing to Commonwealth Bank shareholders outlining the offer of shares which the bank was making. A constituent of mine saw this as a politicisation of the share offer and thought that the independence of the Commonwealth Bank board may have been compromised by that. I would like Senator McMullan to address that issue.

In conclusion, Mr Acting Deputy President, I put it to you that the Labor government has brought before this parliament an historic bill. I will support the government on this bill. During the 1980s and early 1990s we on our side received from the Labor Party venomous, silly, overstated, exaggerated abuse. I can remember standing on the street outside a branch of the Commonwealth Bank in St Kilda where Commonwealth Bank officers were handing out how-to-vote cards; they were encouraging passers-by not to vote for the coalition because, would you believe, they felt that the coalition would privatise the bank. How poorly they were advised by the Labor government. The Commonwealth Bank officers were not the first to be misled by a Labor government and they will not be the last. It is a lesson they should recall.

The questions I put to Senator McMullan are, in summary: what was the nature of the promise that was given by Mr Keating regarding compulsory retrenchments? Was the joint press release of Mr Keating and Mrs Kirner saying that there would be no compulsory retrenchments as a result of the merger of the Commonwealth Bank and the State Bank an accurate reflection of the promise and commitment made? Is the 8,000-strong massive retrenchment program of the Commonwealth Bank in line with the policy Mr Keating announced at the Institute of Directors soon after the election? What is the propriety of Mr Willis making an offer to potential purchasers of shares, rather than the offer coming from the Commonwealth Bank board? Does the government feel this may have compromised the apparent independence of the Commonwealth Bank board?

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to make a brief personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.

para.tab: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I have been called a Marxist by Senator Kemp. I have had occasion to draw his attention to the Oxford definition of a `Marxist' before; we went through the same exercise some time ago. The definition of `Marxist' in the Oxford dictionary includes `nationalisation of all industry'. I think I again need to draw Senator Kemp's attention to the fact that the Australian Democrats as a party—and I personally—are not in favour of nationalisation and that that particular designation is therefore wrong. To the extent that it implies concern for social justice, it is something of a badge of honour, but we must distinguish between that aspect of it and the means that, in the past, have been advocated for it. I repeat that that simply does not fit. Senator Kemp should take note of that; perhaps he will remember it now that he has been told twice.

speech.speaker: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

talk.start.para: —I will not insult the thoughtful contributions that Senators Campbell, Spindler, Watson and Boswell made by adverting too much to the comments that Senator Kemp made. I do welcome the fact that, apart from him, there were thoughtful contributions on matters about which there are strong views in this place. They are different views, but they are strong and legitimate views. I think they were well debated on the principle and some questions of detail, particularly by Senator Watson. I am not going to go to the level of detail that he might wish because, firstly, I am not sure that it is appropriate; secondly, we have an agreement to pass this bill and I wish not to abuse that agreement by speaking for too long.

para.tab: I gather from the indications that there is majority support for this bill. I welcome that. I understand the arguments advanced by those who have concerns, but it is important to reiterate that, at the end of this process, the Commonwealth Bank will remain a majority government-owned bank with the strengths and guarantees which flow from that. So I do not want to debate the privatisation question too much and I certainly do not think Mr Willis needs ethics advice from Senator Kemp.

Senator Watson asked some detailed questions about pricing. It is really a matter that has been dealt with, essentially, by the Department of Finance, but with the very best advice that we think we can get from outside. It is a judgment, on the balance, about the process of maximising the return for the Commonwealth. It is matter for judgment. Nobody can prove in advance that the judgment is correct. All we can say is that it has been taken responsibly on the basis of the best advice.

I understand the concern. I have seen some of the publicity that people have referred to, but I think that, from his remarks, Senator Watson also understands why it is being done that way. When we do something that is a little different, people get a bit apprehensive. I think, on balance, it is a fair method that looks like it will maximise the return for the Commonwealth. But it is something we will all want to watch, analyse and consider because this will not be the last time a matter such as this is considered and we will want to discuss it again. I have not got much more in the way of detail to add to that.

talk.start.para: —Could you take it on notice?

—If there is anything further to add, I will provide it. If the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) or the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) have some more information that they wish to provide, I will happily refer any advice they give to Senator Watson.

para.tab: I just want to make two points in response to the amendment. It has been moved thoughtfully and it warrants the courtesy of a response. I want to reiterate that the government firmly believes that having at least 50 per cent of one of Australia's major banks in public hands remains a worthwhile matter of public policy. It has desirable consequences for prudential controls and customer service, and we intend to pursue that policy. It has been our policy for a long time. We intend to retain it. Therefore, we have no further plan to sell our holding below the level of a government majority. We intend not to do that.

Senator Boswell, in particular, raised concern about the change to the Commonwealth Development Bank charter. I was not able to hear Senator Campbell's comments on that, although I understand from the nature of the amendment that he raised some similar issues. I do apologise to him that I did not pick up those things which he said on that debate, but I heard Senator Boswell speaking on it. I know that others expressed some concern. I think that the change to the Commonwealth Development Bank's charter is a significant plus for small business. It strengthens its capacity to provide the sort of assistance that is necessary.
Once again, change does cause apprehension. This is a body that people have turned to. I am not sure I like the phrase `lender of

speech.para: last resort'. It sounds a bit like certain faile Western Australians with whom I do not want to particularly make an analogy. I know the point that is being made. It is a place that you turn to when other institutions have not been able meet to your demands, and people do not want to see that capacity undermined. But it seems to me clear, although it is a proper concern to have and express, that the change to the charter does not change its current role as a lender of last resort.

para.tab: The bill will enable the development bank to continue to provide funds to businesses which should not otherwise be able to obtain funds. But, in contrast to the existing legislation, it adds to that the capacity for the bank to provide the full financing requirement, rather than only part of the requirement, so it can actually provide more rather than less. Therefore, I think it is a positive for the Commonwealth Development Bank and for small business, and I think it is an appropriately structured way to do it. It is a matter everybody will want to keep an eye on, but I think it is a plus and a positive for both the bank and small business. I support the bill and oppose the amendment. I commend the bill to the Senate.
Amendment negatived.

debate.title: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

para.tab: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

speech.speaker: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

talk.start.para: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum and move:

para.tab: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para:
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in
Hansard
.

para.tab: Leave granted.

The speech read as follows
—

speech.para: The purpose of this Bill is to introduce amendments to the following Acts within the primary industries and energy portfolio—
Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988 and the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (Administration) Act 1992,
Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1987 and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Act 1987,
Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee Act 1984, and the Meat Research Corporation Act 1985,
the Dairy Produce Act 1986,
the Fisheries Legislation (Consequential Provisions) Act 1991 and the Fisheries Management Act 1991,
the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989, the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991,
the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Power Act 1949 and the Wheat Marketing Act 1989.

The Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals amendments will enable the National Registration Authority to involve the public in determining the clearance of an agricultural or veterinary chemical product. The National Registration Authority's operations in respect of the clearance of chemical products are to be open and transparent and seen to be such. Similar provisions will also be included in the package of registration Bills to be introduced shortly and proposed to commence operation in July 1994.

The public's involvement will be facilitated by the National Registration Authority releasing a summary of its evaluation of a chemical product before making a determination. Also, the NRA will be able to seek the advice of certain organisations or persons by releasing confidential commercial information to assist in its evaluation of applications. However, precautions will be taken to ensure that trade secrets and certain information subject to possible commercial exploitation are safeguarded.

The National Registration Authority will be able to conduct public and private hearings for the purpose of obtaining comment on chemical products and will be required to notify the times and places for such hearings in daily newspapers throughout Australia.

Directors and staff of the National Registration Authority are exempt from suit in respect of the granting or refusal of clearance of a chemical product. These amendments will extend that exemption to the National Registration Authority itself.

The amendments to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (Administration) Act 1992 will enable the National Registration Authority to issue receipts in a more efficient manner and will enable the NRA to determine progressively conditions of service for staff transferred from the Public Service.

The Government has a commitment to remove all forms of discrimination in the formulation and administration of government policies and programs. One part of that commitment is removing the 65 year age limit which was imposed in many areas of public activity.

The amendments to the Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1987 and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Act 1987 will remove the maximum age limits for members and executive directors of these bodies to ensure that the best available people can be appointed to positions in the Corporations.

The Government's decisions on a national ecologically sustainable development strategy require the incorporation of ESD principles and priorities into the normal activities of Government decision making and administration. Within the primary industries and energy portfolio, that incorporation process involves—
the inclusion in enabling legislation of objectives focusing on ecologically sustainable development for research and development corporations;
ensuring that expertise in ecosystems management and conservation, as well as economic and social factors are taken into account when people are selected to serve on Corporation Boards; and

requiring these bodies to take ESD principles into account in determining priorities for allocation of funds; to report ESD related research, development and demonstration in annual reports and to report progress in achieving all of the Corporation's objectives, including the new ESD objectives.

The Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Act 1987 already makes provisions for the Board to have expertise in environmental and social factors. The amendments in this Bill implement the other components of the Government's strategy for the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation.

The amendments to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee Act 1984, the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Act 1987, the Meat Research Corporation Act 1985 and the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 will achieve these objectives.

The amendment to the Dairy Produce Act 1986 will remove any uncertainty about the operation of the arrangements under which manufacturers of exported dairy products currently receive market support payments which are financed by a levy on all milk production. On behalf of the Commonwealth the Australian Dairy Corporation administers the market support scheme which includes what is known as an `import offset' arrangement.

Under the arrangement recipients of market support payments must declare purchases of imported dairy products. When these are `like products' to a firm's exports, the firm is liable to pay the Corporation an amount equal to the market support payment on an equivalent volume of exports. In effect, payments are made on net exports rather than total exports.

The purpose of the import offset arrangement is to prevent companies from receiving market support payments on exported product (which would otherwise have been sold on the domestic market) and then importing the same type of product for domestic sale.

If the arrangement is not enforceable, the Australian Dairy Corporation would be required to make payments on the gap between net and total exports (ie for the volume of imports) and in recent years the effectiveness of the market support scheme would have been reduced by between $1 million and $2 million each year.

Because of uncertainty concerning the basis of the import offset arrangement the Corporation has not applied the arrangement for the last two seasons. This legislation removes any uncertainty and allows the Corporation to proceed to apply the arrangement for 1991-92, 1992-93 and the remainder of the life of the market support scheme.

The International Dairy Federation's World Congress will provide Australian dairy producers with increased exposure to international technological developments, and allow them to develop closer working relationships with those at the forefront of the world dairy industry. Australian industry will have the opportunity to demonstrate that it is efficient and that there are positive effects from this Government's policy of reducing both assistance and trade distortions.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has agreed to allow the industry to use the Dairy Industry Fund to underwrite the World Congress. The Fund is presently used for Australian contributions to the International Dairy Federation, the organisation under whose auspices the World Dairy Congress is held. This Bill includes an amendment of the Dairy Produce Act 1986 to enable the use of the Industry Fund to underwrite the Australian hosting of the 1994 Congress.

There is a long-standing agreement between Government and industry that $1 million would be made available to underwrite the Congress. It is expected that significant income will be obtained from sponsorships and other sources and that expenditure from the Dairy Industry Fund will eventually be reimbursed from Congress' proceeds.

The amendment to the Fisheries Legislation (Consequential Amendments) Act 1991 extends the period during which Part IVA of the Fisheries Act 1952 continues in force. Part IVA enables the Commonwealth to enter into arrangements with the States and Northern Territory to vary the jurisdictional arrangements for identified fisheries in accordance with the Offshore Constitutional Settlement. These provisions are complemented by State and Northern Territory legislation. Similar powers have been included in the new Fisheries Management Act 1991 but these provisions cannot commence until State and Territory legislation has been amended.

Initial expectations were that these changes would be finalised by 3 February 1994. This timetable has not been achieved. The amendments will extend the operation of Part IVA for an additional 12 month period to enable the necessary State and Territory legislation to be put in place. Part IVA of the Fisheries Act 1952 will be repealed when all complementary State and Territory legislation is in place.

The amendments to the Fisheries Management Act 1991 reflect the original intention that seasonal and other closures may be authorised under a Management Plan and provide greater flexibility in the type and number of fishing concessions a fisherman may hold.

The Fisheries Management Act 1991 which commenced on 3 February 1992 provided the new Australian Fisheries Management Authority (AFMA) with a firm foundation to undertake the Commonwealth's fisheries management responsibilities. In particular the Act established a new system of Statutory Fishing Rights and provided for the making of Fishery Management Plans to be the primary instrument for managing Australia's commercial fisheries.

The Act provides general powers for AFMA to make Management Plans and create and issue various types of fishing concessions. The success of this approach relies on the certainty that Management Plans, rights issued in accordance with those Plans, and any other action taken under a Plan are fully supported by the law.

Recent legal advice indicates that the provisions of the Act may not fully support the level of flexibility needed to implement some fishery management arrangements. Rather than leave the issue uncertain and open to different interpretations, these amendments put beyond doubt the matters that may be included in a Plan.

Statutory Fishing Rights were created to give greater security to fishermen. For fishermen to have confidence in the arrangements there must be unambiguous provisions to support the issue and holding of the widest range of Statutory Fishing Rights that may be required under a Plan. Provision is made for a fisherman to hold a number of Statutory Fishing Rights as a discrete package of Rights which authorises a particular fishing activity. Examples are combinations of quotas to take various species of fish or specified combinations of fishing gear or boat characteristics such as size or engine power. Provision is also made for the smooth transition of existing fishing rights in fisheries subject to Management Plans, to the new Act.

The amendments to the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 and the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991 are consequential to the establishment of the Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation and the related forest industries research levy and charge Acts.

The amendments reflect changed funding arrangements for the Corporation of $1 Commonwealth for every $2 from industry rather than the $1 for $1 currently provided in the Act. The basis of the changed funding arrangements for the Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation arises from the structure of the industry—half the industry has a primary industry focus, while the other half has a manufacturing orientation. Commonwealth funding is intended to match the rural half of the industry contribution, consistent with arrangements for research and development in other rural industries.

The amendments will also provide that revenue derived from charges under the Forest Industry Research Import Charge Act 1993 will be directed to research and development of relevance to the timber importing industry.

The amendments to the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991 will enable the forest industries levies and charges to be collected under the same arrangements which apply to the collection of other primary industries levies and charges.

The Bill also includes a minor amendment to the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Power Act 1949 to empower the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Authority to invest surplus funds in specified classes of securities without the need to obtain prior Ministerial approval for each transaction. The amendment will avoid the delays which can occur while obtaining this approval and associated unnecessary losses. It furthers the Government's objective of reducing controls over day-to-day operations as part of its wider Government Business Enterprise reform to deliver best possible performance.

The main amendment to the Wheat Marketing Act 1989 is to correct an anomaly in the Act to ensure that it provides the necessary constitutional power for the States to confer functions on the Australian Wheat Board to allow it to conduct intra-state trade in grain and grain products. Changes are also being made to improve efficiencies in the operation of the Wheat Board.

Doubts had been raised as to whether the Commonwealth Act presently confers the necessary powers to enable the Wheat Board to conduct intra-state trade in any grains other than wheat even though State Acts have purported to confer those powers since the commencement of the revised wheat marketing arrangements on 1 July 1989. In order to validate the Wheat Board's intra-state grain trading operations these amendments will be made retrospective to that date.

The proposed amendments in other areas include provisions to allow the Wheat Board flexibility to make adjustments to pool return payments based on variety, quality, transport, storage and handling costs and other similar matters which are unable to be accurately specified in the delivery contract, so as to ensure that growers within a pool are treated fairly in respect of the wheat they deliver.
This Bill also corrects a number of minor operational deficiencies which have been identified by the Wheat Board as restricting its commercial and pooling operations.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and I present the Explanatory Memorandum.

speech.para: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1993-94

This Bill seeks appropriations of the Consolidated Revenue Fund in 1993-94 totalling $5,190.8 million. Of this amount, $2,422.2 million is authorised by the Supply Act (No. 2) 1993-94. The balance of $2,768.6 million will be authorised by this Bill.

APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1993-94

The total amount sought is $126.6 million. This Bill includes for the first time an amount of $0.2 million for a Provision for Running Costs Borrowings for the parliamentary departments under the control of the Speaker and the President of the Senate. This provision mirrors the Provision for Running Costs Borrowings included in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) to facilitate borrowings against a future year's running costs appropriation.
Details of the proposed expenditures are set out in Schedule 2 of the Bill. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The speech read as follows
—

speech.para: This Bill is a machinery financing measure to enable certain defence expenditures to be met from the Loan Fund rather than the Consolidated Revenue Fund and to supplement the moneys available to the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

Legally, expenditure from the Consolidated Revenue Fund cannot exceed the moneys available to that Fund. Successive Governments have adopted the practice of introducing a Loan Bill to authorise the issue of moneys from the Loan Fund to meet expenditure that have been appropriated by the Parliament, but for which insufficient funds are available in the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

The purpose of this Bill is to make provision for the financing of the prospective deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund. The Budget deficit of $16 billion for 1993-94 gives rise to a prospective deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund about $7 billion higher. This situation arises because appropriations from that Fund include various items which are functionally classified as financing transactions rather than outlays, and thus do not affect the Budget outcome. These items include payments to the National Debt Sinking Fund to redeem or repurchase Commonwealth securities and superannuation payments made by the Commonwealth on behalf of public trading enterprises.

The Bill provides authority for the Loan Fund to meet defence expenditures incurred after the passage of the Bill that would otherwise have been met from the Consolidated Revenue Fund, and to supplement the Consolidated Revenue Fund so that it can meet its other commitments. The Bill also provides the authority to raise loans to cover these payments from the Loan Fund.

Except for loan raising expenses, which are currently estimated at $13.4 million for 1993-94, the Bill does not authorise expenditures additional to those already appropriated, or currently before the Parliament. I emphasise that the Bill does not in any way impinge on the prerogative of the Parliament to appropriate moneys, but simply provides the means to finance expenditures previously approved and appropriated by the Parliament.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
