—Order! It being almost 10.30 p.m., I put the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

speech.speaker: O'Chee Sen W.G.

talk.start.para: —During question time today I asked Senator Cook some questions in relation to the hearings of Estimates Committee A which examined the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. I asked those questions because there is grave concern about what is happening in AQIS and with the management of AQIS. Senator Brownhill and I and other honourable senators, such as Senator Boswell and other members of the committee—I notice that Senator Crane is in the chamber, as is Senator Panizza, who has taken an interest in AQIS in the past—are all very concerned about what is happening in terms of management and accountability.

para.tab: Senator Brownhill and I raised particular criticisms in relation to AQIS which can be summarised as accountability and scrutiny. There is a clear obligation on us in this place to ensure that public administration gives the taxpayers value for their tax paying dollar. Section 27 of the Public Service Act sets out very clearly that the Public Service Board must devise `means for effecting economies and promoting efficiency in the management and working of departments'. It also says:

speech.para: All officers who incur or authorise expenditure shall exercise due economy.

These are lofty sentiments which we hope the Public Service abides by. Senator Brownhill and I have been attempting to ascertain whether this has happened in the case of AQIS—a government department operating on full cost recovery from its users, who are mainly farmers or those involved in the processing of primary industry products. Our attention was drawn to the matter because recently there have been two separate audit reports relating to AQIS activities and both have found inefficiencies and unsatisfactory management practices.

para.tab: Our interest was further heightened when an internal review of AQIS SES travel, albeit one that was considerably more curtailed than envisaged by those who commissioned it, discovered numerous irregularities and other actions which are contrary to the terms of the Public Service Act involving the senior executive service within AQIS. For some reason that we simply have been unable to discover, this review was wound up with only nine months travel activity monitored, despite discovering hundreds of instances of prima facie irregularities and breaches of the rules.
The progress report of the initial review stated:

speech.para: With AQIS's move to commercialisation and with full cost recovery a reality for industry we need to know what the actual costs of travel are.
It went on to say:
There is overwhelming evidence to suggest that the handling of payments, acquittals . . . general record keeping . . . is woefully deficient.

Surprisingly, however, at the estimates hearing and in light of those statements, we found that there is no budget for travel within AQIS. Coming on top of the statement about woefully deficient record keeping, this is of great concern. The irregularities include—I list these for the benefit of the Senate—travel without authorisation, authorisation for travel by officers when they are not in Canberra to do so or when they are overseas on the date on which they are supposed to be signing the authorisation, officers appearing not to have been where their travel documentation says they were, and overuse of mobile phones for personal use.

para.tab: The final draft of the management review suggested that there was `serious and consistent obtaining of benefits to which recipients are not entitled'. It went on to say that there is `lack of management' and `consistent disregard for the Secretary's instruction'. It detailed extensively the breaches—major and minor—of every SES officer. It produced various drafts to chart usage and it produced travel summaries. The review concluded:

speech.para: There is overwhelming evidence to suggest that the handling of payments, acquittal . . . general record keeping and accessibility to these records is extremely deficient.

It noted that one officer's travel records could not be ascertained for most of the nine months that were examined for the simple reason that the Mastercard files were missing. It noted that the weekly report to the secretary to the department of AQIS SES movements omitted, on a regular basis, details of overseas trips of some weeks duration involving several officers. It noted the frequent occurrences of travel remaining unauthorised or being authorised subsequent to the travel. That is not supposed to happen. It noted such things as the head of the service spending 46 per cent of his time travelling outside the office. It noted that this same officer requested his travel documents back from the review team during its review and it is suggested that he altered them—or persons altered them on his behalf—on several occasions. They are very serious matters.

para.tab: The review noted that one officer undertook a private trip to Dublin after an authorised visit to North and South America and there was no documentation on file to authorise the change, although the travel allowance was calculated to match the revised schedule. That is rather strange. Neither was this additional leg of the trip notified to the secretary, as is required in the guidelines. The same officer had repeated instances of claiming for taxis in cities he was no longer in or claiming airport parking fees when he took a taxi to the airport. This is the same officer who had no Mastercard files for any period after June 1991.

We also saw evidence of a senior officer soliciting money from the private sector to attend an overseas conference for which he was quite happy to admit he had no automatic entitlement for financial assistance from AQIS. Yet it also appears that he subsequently did attend, on pay, and claimed travelling allowance. The review recommended that the SES officers have their travel benefits independently investigated.

At the same time as this internal review was being conducted, another unit of AQIS—the internal investigations unit—was also asked to look at SES use of Commonwealth plated cars and domestic travel. This internal investigation team also experienced difficulties with SES officers removing original travel documentation and returning it amended. I understand that there is substantial evidence to show the documents before and after they were removed, and they are not one and the same.
The internal investigation unit submitted a progress report on its assignment, saying:

speech.para: . . . suffice to say that at this point we have established examples of administrative irregularities and what I would term blatant criminal fraud.
That is a fairly serious allegation. I asked the author of that document whether he still stood by those comments and he said that he did.

para.tab: Subsequent to this progress report being submitted—this is an important point—the unit experienced difficulty in having its authorised officer status maintained. Indeed, it had an officer removed from the unit—there were only three officers in the unit to start off with—notwithstanding that it had a number of assignments to undertake, requiring full staffing capacity. The officer who was removed was the linchpin of the unit because he had 22 years of investigative experience with the Australian Federal Police. The words that we heard from the head of the internal investigations unit at the hearings was that it emasculated the unit.

The head of the unit complained about those restrictions but, unfortunately, to no avail. It appears that there was an internal departmental review of the methodology and findings of the travel review but it has not been sighted. The secretary to the department then appointed another authorised officer from outside the service to investigate the issue of SES travel irregularities. This officer then proceeded to undertake this review, accepting written documentation from officers without ever accessing the original travel documentation to ascertain their veracity. He concluded that there were no indications of irregularities. He argued:

speech.para: . . . misconduct should only be construed if officers make significant personal financial gains from failing to comply with travel conditions.

I will come back to that in a minute. I suggest that what he wrote is a personal interpretation, his own view, which is not based on any departmental ruling, and it is quite simply wrong. It is wrong in law and, more importantly, it is wrong in the practice of that service. It fails to take into consideration the necessity for senior officers to adhere to a standard of professional care and skill, as outlined in the discipline manual.

para.tab: It has been put to me that there are numerous flaws in the analysis that that review officer did. That analysis, the findings and the way in which the SES officers were treated are hypocritical when one recalls that the same department—that is, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, because AQIS is an outrider of that department—took a junior officer to the Magistrates Court in Canberra in September 1991, which is the same time these irregularities were supposed to be taking place, and prosecuted her for altering a sick leave form for a personal financial benefit $71.83. As far as the quarantine service is concerned, it seems that all animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others.

The officer suggested that the officers who undertook the original travel management review were at fault and that they had denied natural justice to those they had examined. This is a bit of a furphy because they were asked to do an investigation and go through the documentation. They were not making allegations; it was not a trial. They were outlining what had happened and what they had found. The comment made by that officer was very strange, as far as I am concerned.

I do not know why or how this authorised senior officer came to the conclusions he did; I also do not know why the officer who came home from Washington via Dublin did not have his travel plans authorised. I do not know why this same officer's Mastercard files are missing. At the last estimates hearings we tried to find out—goodness knows we tried! We provided a forum for those officers to defend themselves, but the minister denied them that opportunity by refusing to allow them to answer questions and by refusing us the opportunity to ask them questions, and that is very important.

Natural justice has been denied, but not by us or the review team, as the minister has accused in the estimates hearings; it has been denied by the minister himself. Public interest has been denied by not allowing the chamber to undertake a thorough review of what appears to be a most unsatisfactory situation, a situation that appears to have continued for some time.

As I pointed out in question time today, contrary to the assertions of the minister, the Australian National Audit Office did not give AQIS a clean bill of health. In fact, the evidence we had that morning was that the Australian National Audit Office did not find it satisfactory at all. The officers of the Australian National Audit Office were not happy with the task that they had been given.

What is the department and the minister trying to hide? The public has a right to know why the original review was cut short in what the minister himself admits was the review's infancy and why AQIS's internal investigations unit was gutted to render it ineffective. We need to know why and how the authorised officer came to make two reports which were not released and which contained all the hallmarks of either innocence or possibly fraudulent negligence. We need to examine the implications of the audit report and ascertain why the cases of misconduct have not been proceeded with. I remind honourable senators of that junior officer who altered her personal sick leave form for a personal financial benefit $71.83 and who ended up in the Magistrates Court.

AQIS is about to embark on a major rationalisation of staff. It is an overdue clean-out of a department that has for far too long drained the public purse. But how can any department tell its workers that they need to become more efficient when the officers at the very top, the officers who are directing that efficiency, are failing to adhere to the department's or the service's own guidelines? How can the department move to full cost recovery when it does not even know how much it should be spending on travel and when it apparently does not even care whether or not the travel is approved?

I remind honourable senators that, unless we scrutinise this department, the people who pay the cost—the users—have no say at all. We have user-pays, but we do not have user-says. We are dealing here with public money in a department that bases its charges and costs on full recovery from the rural sector. It does not base its charges and costs on what that sector can afford to pay; rather it bases them on the amount it needs to rake in to meet the costs of things that it wants to spend its money on.

We are dealing here with very senior levels of the Public Service who, like Caesar, think they should be above reproach. All we have sought to do is ascertain whether there is any substance to the irregularities that have been uncovered by the original review. We are talking about integrity and principle. Indeed, it is our job and our obligation as senators to ensure that the interests of our constituents are being served and that the costs they incur in dealing with this department are fair and equitable.

I have in my possession many documents which I could table that go into much detail about those travel irregularities. Do not let it be said that I am denying anybody natural justice. I have pages and pages of documents which list name after name. They were not tabled in the estimates hearing and at this point in time I will not table them here in this chamber. But honourable senators can see this weighty tome. There is a proper place for this to be discussed and I believe it should be at the supplementary hearings of the estimates committee. The officers should have the opportunity to answer for themselves. If not, it must be properly addressed in another committee at another place. That is why I am withholding these documents.

There are, however, documents that I seek the leave of the Senate to table, and they are as follows: an AQIS progress report on review of AQIS travel in 1991-92, which is AQIS minute dated 3 November 1992, authored by K. Rush and S. O'Shea; the AQIS executive board meeting number: review of AQIS travel by K. Rush, which is undated; the AQIS SES travel review minute to Mr Core, the Acting Secretary to the Department, authored by Rush, O'Shea and Jones, which is some 19 pages plus attachments and dated 12 March 1993; the AQIS executive board agenda item 5 meeting 2/93: travel review 19 March 1993 cover page, which is seven pages plus financial management instruction; and, finally, a letter to Mr Ken Murphie of the Cold Storage Association from Mr P. Corrigan of AQIS dated 3 March 1992.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I thank all honourable senators in this chamber for their assistance and their willingness to hear this matter out. This matter is not concluded, however. This matter requires proper investigation. I hope that the Senate, now being apprised of the facts, will see that its duty is done and ensure that these matters are examined in a parliamentary committee so that the truth can be ascertained, AQIS can be repaired, the difficulties can be rectified and we can have an efficient quarantine and inspection service. I thank the Senate.

—This afternoon, while I was absent from the Senate on other duties, a bill dealing with the wine tax was debated. I am very keen to have placed briefly on the record my concern about this legislation because it would stand to have a major effect on the fledgling wine industry in Tasmania, which is the state I represent.

para.tab: I draw to the Senate's attention the fact that about 40 to 50 wineries have been set up in Tasmania in the past 30 years, many of them in very recent years. About $9 million worth of wine is produced in a year at wholesale value and the retail value of that wine is about $15 million. About three-quarters of the wine is sold in Tasmania, about 20 per cent is sold to the mainland and about five per cent is exported. So it is a very fledgling export industry, but it has great potential for the future.

The wine industry certainly already has great significance for Tasmanian tourism and the hospitality industries, because it complements the image which Tasmania has built up so carefully in recent years in the production of fine foods. Fine wines go very well with fine foods when it comes to selling an image of quality for Tasmania.

There are around 100 full-time staff and between 300 and 400 casual and part-time employees in the industry in Tasmania. The important thing to remember is that most of those workers are in rural areas where we already have high unemployment. In some parts of Tasmania, youth unemployment is around 40 per cent. If this legislation were to go through, the impact of these extra job losses on Tasmania would be horrific.

It is ironic that the secretary of the ACTU, Mr Kelty, was in Tasmania only last week looking at issues of regional development, employment and unemployment. At the same time the federal government is wilfully trying to put measures in place which will throw another 300, 400 or 500 people out of work. It is beyond belief that on the one hand it could do one thing and on the other quite the opposite.

This proposed tax increase would affect Tasmania more than almost any other state, as our wines are very expensive because they are produced on a small scale. If ever the term `boutique wine' were correct, it certainly is correct in relation to most of the wineries in my state. This proposed tax hike would put between $1.50 and $2.50 on top of bottle shop prices. It is just beyond the pale for people to expect to pay that for wines that are already pretty expensive for proper reasons.

The industry is really very aware of the price barriers. Wines are already being carefully priced according to those barriers. The problem for the industry is that the increase would push the purchasing price over the top and Tasmanian wines would be left on the shelf. As I said earlier, it is a fledgling industry that is capital intensive and no one vineyard yet has its business stabilised.

The national estimate of the effect of the tax is a sales drop of 15 per cent, but we believe that in Tasmania that would probably be higher. I believe that no vineyard in Tasmania could cope with that effect.

The government has argued that winegrowers should develop the export market, but I believe that at this stage that is a dream for Tasmania. As I have said already, only five per cent of our wines are exported and growers are not yet in a financial position to develop an overseas market. It is early days yet for most of them, much as they might like to do so when they get on a firmer footing.

We must remember that it takes about seven years to sell wine from this year's cuttings. The government's argument that wine should be taxed at the same rate as lemonade is quite ridiculous. It is an insult to the people who are trying to produce quality wines. We all know that lemonade and beer are produced today and can be sold tomorrow. That is quite irrelevant to the economics and the realities of the wine industry.

We have huge potential in Tasmania for a fine wine industry, including an export push at the proper time. But this wine tax would have killed off this potential. We must remember that the people who have gone into these vineyards and wineries have put all their savings, hopes and dreams into a fine wine industry in our state. They should be supported, not thwarted. I urge the government to accept the will of the people as evidenced in the Senate vote today.

Unfortunately, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) has threatened the imposition of an excise if this bill were to be rejected by the Senate. That threat is disgraceful and intimidatory. The opposition is committed to rejecting that excise if the Treasurer proceeds with his obscene threat.

speech.speaker: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

talk.start.para: —Earlier tonight the Senate effectively defeated the 55 per cent wine tax hike by returning it to the other place with the request that it be removed from the sales tax bills. I want to raise a couple of issues which I hope the members in the other place will carefully consider in dealing with that request and, it is to be hoped, accepting it. I refer to the issues of tax equity and international competitiveness.

para.tab: In the face of overwhelming evidence of the detrimental effect on the wine industry of an extra 55 per cent increase in sales tax on its investment, employment potential and export growth, the only defence which the government can offer, apart from shonky figures and analysis, is the need for tax equity. But unlike the federal Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), the wine industry knows its grapes. It knows that the Treasurer's rationale for the 55 per cent tax hike is unfounded.

Among the fanciful claims to support the Treasurer's view that tax equity demands this impost occur are as follows. There is the claim that Penfolds Grange Hermitage be taxed at the same rate as lemonade; that the previous tax structure discriminates against other alcoholic beverages; that the previous structure ignores the pre-eminent turnover and employment position of the brewing industry; and that it ignores the socioeconomic consumption patterns regarding different alcoholic beverages. All these claims are false and have been shown and demonstrated to be such by the wine industry in publicly available evidence, of which the government must be well aware. The facts to support the Treasurer are very scarce on the ground, as indeed will be new vineyards if the government, with its majority in the other place, persists with this tax.

The theory of tax equity requires that like industries bear similar tax imposts. To say that wine should be taxed at similar levels to brandy, beer or spirits begs the question as to whether they are indeed like industries. They all produce alcoholic beverages, but a logical comparison beyond that suggests that they are not the same.

The beer industry relies on raw materials with short production lead times. Crops, such as barley and hops, are sown and reaped on an annual basis. Beer is comprised mostly of water to which those raw materials are added. The raw materials of spirits are essentially waste products.
In contrast, grapevines, the raw material source for wine, require up to seven years from planting to adequate grape produc

speech.para: tion. So the supply tap cannot be turned on and off annually at the whim of government tax policy without doing severe damage to grape growers, not to mention winemakers.

para.tab: Another contrast is that beer production is essentially big business, with some exceptions, such as Coopers in South Australia. Wine production is essentially through many small businesses, although there are again some big business exceptions. But by and large, on the one hand, breweries are big business and, on the other hand, wineries are small business. So these and other differences destroy the tax equity arguments.

The second issue of importance to the wine industry is international competitiveness. This Keating Labor government talks repetitively and quite correctly about the need for Australia to become internationally competitive. But in reality it only gives lip-service to the creation of that competitiveness. International competitiveness is not just about having product competition in the domestic market, better investment and better labour productivity and so on; it is also about having an internationally competitive tax system. The government has steadfastly refused to establish this.

On the contrary, it is heading in exactly the opposite direction with this wine tax. Introducing greater equity between the taxation treatment of wine on the one hand and beer, brandy and other spirits on the other flies directly in the face of best international practice. I seek leave to incorporate in
Hansard
a table detailing the relative tax treatment of wine, brandy and spirits in the major European producing countries.
Leave granted.

The document read as follows
—

speech.para: COMPARATIVE TAXATION TREATMENT OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES IN EUROPE
COUNTRY BEVERAGE EXCISE V.A.T
SPAIN Wine Nil Nil
Spirits $9.42/ltr 15%
FRANCE Wine $0.06/ltr 18.6%
Spirits $21.11/ltr 18.6%
Brandy $12.15/ltr 18.6%
GREECE Wine Nil 18%
Spirits $9.59/ltr 18%
ITALY Wine Nil 12%
Spirits $9.27/ltr 19%
LUXEMBOURG Wine Nil 12%
Spirits $18.00/ltr 15%
PORTUGAL Wine Nil 5%
Spirits $11.72/ltr 16%
GERMANY Wine Nil 15%
Spirits $24.06/ltr 15%

talk.start.para: —I thank the Senate. All these countries, with the exception of France, completely exempt wine from excise. French excise on wine represents only 0.3 per cent of the excise on spirits. Even value added tax, which like a GST is uniformly applied at retail level, is less for wine in a number of these countries. This reinforces the argument that a wholesale sales tax, which already in Australia applies to different goods at different rates, at the wholesale stage in Australia should most definitely give preference to wine. Reference to this table clearly shows the strong preference given to wine by our competitors in the international marketplace.

para.tab: In these countries wine gets far better tax treatment than in Australia with our pre-budget tax structure, let alone what it will become under the tax hike rejected today in the Senate. Quite simply, every successful wine exporting country treats the industry preferentially, as against other alcoholic beverages, in terms of taxation.

On the other hand, countries which fail to do this have destroyed the export potential of their industry. New Zealand is a prime example of this. Investment and expansion for export has dried up since New Zealand changed its tax structures to bring so-called equity between alcoholic beverages. Its export potential has not been realised as a direct consequence of this. It is one of the few areas where New Zealand has ignored international best practice and, in contrast to its resultant success with other commodities and products, it has suffered the consequences. So international best practice and competition demand that this tax hike be rejected, and I trust that members in the other place will see the wisdom of the Senate's decision this evening.

Before concluding, I wish to turn my attention to the consequences of the legislation passed today to correct anomalies in the motor vehicle import by-laws to prevent certain vehicle importers reclaiming duty paid and, therefore, contrary to the intent of the government's motor vehicle plan, effectively allowing vehicles in duty free. As my colleague Senator Ferguson indicated during the lunch time debate on this legislation, the opposition reluctantly accepted it, despite its retrospective features, to protect the integrity of the car plan. However, we are highly critical of the sloppy drafting of earlier regulations which made it necessary.

I wish to draw attention to certain consequences that will arise now that legislation has been passed. Senator Schacht commented earlier that he still did not have a response from the Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, regarding the refund of application fees to the companies which lodged applications for customs duty refunds. The government's steadfast refusal, prior to the correction of the anomaly by today's legislation being passed, to refund these fees is unacceptable.

talk.start.para: —You can't refund outright.

—Under the by-law provisions each application for a refund of duty requires a lodgment fee of $200 from the applicant. All companies which have sought refunds under this loophole have therefore paid to the government $200 for each and every separate application.

para.tab: In the case of Volvo, the major applicant, it has lodged 271 applications costing it $54,200. While we accept the retrospective closing of the loophole to deny it some $10 million in duty refunds, I believe it is unacceptable that Volvo should be financially penalised for lodging applications under the law as it stood prior to this amendment. While on this occasion we accept action being taken to prevent the company obtaining an unintended windfall gain of $10 million, we do not accept that it should lose $54,200 in application fees.

Had the by-law been correctly written at the time Volvo imported these vehicles, it would never have lodged the refund application and paid $54,200 in lodgment fees. Volvo is therefore morally entitled to a refund of these lodgment fees. As the minister interjected a few moments ago, there is no provision in the existing legislation for these fees to be refunded.

I am pleased that on a unanimous multiparty basis, the Senate standing committee that examined this legislation, prior to its passage in the Senate earlier today, recommended that an ex gratia payment be made to all applicants refunding their lodgment fees. I also welcome Minister Schacht's acquiescence in agreeing to approach the Minister for Finance to provide that ex gratia payment. However, I regret that as yet, as he indicated today, he does not have a response from the Minister for Finance to that request.

It is essential that Minister Willis agree to Minister Schacht's request. If he refuses, the passage of this legislation today will not only leave a very sour taste in the mouth of the opposition but also, I believe, of all members of the Senate committee who unanimously passed that recommendation.

I also want to raise a further concern which came to light with regard to the car plan in evidence to the committee hearing. It was claimed by a witness that further loopholes exist in the by-laws allowing any manufacturer to import vehicles duty free, virtually without limit. Customs officials denied this, so clarification was sought. However, Minister Schacht's subsequent letter providing this clarification in effect confirms the claim of the witness. The relevant part of the minister's letter said:

speech.para: The volume of goods imported by the participants under its determination is monitored by plan administration,
. . . As volume entitlements are reached, participants voluntarily discontinue imports under the determination in accordance with agreed plan arrangements.
. . . The plan administration audits volumes regularly and may revoke determinations should the voluntary discontinuance referred to above not occur.

In other words, the volume of duty free imports allowed to a manufacturer is not directly controlled by the by-laws. It is a voluntary action by the manufacturer undertaking such imports. If the volume imported exceeded the duty free entitlement under the export credits accrued, the only action the government could take would be to revoke the determination allowing those imports. That is, a further initiative is required by the government to prevent such an occurrence. We cannot rely on the immediate effect of law.

para.tab: This raises the question: what if a manufacturer decided it no longer required the benefit of that determination for whatever reason it might have? Without the certainty of law, what is to prevent it importing vehicles duty free, willy-nilly and then subsequently being willing to sacrifice its determination.

Under the present voluntary arrangements, the government is at best relying on the goodwill of manufacturers and, at worst, its own capacity to blackmail them to control duty free imports. In the light of the experience surrounding the need for the legislation that was passed today, this is hardly acceptable. I believe the government should take a long hard look at this situation. I warn the minister that the government should not come back to the Senate again with another piece of retrospective legislation—relating to the by-law anomaly that was corrected today—and seek the opposition's support if a problem emerges with regard to this issue that I have raised in the latter part of remarks. Given the experience we have had and given the warning given to the government, it would be very hard pressed to gain our support.

debate.sub1.title: Public Accounts Committee: Midford Paramount Report

talk.start.para: —I want to report on two developments that have occurred in the last 48 hours concerning the increasingly distressing saga of the aftermath of the Midford Paramount report. Yet another of the directors of the company concerned has been hospitalised. He is very ill, due to the stress and strain of what is now nearly 10 months since the Public Accounts Committee report was brought down. It was reported to me today that the health of one of the other people involved is only just being sustained by his local church and prayer. One of the other persons I have mentioned from time to time is so close to total collapse that he has almost given up.

para.tab: I understand that since I last spoke on this matter a week or 10 days ago, there has been some movement and some attempt to speed up the process. But this stands, as I have said before, as a damnation of the inhumanity of the bureaucracy when it comes to righting wrongs that have been perpetrated by the bureaucracy against individual Australians. If any of these people die before this matter is determined, then the responsibility for the death or bankruptcy—or both—of these individuals will have to hang on the consciences of those people who simply will not respond to what the parliament and a committee of the parliament has determined after full and thorough research and evaluation. They need to bring some justice to people who have suffered in a way that no ordinary Australian should be forced to suffer at the hands of the bureaucracy.

I can only say tonight, when I know of the plight of the families, of the distress and the pain, that goodness and conscience must be left within some folk within the bureaucracy and those in government who have the ability to direct them. When we come back to this place in a week's time, there must be a resolution; there must be an announcement that the compensation will be paid and that these people will have a chance to have life restored and hope restored.

speech.speaker: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

talker.name: Senator SCHACHT
talker.role: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

talk.start.para: —I want to make a few remarks tonight. It may be coincidental that I am the duty minister when issues relating to customs are raised by a number of speakers and I will respond to those in a moment. Before I do, in my capacity as Minister for Science and Small Business, I want to comment on statements made by the shadow minister for science, Dr Kemp, during a debate in the House of Representatives yesterday and also in a press release that he issued today.

para.tab:
First of all, in a debate yesterday in the House of Representatives, Dr Kemp used most of his time to attack me in my role as minister for science. That is fair enough; it is a political forum; and if you dish it out, you have to be willing to take it, so I am not worrying too much about that.
Dr Kemp said that he had visited the Australian Institute of Marine Science in Townsville and that he was impressed with the work of AIMS. He commented on the excellent work of AIMS and said that it should continue, and commented on the structure that I had proposed back in July, which is now being assessed by the committee chaired by Mr Ken McKinnon.

What I find most interesting is that after this visit, Dr Kemp is laudatory in his comments about the work of AIMS as a stand-alone institute operating in the tropical areas of Australia. I am very pleased he recognises that but what I find astonishing is that in March of this year during the federal election campaign it was coalition policy to merge AIMS with the James Cook University in Townsville.

It is quite clear that Dr Kemp—who may not have been the shadow minister for science, but who was a frontbencher in that period—was not aware of the excellent work of AIMS and was proposing that it be merged with James Cook University. I am very pleased that he now recognises the value of the work done by AIMS. I have never said anything on the record other than that I have always been very impressed with its work. I have also been very impressed with the work of the CSIRO divisions of oceanography and fisheries based in Hobart.

I also want to refer to a statement issued tonight by Dr Kemp on the summary report that I tabled yesterday on behalf of ASTEC entitled
Research and Technology in Tropical Australia
. After making some comments about the report, Dr Kemp cannot help but turn most of the press statement into a diatribe against me as minister for science and my performance. Again, that does not particularly worry me. However, I do want to point out an absolute error in his statement that he continues to perpetrate, despite the fact that I have never said it. In his statement Dr Kemp claims:

During my recent visit to major centres for tropical marine research in Townsville, there was concern expressed about the possibility that tropical R&D could be "lost" in a new institute, particularly if it were located in Adelaide or Perth as Senator Schacht has suggested.

speech.para: I have never suggested any such thing. I have been on the public record from early July of this year saying that I do not support any such institute having its headquarters in Adelaide or Perth. If a new institute were created, the board would make that decision. I would have thought that it would decide that the headquarters of such an institute would be either in Townsville or Hobart where most of the infrastructure for that new institute would be.

para.tab: There is nothing on the public record that I have ever suggested that I am supporting this new proposal only on the basis that its headquarters would be based in Adelaide. This is typical of the ranting of Dr Kemp on these issues. As I say, earlier this year he had no compunction in proposing that AIMS should be merged with the James Cook University—it was just announced by the opposition; now it is recognised that AIMS is an excellent body after he has at least visited the organisation.

I now want to turn to the customs issues raised here tonight. First, I turn to the speech made by Senator Chapman on the amendment to the Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill dealing with retrospective legislation to close off a possible loophole that could have ended the export enhancement program for the car industry. I emphasise `possible loophole'. We in government never conceded that that loophole automatically meant the outcome that was claimed; that is, that people could import cars into Australia without paying a tariff. We did concede in the estimates hearing that there was a chance that if the legislation went to the courts and ultimately to the High Court it could rule against us. No matter how small that risk was, we as a government were not going to put at risk that excellent program and policy for the car industry in Australia.

In the debate today, I listed most of the major car manufacturers in Australia who supported us with this retrospective legislation because they understood that an excellent car industry plan would be put at risk if there was not this retrospective legislation. They themselves were willing to play by the general rules, by the policy as it was announced some years ago by Senator Button.

Senator Chapman raised the issue of a possible further loophole and says that the way it is operating is awkward—I suppose that is the best way to describe it—and unclear.
I would agree with Senator Chapman that there is an element of goodwill in the operation of the car industry plan with the major manufacturers, but they have given no indication other than their goodwill in the operation of that plan. It is true that if that goodwill does come to an end and someone tries to, as Senator Chapman says, break the rules we can revoke it with a determination of legal matters, which I am not an expert in. That is probably a clumsy way to have it drafted.
As always on legal matters, I will take further advice.

Senator Chapman quoted my letter that I sent to him as a result of the hearing. I will again ask the legal section of the Customs Department to have a look at that particular matter. I suspect that the answer will be the same, but this is a legitimate issue to be raised—no-one wants to have to deal with closing of loopholes and retrospective legislation.

I have to say, whoever is the government of the day, sooner or later Senator Chapman will discover, if he is ever a minister, that he will probably have to front up with some retrospective legislation to cover an unforeseen error—not done maliciously or malevolently, but an honest mistake. It is good government to cover those mistakes and repair them. I do not think we ought to expect that we can just let that mistake last so that some people get an unnecessary advantage at the expense of the rest of the community.

Senator Chapman also mentioned the issue of the ex gratia payment made to the agents for Volvo of over $50,000, and, I think, one other company. I have written to the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) who is the only one who has the power to make an ex gratia payment. I have not received an answer the reason being, as I understand it, that investigating an ex gratia payment takes some time. I am sure Senator Chapman would not want us to rush in and establish an unfortunate precedent or make an error about the way we establish an ex gratia payment.

I assure Senator Chapman that I will monitor the progress of dealing with the issue of the ex gratia payment. As I have indicated, I believe such a payment is fair. I said that to the committee after we debated the issue in the hearing and I have said it here in the parliament as well. I hope that we can come back with good news. I do not think it will be as quickly as Senator Chapman would like, or obviously as Volvo would like, because I understand these things take some time.

I now turn to the issue raised by Senator Bishop regarding customs and the famous—infamous, notorious or whatever honourable senators want to call it—long, exasperating saga of Midford Paramount and the Australian Customs Service. I have already spoken briefly in this chamber about this case and about the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts which was tabled in December last year. I have said before in this chamber that I may be one of the very few senators who has actually read the whole 600 pages of that report. Three weeks into the job as minister, I spent the whole of my Easter this year reading the whole of that report. As a result I have had lengthy discussions with the customs officials over many hours, going through one by one not only the recommendations of the report but also the descriptions in the report about what happened in that case according to the public accounts committee.

I think Senator Bishop would acknowledge that we have now tabled in the parliament the recommendations—I think there are 130 of them—that have been accepted by the government as far as administrative procedures are concerned. I anticipate that there will be amendments coming into the parliament in the next sittings to alter the Customs Act in a number of areas—again as a result of the government's acceptance of some of those recommendations in the Midford report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. I have noted before that that report was supported by both sides of the public accounts committee. I think it has been acknowledged that this is not a majority and minority report; it is a bipartisan unanimous report. That fact certainly carried considerable weight in my mind when I read the report.

As Senator Bishop would be aware, since taking on this job I have announced a complete review of the operation of the customs department with the broadest possible terms of reference. It is chaired by Mr Conroy, former chief executive of the Westpac Bank. The two other members of the review are Ian Macphee and Susan Ryan. They have taken submissions all around Australia and had consultations with industry, customs and other interested parties. I do not know whether they have had discussions with Senator Bishop. If they have not, that offer is still there.

talk.start.para: —They have, and I have accepted it. As I have said to you, it is something that I want to see done.

—The offer is there to any member of the parliament and any member of the public to make submissions to that review. I cannot prejudge the review. All I do know is that they are being very thorough in the work they are conducting. I hope that the report, when it is tabled and made available to the public by the deadline at the end of this year, not only deals with some of the obvious complaints that people may have, such as those arising out of the Midford report, but above all else looks at a way of structuring the operation of the customs service in this country that makes it relevant and effective not just for the rest of this decade but into the 21st century.

para.tab: I think the Australian Customs Service, though it is under criticism by such reports as Midford, in a number of areas does an excellent job. It is leading the world in the introduction of electronic technology and removal of unnecessary paperwork. The Compile system is still being developed. It still has some teething problems. We recently adopted optional port of lodgment, with some controversy; some custom brokers completely opposed it. But it means that in the long run we will have a more effective electronic system for people to make their entries into the customs system for their exports or imports.
We are now developing systems whereby this electronic work can be done from ships still at sea before the ship even arrives in Australia.

talk.start.para: —What about the human issue that Senator Bishop raised?

—I ask Senator Reid to let me finish. Customs has been able to develop and use new technology to make an industry sensitive and industry acceptable system. For example, one of the first initiatives under APEC was to establish a committee, chaired by the Australian Customs Service, to look at ways to improve harmonisation to improve the administration of customs procedures between member countries of APEC. That is already well under way. Despite problems that I acknowledge have been raised by Senator Bishop and others, there is much in the customs system to be commended.

para.tab: Finally, I turn to the remarks that Senator Bishop raised about the personal side of those affected by the Midford Paramount case. The IDC, the interdepartmental committee, was established by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to look at the compensation claims of the people affected. Of course, it is chaired by the finance department, as is appropriate in these cases; it is not chaired by the customs department or DITARD. Those departments are able to send observers but they are not full voting members.

talk.start.para: —Yes, they are, Chris.

—They are not voting members; they are observers at the meeting of the IDC. Even if they were full members, it would be very awkward for them to try to use the IDC process to get out from under in terms of paying the compensation when the Prime Minister has clearly initiated this process of assessing such a payment by establishing this IDC. I appreciate that this has taken longer than anticipated. When I have asked about the delay, I have heard that this is because various parties to the Midford dispute, including those seeking compensation, have changed their arguments from time to time. I do not automatically accept that that is correct, but I have heard that put.
—Don't compound the felony.

—I assure Senator Bishop that I want the matter dealt with and cleared up and an announcement made about the compensation to be paid as soon as possible. It is no good for me as minister representing the customs service in this place, or for the customs service itself, to have this hanging around. The issues raised tonight about the personal impact on people are raised with considerable anguish for the people concerned. It is not good for that to continue. I assure the Senate that I will continue to press for an outcome on the compensation issue as soon as possible—but for it to be done properly and effectively with due compensation being paid.

para.tab: I hope that when we return in a week or so there may be some announcement. I assure honourable senators that there is no malevolence or maliciousness on the part of the government in trying to delay sorting out the compensation so that these people are unduly distressed by it. The process has to be done properly and we will get there as soon as possible.

talk.start.para: —How many hours a week are they spending on it?

—As I understand it, they have spent a lot of time on it. How much I do not know, but I understand that it is a lot of time. Whether that is 50 hours, 100 hours or 1,000 hours I do not know, but I do understand that a lot of time has been spent on it and it has not been—
—It is not good enough. Don't try to excuse it.

—The delay has not been deliberate. There is no benefit to the reputation of the Customs Service or the government of Australia by unnecessary delay in this matter, so I can assure Senator Bishop that we will continue to press that the matter be finished as soon as possible.
—You are either in charge or not. Tell the bureaucrats to get off their bots.

—We are pressing the bureaucrats. The chair of the committee is not from the customs department because that would be improper in view of the circumstances. The matter is quite properly with the finance department. We will continue to press it and I hope that when we return for the next two weeks a suitable announcement can be made that will be satisfactory to all honourable senators.

para.tab: Question resolved in the affirmative.

para.emphasis: Senate adjourned at 11.31 p.m. until Monday, 18 October 1993, at 2 p.m.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 24 May 1993:

para.tab: (1) Has $16 million been provided by the Commonwealth under the Helsham package for the establishment of hardwood plantations on Crown land in Tasmania.
(2) Have any conditions been placed on the use of these funds; if so, what are these conditions.
(3) What legislative obligations apply to ensure that Commonwealth funding is not used for environmentally destructive activities.

(4) Does the Tasmanian Forestry Commission intend to establish hardwood plantations; if so, which areas are being considered and which of these areas have already been cleared of native forest vegetation.
(5) Have Helsham funds been used for the establishment of any plantation, in any of these areas; if so, which areas.
(6) What steps will be taken to ensure that all funds provided by the Commonwealth are used for establishing plantations only on land already cleared.

answer.speaker: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.tab: (1) The Commonwealth has approved an allocation of $16 million for the establishment of around 8,000 hectares of eucalypt plantations in Tasmania on both Crown and private land. This is part of the $50 million Helsham structural adjustment package agreed by the Commonwealth and Tasmanian Governments under the 1988 Heads of Agreement following the World Heritage Listing of certain Tasmanian forest areas. It is important to note that a key objective of this package was to enable Tasmania to replace resources which were withdrawn as a result of the World Heritage listing and the agreement specifically included provision for this plantation program. To date, some $4.957 million has been provided to Tasmania for specific activities relating to this project. All plantations established to date are located on Crown land.

(2) The funds are to be used for the establishment of eucalypt plantations in Tasmania, consistent with the intent of the Heads of Agreement. Financial and administrative conditions for the use of the funds are set out in an intergovernmental funding agreement between the two Governments which includes all projects funded under the Helsham package.

Where plantations are to be established on forested land to be logged as part of the Tasmanian Forestry Commission's (TFC) normal operations, the approval of the Minister for Resources is required where this involves export woodchip operations. This is done on an annual basis as part of the Minister's normal consideration of woodchip export licences and in making his decisions, he is subject to the Commonwealth legislative obligations outlined in the response to Question 3 below.
For its part, the TFC is required to adhere to the State's Forest Practices Code which provides a set of standards to protect environmental values during forest operations.

(3) The Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974, the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 and the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992 impose obligations on a Commonwealth Minister relating to avoiding or minimising the impact of activities which would adversely affect the environment, a national estate area or an endangered species, respectively. As noted above, of particular relevance to the Minister for Resources is the obligation imposed in the consideration of proposals for the export of unprocessed wood under the Export Control Act 1982.
To date no plantations under this project have been established in national estate and advice from the TFC is that it is not their intention to do so in the future.

In addition, as noted above, the TFC is required under Tasmania's Forest Practices Act 1985 to comply with the State's Forest Practices Code. The code is designed to protect the following environmental values:
soils
site productivity
landscape
geomorphology
water quality and flow
flora, fauna, genetic resources
archaeology.
(4, 5 and 6) The TFC has established 1401 hectares of eucalypt plantation to date with a further 1840 hectares scheduled for planting in 1993. Helsham funds are being used for all of these plantings.
Location of plantings by TFC districts are:

answer.para: 1992 (proposed)
ha ha
Burnie 100 170
Devonport 238 160
Geeveston 179 297
Deloraine 336 411
Scottsdale 328 315
Fingal 220 365
Smithton - 122

para.tab: Criteria for identifying possible sites for plantings have been set by the TFC and Forests and Forest Industry Council (FFIC) based on physical and strategic characteristics, eg. altitude, rainfall, soil type, proximity to markets. The following priorities are applied in selecting suitable sites:
(1) Cleared land—pasture or previous plantation site
(2) Understocked forest—high site potential but presently stocked with wattle, scrub, etc.
(3) Forested land—logged as part of TFC's normal operations to meet sawlog commitment.
All proposals for plantations are reviewed by the TFC and FFIC to ensure that site selection criteria have been met and that priority has been given to cleared land.

Plantings on cleared land totalled 280 hectares in 1991 and 1992. It is anticipated that, on preliminary estimates, a further 640 hectares will be planted on cleared land in 1993. In addition to these plantings, some 560 hectares have been planted on understocked land which is predominantly covered by wattle and scrub, with a further 590 hectares expected to be planted on similar land during 1993. The balance of the areas planted in those years (561 ha in 1991 and 1992; 610 ha in 1993) was planted on land which had been logged to meet the TFC's sawlog commitments.
TFC's annual targets for plantings mean that all available cleared land is included in the schedule for that year.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 30 August 1993:

para.tab: (1) Given that there have been a large number of complaints, will an investigation be conducted into the repeated low flying of aircraft over residential zones adjacent to Parafield Airport in South Australia.

(2) With reference to an incident on 26 August 1993 between 1900 and 2115 hours, when two aircraft were performing low level circuit training, who owned and operated the aircraft in this incident and was this training conducted within the guidelines that presently exist.
(3) Why was the circuit training level lowered earlier in 1993 despite thousands of residents complaining about the noise created during the circuit training.
(4) Will circuit training cease on Christmas Day, Good Friday, Anzac Day and at other times when the community believes that such activity is not appropriate; if not, why not.

(5) In light of the obvious discomfort being experienced by the residents near Parafield Airport because of this low level training, will steps be taken to alleviate some of the problems being experienced by the local community; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

para.tab: (1) I am aware of the community's concerns about aircraft noise in the vicinity of Parafield Airport. Ways in which the noise impacts of circuit training at the airport may be ameliorated are under regular review.
(2) Neither the Civil Aviation Authority nor the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation have any record of an incident occurring on 26 August 1993 between 1900 and 2115 hours.

(3) The circuit training level was not lowered earlier in 1993. The standard 1000 feet circuit height has been in operation since prior to the introduction of General Aviation Approach Procedures (GAAP) in 1979.

(4) & (5) Circuit training on Public Holidays is primarily a commercial decision for the operator. However, the Government will follow up any practicable measures which have the potential to mitigate aircraft noise at Parafield Airport.
